title: Politics and a Ruptured Tendon Dont Faze Lead Iran Negotiator

title: Inflationistas at Bayes
description: Im putting together a syllabus for one of the courses Ill be teaching this spring  Econ 348, The Great Recession  and in the course of searching for various views about inflation, ended up looking at a dispute from a while back involving some of the usual suspects. Brad DeLong poked fun at John Cochrane for having declared, back in 2009, that the danger now is inflation. Cochrane angrily denied that this was of any significance  he only said that it was a danger, he didnt necessarily predict that it would happen within any particular time frame. (He thereby provided a demonstration of another key fact about our economic debate: nobody ever admits that they were wrong about anything, and nobody changes views in the light of evidence.) title: Rest in Peace, Elwood, Worlds Ugliest Dog
description: A mixed breed dog named Elwood (below), who was named the Worlds Ugliest Dog in 2007 and inspired his owner to write a childrens book about self-acceptance, has died, The Associated Press reported. He was 8 years old. Karen Quigley, 52, of Sewell, N.J., adopted Elwood, a dark-colored, nearly hairless Chinese crested and Chihuahua mix, after a breeder decided that he was too ugly to sell and would euthanize him. His odd appearance, which included heavy eyelids, a protruded tongue that hung out the side of his mouth and a white tuft of hair on his head, was a hit at the Sonoma-Marin County Fair in California, where the ugly dog contest is held. The experience motivated Ms. Quigley to write and self-publish a childrens book that promoted acceptance called Everybody Loves Elwood. The dog later developed an online following, being referred to as Yoda or E.T. by his fans. Elwood appeared at more than 200 events to help raise money for animal rescue groups and nonprofit animal organizations.

description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalias Parliament voted the prime minister out of office on Monday in a no-confidence motion, with 184 of 249 lawmakers in favor, after what was termed a constitutional dispute between the president and the prime minister, Somali officials said.

title: Amazons Blue-Sky Thinking
description: Amazon is promising yet more jam tomorrow  this time from drone deliveries.

title: After Renting Out a Terrace, He Received an Eviction Notice
description: David Shea, a retired typographer, thought that he was renting out his large enclosed terrace to a visitor from Miami who was looking for a cheap place to stay for a few days in Manhattan. The man had contacted him through Roomorama.com, one of several websites that connect travelers with private hosts.

title: Nets and Knicks Share Woes and, This Week, a Floor
description: Thursday is the one day of the week when the N.B.A.s frantic nationwide schedule slows and all eyes turn to a doubleheader showcase on TNT. When the league scheduled this weeks matchup between the Nets and the Knicks, the first of their four meetings this season, it probably expected a game of far more consequence than a meeting of two of the three worst teams in the Eastern Conference.

title: Healing Soldiers Most Exposed Wounds
description: Col. Robert G. Hale fixes faces.

title: What to Expect at the Gothams
description: The traditional starters pistol for the glitzy season in New York is the Gotham Independent Film Awards, taking place tonight at Cipriani Wall Street, with the the comedian Nick Kroll (of Kroll Show on Comedy Central), an old Bagger pal, serving as host. Like its West Coast cousin, the Film Independent Spirit Awards, the Gothams are more of a D.I.Y. affair, full of jokes about tight budgets, short shooting schedules and other difficulties of indie filmmaking, an apparently thankless task that nonetheless inspires devotion in the room.

title: The Great Los Angeles Auto Show Fire of 1929
description: Sunday brought about the end of another chapter in the history of the Los Angeles Auto Show, an event that, aside from 1940 to 1951, has showed off new cars since 1907. This year in the hallway between the two cavernous rooms glinting with new automobiles, there was a long display about the history of the show, bringing to light a bit of trivia.

title: French Court Orders Criminal Trial for EADS Shareholders
description: PARIS  A French court on Monday ordered the German carmaker Daimler and the French media conglomerate Lagardre to face a criminal trial on allegations of insider trading in the 2006 sale of shares in the European aerospace and defense group EADS.

description: Chimpanzees are not people, no matter how they are dressed up for commercials, but perhaps they are close enough that they deserve some of the same rights humans have.

title: Reality Checks on Tumorous Rats and Methane Bombs
description: This is a quick roundup of developments and resources illustrating how the most dramatic front-page thought or activist talking point is always worth examining from the root up. Or, as Carl Sagan liked to say, Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

title: In Thailand, a Drones Eye View of Protests
description: Thailands news media outlets have been increasingly using small, unmanned flying gadgets that give them a birds-eye view of the protests in the streets of their capital. As my colleague Thomas Fuller writes, the miniature drones have circulated videos of the battles, including one between riot police outside the prime ministers office and protesters attacking the barricades.

title: The Gun Report: Thanksgiving Weekend Edition
description: Marissa Alexander, the Florida woman who unsuccessfully argued last year that the states Stand Your Ground law made her immune from prosecution after she fired abullet into a wall in her hometo scare off her abusive husband, has been released from prison as she awaits a new trial. Though no one was hurt, she received a 20-year prison sentence. Alexander had argued that she fired a warning shot from a legally licensed gun to defend herself from a beating at the hands of her estranged husband, a man who had testified to abusing her in the past.

title: Immaculate Stability (Wonkish)
description: David Andolfatto, understandably, rises to Steve Williamsons defense against the barbarians. But Im sorry to say that he still doesnt get the point.

title: In Surprise Win, Laure Prouvost Takes Turner Prize
description: LONDON  The artist Laure Prouvost, whose works combine whimsical objects and drawings in evocative settings with an Instagram-like stream of film images, has won this years Turner Prize, the prestigious and often contentious annual award for a British artist under 50.

title: Brussels to Investigate Deal for British Nuclear Plant
description: LONDON  European regulators said on Monday that they expected to conduct a full inquiry into a deal to build Britains first nuclear power station since 1995, threatening delays that could undermine investment plans for the 16 billion pound project.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 26-Dec. 2, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

title: New Strides in Spaying and Neutering
description: Todd Bruce, a herd manager on a farm in Oregon City, Ore., had long resisted neutering his 5-year-old Australian cattle dog, Cody, for fear of losing the extra set (or two) of legs in the field.

title: A First Report Card Fails to Exceed Expectations
description: Dont compare yourself to others. Let go of striving and accept the world as it is, not as youd like it to be. Practice humility and gratitude. Forty-three years, and this is the Buddhist wisdom Ive learned to embrace, the foundation on which my inner peace rests. Until I got my sons first report card.

title: Rare Biblical Texts From Bodleian and Vatican Libraries Digitized
description: A Gutenberg Bible, a dazzlingly illuminated 15th-century Hebrew Bible from Spain and a copy of Maimonidess 12th-century commentary on the Mishnah written in the philosophers own hand are among the rare bibles and biblical commentaries from the Vatican Library and the Bodleian Libraries at Oxford that have been digitized and posted online, as part of a collaboration between the institutions that went live on Tuesday.

title: As Lundqvist Sits Again, a Hot Hand Turns Cool
description: The Rangers goaltender controversy ended almost as quickly as it began. On Monday morning, Coach Alain Vigneault surprisingly named the first-year sensation Cam Talbot to start against the Winnipeg Jets on Monday night at Madison Square Garden. The decision meant a healthy Henrik Lundqvist would sit out a second straight game  which had not happened since February 2011.

title: Liberal Catholics in the Age of Francis
description: My Sunday column discussed what Catholics on the political right should make of Pope Franciss latest exhortation, and how they should respond to a papacy that has been emphasizing the churchs social teaching in language that Catholics with free-market views might not necessarily be eager to embrace. The other, equally-interesting question, of course is how Catholics of a more liberal persuasion (politically and theologically) should respond to Francis  or, perhaps more aptly, what they should be looking for, hoping for, and working toward in a pontificate whose tone they mostly find congenial, but whose substance has included reaffirmations of Catholic teaching on some of the culture-war issues dividing left and right.

title: Justice Department Approves Microsoft Deal
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft got closer on Monday to completing the most significant deal in the companys history, its $7.2 billion acquisition of Nokias mobile handset and services business.

title: Robots and Property Values

title: Video of Police Brutality in Kiev Fuels Rage

title: Justices Pass on Tax Case From Online Merchants
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ruling from New Yorks highest court requiring Internet retailers to collect sales taxes even if they have no physical presence in the state.

title: A Head for Hunting
description: They may be slow, but seahorses can snatch fast prey because of the unusual shape of their heads. Using a microscope outfitted with a laser and high-speed digital camera, researchers from the University of Texas at Austin observed that the area around a dwarf seahorses nostrils created a no-wake zone in front of its mouth, allowing the animal to sneak up on tiny crustaceans.

Theres probably a budget spreadsheet showing how much youve spent, or one where youve worked out how much youll need in the future. Maybe you even use some budgeting software. Who knew it was so much fun lining up a bunch of numbers?

title: Learning to Defuse the Aorta
description: When Dr. Hal Dietz arrived at Johns Hopkins University in the 1980s, he became obsessed with helping children with Marfan syndrome, a rare and often fatal disorder that can cause the aorta, the large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart, to grow and grow until it bursts.

title: American Brass Quintet Makes Sure It Doesnt Shrink to a Trio
description: Among North American brass ensembles none is more venerable than the American Brass Quintet, which was founded in 1960 and has been a resident ensemble at the Aspen Music Festival since 1970, and at the Juilliard School since 1987. But rosters change, and the retirement of the trumpeter Raymond Mase and the hornist David Wakefield has created two openings in the quintet in quick succession.

title: Men at Work for Women in Labor

title: Uncertainty Comes Fast for Redskins Sure Thing

title: Chinese Leaders Rise Came With New Attention to Dispute With Japan

title: Top U.N. Rights Official Links Assad to Crimes in Syria

title: Building a Cheaper Catalyst
description: The chemical reactions that help produce margarine, medications, cleaner car exhaust and countless other useful things rely on valuable metals like platinum, rhodium and ruthenium as catalysts. But such metals are rare, expensive and occasionally toxic. For years, scientists have tried to develop methods of catalysis using cheap, common, nonpolluting metals like iron and cobalt.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the office of a leading news media group in Karachi on Monday evening, wounding a security guard and underscoring the threats journalists face in the country.

description: Its been a boon literary year for wine lovers. The flow of noteworthy books has been so steady that some seminal works can get lost in the current, like a 25th anniversary edition of Adventures on the Wine Route, Kermit Lynchs prophetic look back at the wisdom and traditions discarded by the mid-20th-century wine industry, presaging a welcome rediscovery and new embrace.

The World Health Organization sharply increased its estimate of 2009 swine flu deaths and architects in Nepal found evidence that Buddha lived centuries earlier than previously thought. Still need something to be thankful for? Researchers in Pittsburgh may have put a number on the cases of contagious disease prevented by vaccines.

The previous Broadway record for the holiday week, set in 2011, was $28.1 million (about $29.2 million after adjusting for inflation).

title: Jazz-Funk Persuasion Rules the Night

title: On an Expansive Stage, a Company Spreads Its Wings
description: LONDON  The mind of the choreographer Mark Morris, as we read it in his dances, is bewilderingly diverse. I first saw his work 29 years ago, in its first London season, and he is as mysterious to me now as he was then  but more marvelously so. Last week, the week after the Mark Morris Dance Groups 25th-anniversary performances of LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato at Lincoln Center, Mr. Morris presented seven recent works in two programs at Sadlers Wells Theater here. They ranged from the tender celebration of eccentricity in A Wooden Tree to the controlled philosophical imagery of Socrates, from the male-female intimate duet of Jenn and Spencer to the intermeshing group patterns of Crosswalk.

title: Mexico: U.S. Indicts a Former Governor
description: The United States has indicted a former governor of a Mexican state that borders Texas in a case that has come to illustrate concerns over political corruption and has embarrassed the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Federal prosecutors on Monday unsealed the indictment charging the former official, Toms Yarrington Ruvalcaba, who served as governor of Tamaulipas State from 1999 to 2005, with racketeering and money laundering. Mr. Yarrington, who is being sought, funneled payments from drug traffickers into Texas banks, real estate and false businesses, prosecutors said. Mr. Yarrington, a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, ran for president in 2005. But he was ejected from the party in 2012 as the inquiry came to light during the presidential campaign of Enrique Pea Nieto, who promised a new PRI, free of corruption.

title: Washington Mayor Will Seek Re-election
description: Mayor Vincent C. Gray of Washington said Monday that he would run for re-election. A spokesman for the mayors office, Robert Marus, said Mr. Gray had picked up petitions to begin gathering the 2,000 signatures required to participate in the Democratic primary on April 1. Mr. Gray was elected in 2010, and his tenure has been shadowed by investigations into that campaign, which was financed in part by $650,000 that was not reported to the election authorities. Mr. Gray has denied any knowledge of wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime, but the investigation is still open and three of the mayors associates have been found guilty. Mr. Grays decision ended months of speculation and was likely to reshape the crowded Democratic field, which includes four members of the District of Columbia Council.

title: New Job After Shots Are Fired: Helping Students Feel Safe
description: On a chill autumn morning, sun poured through the high windows as a young elementary school principal, Meghan Dunn, sat with her staff. On the fifth floor, a middle school principal in the same building, Kiersten Ward, chatted with her parent coordinator and an assistant.

title: In Marketing, Arts the Thing
description: FOR decades, the MGM lion has roared under the slogan Ars gratia artis, or Art for arts sake. On Madison Avenue, executives are busily thumbing through their Latin dictionaries to figure out how to say Art for marketings sake.

title: Britain: Envoy Aims to Mend Iran Ties
description: Britains new envoy to Tehran will travel to Iran on Tuesday, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since Britains embassy in Tehran was stormed more than two years ago. The visit of the envoy, Ajay Sharma, who has the rank of a nonresident charg daffaires, was announced by his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Habibollah-Zadeh, to the official news agency IRNA. Foreign Secretary William Hague confirmed the report in a Twitter message, adding, Well improve U.K.-Iran ties on a step-by-step, reciprocal basis. Mr. Habibollah-Zadeh said that Mr. Sharmas visit would include a look at British diplomatic buildings and talks with Iranian Foreign Ministry officials, and that he would then make a similar visit to London.

But on Monday, the company confirmed that it had bought Topsy Labs, a research company that could help Apple better understand what people are talking about on social media networks like Twitter.

title: U.S. Pledges New Funds to Fight AIDS

The pledge was made as the Geneva-based funds replenishment conference opened in Washington; the funds leaders hope to have $15 billion pledged by Tuesday. Under the terms of the pledge, the United States will pay the full amount only if other countries pledge $10 billion. Dont leave our money on the table, Mr. Obama said. He also said that state waiting lists for AIDS drugs, which grew to more than 9,000 patients in 2010, were finally cleared last week with federal aid under the Ryan White Program. And he said another $100 million in the federal budget would be redirected to AIDS research.

title: The Battle of Fort Sanders
description: By Nov. 29, 1863, Union-held Knoxville, Tenn., had been under Confederate siege for 12 days. The city itself was a war zone. Sharpshooters from increasingly closer vantage points picked off officers and men alike, so accurately that only one civilian was killed among dozens of dead soldiers. Artillery positions exchanged fire around the line.

title: No (Spousal) Benefits for You
description: Following valid orders from higher-ups is central to how the military functions. At least, its supposed to be. But getting every state National Guard unit to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels order that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal and family benefits is proving difficult.

title: Bob Dylan Charged With Inciting Hate Under French Law
description: To people who follow the pronouncements of Bob Dylan, his comment in a Rolling Stone interview in September 2012 suggesting that American blacks could sense whether whites had slave-master blood just like Jews can sense Nazi blood and the Serbs can sense Croatian blood may have seemed just the sort of vaporously impressionistic, emotionally pointed kind of thing that Mr. Dylan has been known to say for decades.

title: The Snowden Files, Press Freedom and Britain
description: Updated 12:58 p.m. As Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, faced questions on Tuesday from members of a Parliamentary committee about publishing classified National Security Agency documents, media organizations from around the world called on officials to uphold Britains commitment to freedom of the press.

title: Image of the Day: December 3
In Our Pages: December 4
description: 1938: Scarlett OHara Chosen

title: Slide Show: Gotham Awards
description: See what Lupita Nyongo and Jared Leto wore to the Gotham Independent Film Awards, the traditional starters pistol for the glitzy season in New York.

title: Times Minute: Dec. 03 at Noon
description: Detroit's bankruptcy ruling; a ballet star is sentenced and movie awards season kicks off.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Overcoming Media Bias
The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Train Engineer Was Dazed Before Crash, Lawyer Says
description: The engineer who operated the Metro-North Railroad train that derailed over the weekend, killing four people and injuring more than 70, told the authorities on Tuesday that he had become dazed before the accident, suffering what his lawyer referred to as highway hypnosis.

title: An Authentic Lambrusco With Posole
description: Posole presents a deeply satisfying array of earthy, spicy, savory and bright flavors, which offer more than a few possible areas of harmony, as long as the wine is low in alcohol and tannins. My first thought: an authentic Lambrusco with dry, meaty flavors and refreshing bubbles that ought to pair beautifully.

title: Spring Breakers, the One Film Cineastes and John Waters Can Agree On
description: Two best-of announcements this week, from the New York Film Critics Circle and the National Board of Review, may help bring some clarity to an overstuffed Oscars contest. At the moment, though, the Bagger is more interested in some lists that probably have little affect on the race but say a lot about how to encapsulate movies. The cineaste journals Cahiers du Cinma (from France) and Sight & Sound (Britain) announced their best films of the year recently, as did John Waters, in ArtForum. There was some overlap.

title: Dance Music Redux
description: Every few years, dance music has a moment in this country  at least, thats how it can seem from afar. But the truth is that ever since disco, dance music has been a constant in American pop, even if it wasnt dominant. And around the world, it is often at pops center, with Americans looking on in curiosity.

title: October Medicaid Applications Far Outpace Enrollment Through Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Tuesday that 1.46 million people had applied and been found eligible for Medicaid or the Childrens Health Insurance Program in October, far more than had selected a private health plan in the new insurance marketplaces.

title: When Is It Safe to Drive After Breaking a Bone?
description: Hands on the steering wheel, one foot toggling between brake and pedal, head twisting to check mirrors. Consider the many bones and joints you must engage before you even turn on a cars ignition, among them the fingers, wrist, forearm, elbow, shoulder, neck, heel, ankle and leg.

title: For Art Basel, Miamis Swankiest Garage Becomes a Gallery Yet Again
description: Right now, the art world and its glamorous interlopers are revving their engines for this years Art Basel Miami Beach, which opens to the public on Thursday. Meanwhile, at the citys premier automotive temple, grease monkeys are putting the final touches on an exhibition of cars as art. The Swiss-minimal garage at 1111 Lincoln Road, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, has become the apogee of Art Basel lavishness and excess since opening in 2010, with pop-ups galore (like this years Colette-sponsored Art Drive Thru, which opened yesterday), and events like 2011s Ferrari fete, during which hot rods paraded up and down the structures seven levels of open-air ramps all night long.

title: How Much Would You Pay to Have a Baby?
description: I love casinos. The sounds, the lights, the corny decadence.  I love it all, except for one thing: I hate losing money. So in the handful of times Ive visited one, Id give myself a high-low limit. If I lost $100 or won $200, Id have to leave. I guess Im not much of a gambler.

title: Billy Joel to Be a Madison Square Garden Franchise
description: Add Billy Joel to the list of franchises  sports teams, until now  that call Madison Square Garden home. At a news conference on Tuesday morning at which Mr. Joel, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and several Garden executives spoke, Mr. Joel was named as the Gardens first entertainment franchise, joining the Knicks, the Rangers and the Liberty.

title: Soccer and Logic Dont Often Mix
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  In 500 words, Im about to logically explain why I do not subscribe to logic.

title: TimesTalks: Diego Luna
description: The actor and director talks about his upcoming movie "Elysium," and the differences between acting for theater and film.

title: Wall Street Toasts Blankfein and Judaism at UJA-Federation Dinner
description: Goldman Sachs emerged from the financial crisis as the whipping boy of Wall Street. But on Monday evening, the firms chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, was feted like a king.

title: Biden Asked to Raise Case of Jailed Nobel Laureate and Wife
description: A group of human rights organizations has issued an open letter calling on Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to press Chinese officials on the plight of two of the countrys most prominent dissidents, Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Nobel Laureate, and his wife, Liu Xia, who is under house arrest and said to be suffering from severe depression.

title: TimesTalks: Ricky Gervais
description: The comedian reflects on his approach to comedy, the success of "The Office" and his new series on Netflix, "Derick."

title: Do You Get In Any Reading Over the Holidays?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Anna Holmes and Pankaj Mishra reminisce about travel, solitude and guilty pleasures.

title: A Chance to Step Into Disneys Childhood
description: LOS ANGELES  The on-again-off-again campaign to turn Walt Disneys Chicago birthplace into an attraction has taken an unexpected new turn. And two theme park ride designers who mostly work for Disney rivals are at the wheel.

title: Louis C.K. Signs Production Deal With FX
description: Louis C.K. is extending his association with the FX network, signing a production deal that will create new shows for the networks under the FX umbrella.

title: The King of Fruits
description: Durian stinks so badly that its banned from hotels and mass transit in parts of Southeast Asia, yet its regarded by some as a delicacy.

title: A Love Letter to a Smelly Fruit
description: When my friend Bob Halliday thinks about durians, the tropical fruit that some say smells like garbage, he not only salivates with delighted anticipation, but he also foams like a geyser. Those were the words he used on the eve of our visit to an orchard north of Bangkok that was filled with these green spiky fruits dangling dangerously from towering trees.

title: Cultivating a Wine Region in India
description: In India, where whiskey is the alcoholic drink of choice and teetotalers exist by the legions, a wine culture has been almost nonexistent. Nashik (also Nasik), a picturesque area with deep green rolling hills about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Mumbai, is finally changing that perception. More than a half-dozen wineries with attractive tasting rooms and, in some cases, restaurants and accommodations, have opened here in the last several years and are turning this fertile valley into a popular oenophile destination for trendsetting Indians.

title: Volcker Rule on Bank Risk Approaches Its Final Edits
description: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | Federal regulators have reached a tentative agreement to complete a rule aimed at Wall Street risk-taking, federal officials said on Tuesday, overcoming internal squabbling and an onslaught of Wall Street lobbying that stymied them for years.

title: Versace Valuation May Be as Over the Top as Its Clothes
description: Versaces valuation looks as aggressive as its outfits. The Italian fashion house, which is sizing up buyout firms and sovereign wealth funds to finance a capital increase, believes it is worth more than 1 billion euros, or $1.36 billion, and could triple in value in three years. There is real potential, because Versace has fallen behind industry trends. But a big price tag for a skimpy minority stake next to a powerful family? Thats hard to pull off.

title: Fed Policy and Inequality
description: Catherine Mann, an economist at Brandeis University, discusses the ways in which quantitative easing has increased wealth among both high-income and lower-income groups.

title: The Gun Report: December 3, 2013
description: In September, Gary Roberts, 57, was shot to death by his wife after he threatened to kill the police officers who were on their way to the couples Greenfield, Ind., home to question him about the arsenal of explosives and some 1,400 weapons he had stored in the basement. Elizabeth Roberts, 56, his wife of 31 years, told police that her husband began loading ammunition into a gun magazine and pledged to kill any officers who came to the home. When she said she would shoot him to prevent the impending bloodshed, he handed her a gun loaded with hollow-point bullets and told her to do what she had to do. She fired one shot into his chest, killing him.

title: For World Cup Draw: 32 Divided by 4
description: FIFA announced which teams would be in each of the four pots for Fridays World Cup draw in Brazil during a news conference on Tuesday in Bahia, Brazil.

title: Whom the Fed Is Enriching
description: At a November confirmation hearing, Janet Yellen was asked whether Federal Reserve policies had mostly benefited wealthy people, while doing little to improve life for the common man. After all, ultra-low interest rates and quantitative easing likely contributed to the run-up in stock prices over the last few years.

title: A Documentary Shortlist Filled With Politics and Music
description: Updated, 3:47 p.m. | Working from a record 151 qualifying films, the motion picture Academy on Tuesday announced the 15 films on the shortlist for the best documentary feature Oscar:

title: Out of the Doldrums, Automakers Post Strong U.S. Sales
description: Sales over the Thanksgiving weekend may have been a disappointment for the nations retailers, but they were a boon for automakers, lifting their sales in the United States for November to the best rate since before the recession.

title: Thomas Keneally to Write Book and Lyrics for New Musical
description: Thomas Keneally, best known for writing Schindlers List but also the author of historical works about the founding of his native Australia, will turn to that subject in Transport, a new musical for which hes written the book and lyrics.

title: 1930 Model A Ford Makes Cross-Country Voyage on Second Try
description: Sometimes, its best to cut ones losses and move on. For Rod Wade, the Australian automotive adventurer whose cross-country run last month in a 1930 Model A Ford was abbreviated by a broken crankshaft, cutting his losses wasnt in the cards. It was time to move on; all the way across the United States.

title: Little Things Stand Out About Baseballs Best
description: The Hall of Fame is baseballs finish line, the ultimate validation for careers that awed and inspired us when we were much younger. We view it with nostalgia because we want to remember the good.

title: Extra FaceTime IDs, and Reordering Email
description: Multiple IDs

title: Pope Francis and the Ghost of Sargent Shriver
description: After my post yesterday contrasting the challenges the Francis era may offer to American Catholics who feel at home on the political right of center with the opportunities it may open up to their more liberal co-religionists, its only fair to also point out the implicit challenge that the new pope is offering to liberal Catholics as well  or at least to liberal Catholics who see their relationship to the church in terms of fidelity as well as criticism and dissent.

title: Sleep and the City
description: Travelers looking for a good nights rest in a city that never sleeps can customize their experience at WestHouse, a luxury boutique hotel scheduled to open in late December.

title: Windsor Terrace: Less Way Station, More Destination
description: For decades the curved, somewhat comma-like shape of Windsor Terrace, in central Brooklyn, seemed almost to symbolize its role: a kind of geographic pause between larger flanking neighborhoods. Squeezed between Park Slope and the various parts of the Flatbush area, and linking them in the process, Windsor Terrace never really achieved the stature of its bigger-name peers.

title: Fried Chickens Northern Exposure
description: Heres a culinary etiquette question: Does a bottle of bourbon qualify as a dish, as in bring your favorite Southern dish?

title: Why Tracey Emin Is in a Miami State of Mind
description: Tracey Emin has always been associated with London. Its where she studied painting before achieving early notoriety as one of the Young British Artists. Its the place she unveiled her infamous camping tent, embroidered with the names of all the people shed ever slept with. Its the city in which she continues to live, work and teach.

title: Taconic Capital Co-Founder to Retire
description: Kenneth D. Brody, a co-founder of the hedge fund Taconic Capital Advisors, plans to retire from his full-time role by the end of the year, he told his investors on Tuesday.

title: Editor Describes Pressure After Leaks by Snowden
description: The top editor of the British newspaper The Guardian told Parliament on Tuesday that since it obtained documents on government surveillance from a former National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden, it has met with government agencies in Britain and the United States more than 100 times and has been subjected to measures designed to intimidate.

title: Preview: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
description: Oscar Isaac and Adam Driver in a clip from the Coen brothers new movie.

title: New York, Circa the 60s, Reborn in New York, Circa Today
description: How the Coen brothers new film starring Oscar Isaac and Carey Mulligan recreates a lost bohemian downtown.

title: Positively Fourth Street, All Over Again
description: One primary pleasure of the Coen brothers new movie, Inside Llewyn Davis  a film that is abundant in its pleasures  is revisiting a New York that most New Yorkers thought was gone for good: Greenwich Village of the early 1960s, when downtown was teeming with bohemians and dreamers and not with lost tourists holding upside-down maps. Davis follows a Bob Dylanesque folk singer named Llewyn Davis and unfolds mostly (with a few detours to far-flung uptown and Chicago) in that fabled realm of a lost New York, complete with cold-water flats and smoke-filled subterranean clubs.

title: Syria Crisis Is Worsening, U.N. Relief Official Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  The top emergency relief official at the United Nations expressed new alarm on Tuesday at the humanitarian crisis caused by Syrias civil war, telling the Security Council that despite some modest progress, both the government and insurgent sides were still impeding urgent deliveries of food and medicine to millions of desperate civilians.

title: Text to Text | I Have a Dream and The Lasting Power of Dr. Kings Dream Speech
description: Last summer was the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. painted his dream of racial equality and justice for the nation that still resonates with us. I have a dream, he proclaimed, my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. In this Text to Text, we pair Dr. Kings pivotal I Have a Dream speech with a reflection by the Times literary critic Michiko Kakutani, who explores why this singular speech has such lasting power.

title: Beyond Brisket and Burritos in Austin, Tex.
description: People who say that Austin isnt at all like the rest of Texas should look a little harder. The capital city may swaddle its Lone Star bravado in slacker irony, swap out big hair for cycling musculature and express its rugged individualism with six-strings rather than six-shooters ... but really, were talking about the same prideful, gabby, strangely infectious psychodynamic. Even for Austins most rabid Gov. Rick Perry haters, defecting from the state is not an option: they adore being Texans, one and all, and appreciate that the term sets them apart somehow.

title: How a Growing Business Set Itself Apart
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, founder of Atrium Staffing. This post continues the conversation with Ms. Cenni, who explained how her $140 million staffing and payroll firm differentiates itself.

title: Court Is Accused of Unfairly Targeting a Continents Leaders
description: Little noticed outside Africa, a movement against the International Criminal Court has been brewing on the continent this fall, challenging a unique but often polarizing international mechanism to prosecute grave human rights abuses.

title: International Criminal Court Wrestles With Applying Law, or Bending
description: THE HAGUE  As the International Criminal Court takes up its highest-profile trials to date  the case of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto  it is wrestling with a question that so often looms over international justice: Should the law prevail, or bend to the demands of diplomacy and political stability?

title: Surprising New Face in Arabic Music
description: The Arab world has an unlikely new star: an American who sings  but barely speaks  Arabic. Not only that, her genre is traditional Arab music.

title: TimesTalks: Kim Cattrall
description: The actress talks about acting for theater as opposed to television, and moving out from under the shadow of Samantha, her character on Sex and the City.

title: TimesTalks: Metallica
description: The band talks about their new film, Metallica: Through The Never.

title: Charlie Bird
description: Inside the SoHo restaurant that gets packed early on and stays that way for hours.

title: A Relaxed Air, but Attention Must Be Paid
description: THE HARDEST-WORKING WOMAN in the food business one recent night was the host of Charlie Bird, in SoHo. Armed with nothing but good cheer and a smile that could stop a war, she had the unenviable job of preventing an uprising in a waiting area by the door that might comfortably hold three people if they were very skinny and could survive for minutes at a time without breathing. There were around 10 of us.

title: American Hustle Makes a Showing With Critics Circle
description: The late-arriving American Hustle, which reunites David O. Russell with much of his casts from The Fighter and Silver Linings Playbook, was the surprise winner with the New York Film Critics Circle, which announced its year-end picks on Tuesday. The film, set loosely around the 1970s Abscam scandal, took best feature, best screenplay (for Mr. Russell and Eric Singer) and best supporting actress, for Jennifer Lawrence. It is among the final entries in the very tight Oscar race this season and beat out expected competitors like 12 Years a Slave, Nebraska and Inside Llewyn Davis.

title: The Art of Plating
description: Amanda Cohen, the chef and owner of Dirt Candy, showcases the different qualities of spinach in this beautiful construction.

title: Beautiful Plates
description: Food meets plate in a process far more elaborate and elemental than many may realize.

title: The Ceramic Canvas
description: Wait. We know youre hungry. We know youre ready to use that shiny fork as a battering ram. But before you dismantle and devour that dish of beautiful food placed in front of you, take a moment to look at it. Really look.

title: Americanized Labor Policy Is Spreading in Europe
description: In 2008, 1.9 million Portuguese workers in the private sector were covered by collective bargaining agreements. Last year, the number was down to 300,000.

title: Supreme Court Considers Frequent Flier Contracts
description: WASHINGTON  Rabbi S. Binyomin Ginsberg used to fly often enough on Northwest Airlines that he achieved Platinum Elite status, the highest level. But the airline revoked his membership in its frequent flier program in June 2008, saying that he had abused it by making too many complaints and by booking himself on full flights in the hope of being bumped.

title: House Votes to Extend Gun Law Without New Provisions for 3-D Printed Firearms
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Tuesday to extend a law banning firearms that can pass undetected through airport X-ray machines, but left out provisions that law enforcement officials say are necessary to combat the growing threat of guns made with 3-D printers.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Black Action Tees
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: The Real Health Care Distraction?
description: In the last few weeks its been trendy, in Republican circles, to claim that anything Democrats do or say unrelated to the Affordable Care Act is a ploy to distract attention away from the problematic HealthCare.gov rollout. (Really, anything: filibuster reform or a diplomatic breakthrough with Iran.)

title: She Makes That Much on Broadway?
description: On TV Land, you dont sweat the details. Three Hollywood harpies accidentally land in Ohio, move in with Betty White and date young cornfed hunks (Hot in Cleveland)? Of course. Three men share an apartment owned by their wacky divorce lawyer (The Exes)? Why not.

title: When Life Resembles Art  or at Least Monty Python
description: As a dude of a certain age whose so-called formative years were lived in the mid-80s, I have spent a good portion of my life trying to perfect my Cockney accent in falsetto and forcing Monty Python expressions into everyday conversation. Sometimes its not easy. Then there are times like last week.

title: Oyster Bar Franchise Opens in Brooklyn
description: Headliner

title: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Central African Republic, Thailand, Bahrain and Ukraine.

title: Obama Urges Focus on Health Care Laws Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday urged Americans to refocus on the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, pointing to people who had already avoided costly health care expenses because of the laws provisions.

title: The City of Angels and Crime and Seriously Stylish Hats
description: Warning: In the Land of Noir, things move more slowly than they do in our usual television cop show universe. Men  and, yes, its mostly men in the Land of Noir  walk with an odd combination of shuffle and swagger that is not designed for speed. Conversation is sparse. Deliberate. Nobodys in a hurry to get his words out.

title: T.R. Fehrenbach, Historian, Dies at 88; Chronicler of Larger-Than-Life Texas
description: T. R. Fehrenbach, a historian and journalist whose sweeping treatment of Texas history portrayed the state as an almost mythic land, powerfully pleasing many Texans while mightily rankling others, died Sunday in San Antonio. He was 88.

title: Expansive and Teasing, and Still a Superstar
description: For the last few years, Garth Brooks, ubiquitous high-energy country megastar of the 1990s, has been more or less in hiding, spending time with his family and only peeking his head out from under his shell for occasional one-man shows  focusing on the music that influenced him  at the Wynn Las Vegas casino, where he had a residency beginning in 2009.

title: Kozlowski Is Granted Parole
description: Come January, L. Dennis Kozlowskis long tenure in New York States penitentiary system will near its end.

title: Bach as a Mensch and an Imperfect Human Being
description: Not to proclaim that an authors first book will necessarily stand as his magnum opus, but it is hard to imagine what the English maestro John Eliot Gardiner, 70, might do to surpass Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven in its commitment, scope and comprehensiveness. True, as Mr. Gardiner writes and has amply shown over the decades, he is equally (though differently) drawn to the three Bs  Beethoven, Berlioz and Brahms  and could have mustered equivalent fervor for writing about Monteverdi, Schtz or Rameau.

title: On Piano, and Staying Attuned to the Audience
description: Eric Yves Garcia, a Manhattan piano bar entertainer who toiled in semi-oblivion at Chez Josephine until his recent appearances at the New York Cabaret Convention, belongs to the school of jazz-leaning connoisseurs of the American Songbook epitomized by the irreplaceable Bobby Short. If Mr. Garcias sprightly appearance at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Monday evening says anything about the frustrations of turning out semi-anonymous background music in a restaurant, it might be that inside many a piano bar musician beats the heart of an aspiring concert entertainer, waiting for his moment.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Worlds Most Expensive Phone, and Why We Like Listicles
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Instruments May Look Standard, but the Sounds They Create Are Not
description: At the start of the Mannes Percussion Ensembles concert on Monday evening James Baker, the ensembles director, announced a change in the program. Two planned works had been dropped, he said, because the group had decided it would rather prepare fewer pieces at a higher level of polish than bite off more than it could comfortably chew.

title: Fraternal Ties, of Gut and Sinew
description: In movies, the working class often serves as a sacrificial emblem of the failure of the American dream, one that these days is often embellished with lovingly photographed decay and an elegiac air. Set in a corroded stretch of the Rust Belt, Out of the Furnace ups the ante with a story of two blue-collar brothers  a steel mill welder and a former soldier  who are as totemic as the figures immortalized in a Works Progress Administration mural. Its a heavy, solemn tale of blood ties that turns into a melodramatic gusher filled with abstractions about masculinity, America and violence, but brought to specific, exciting life by Christian Bale, Casey Affleck and Woody Harrelson.

title: Proving That Ailey Never Stands Still
description: On a recent afternoon, 10 dancers from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater caught their breath after a run-through of Chroma, an exceptionally fast-paced, convoluted work by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor. The windows of the fifth-floor studio offered sweeping views of Midtown Manhattan, but the city looked almost sleepy next to the dancing that had just happened.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute: Dec. 03 at 6 p.m.
description: President Obama makes a health care announcement; a government shake-up in North Korea; and the future of the pencil.

title: A Home School Where the Lessons Are Subtle
description: Desultory, dauntingly DIY but secretly efficient, Breakfast With Curtis is something like a leafy summer afternoon in movie form. This is the third feature from the writer and director Laura Colella, who has shot it in and around her own well-loved, multifamily Victorian and the house next door. Her neighbors play the films overlapping, underdressed group of friends and family. This micro-indie movie is partly about a taciturn, home-schooled teenager, Curtis (subtly played by Jonah Parker), coming out of his shell, but its mostly about hanging out.

title: Police Officer Charged in Queens Extortion Racket
description: Shortly after opening a new restaurant in Astoria, Queens, this year, the owner received an unwelcome visitor, he said, who explained that it would cost him money to operate in our neighborhood.

title: Illinois Legislature Approves Retiree Benefit Cuts in Troubled Pension System
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.  The Illinois legislature on Tuesday ended a day of emotional debate and fierce back-room arm-twisting by passing a deal to shore up the states debt-engulfed pension system by trimming retiree benefits and increasing state contributions.

title: Bryant and Messi Try to Repeat a Hit Airline Ad
description: A commercial for Turkish Airlines that unexpectedly became a worldwide hit in social media, drawing more than 105 million views on YouTube in the last 12 months, is getting a sequel.

title: A Rare Glimpse at Some of the Finest Jewelry and Objects Ever Made
description: When Kate Middleton married Prince William in Westminster Abbey in April 2011, she wore a delicate Cartier diamond tiara known as the Halo Scroll. In 1936, the Duke of York purchased it from the French jeweler for his wife, three weeks before they ascended to the throne and became King George VI and Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother. She later gave it to her daughter, Princess Elizabeth  now Queen Elizabeth II  as an 18th birthday present.

title: Busy in Gray Areas of the Law in a Bid to Control a Rival
description: In Charles W. Ergens war for LightSquared, the fiercest fight involves a legal loophole.

title: Super PAC to Raise Money for Liz Cheneys Senate Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Supporters of Liz Cheney, whose campaign for a Senate seat in Wyoming got off to a rocky start, have created a super PAC to bolster her name awareness and approval rating. The group is hosting a high-dollar fund-raiser this week in Washington featuring her father, former Vice President Dick Cheney, at a Georgetown restaurant, according to an emailed invitation.

title: A Traditional Audio Company Enters the Wireless Realm
description: The growth of the market for wireless speakers has slowly been enticing more traditional audio companies to cut their wires, too. And a recent offering from Klipsch shows that high-end audio companies know how to fit a lot of sound into tiny wireless speakers.

title: Real Estate Rumblings in Ho Chi Minh City
description: After years in the doldrums, the Vietnamese real estate market is showing signs of life. But many analysts say banking and political reforms are needed before a healthy rebound will be possible.

title: Optimism Over Vietnam Property, With Caveats
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  Dinh Thien Thiens barbecue business bloomed just as Vietnams property market wilted. It was not a coincidence.

title: Lamperts Firm Cuts Its Stake in Sears
description: Edward S. Lampert, the hedge fund manager who serves as Sears Holdings chief executive, remains the struggling retailers biggest shareholder.

title: A Gaming Headset for Players on the Go
description: As consumers shift more of their attention from console games to mobile apps, gaming accessory makers are following suit. The latest offering comes from Turtle Beach, which has released a headset designed specifically for mobile media.

title: Frank, Once Kidds Right-Hand Man, Is Demoted
description: Less than two hours before the Nets tipped off against the Denver Nuggets on Tuesday, Coach Jason Kidd announced a change to his staff. Lawrence Frank, Kidds top lieutenant and the Nets only assistant with head-coaching experience, was being reassigned away from game and practice duties.

title: Quest for Meaning, Millennial Edition
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Dressing Answers May Be in Your Closet Now
description: The most wonderful time of the year can be more stressful than festive if youre fretting about what to wear (and perhaps a looming credit-card bill). But you may not need to look beyond your closet. There must be a black dress, white dress, pantsuit or sequined sheath in there somewhere. Then give it the fun it deserves with unexpected, eye-catching accessories. Any one of these will do the statement-making trick.

title: President Karzai and the Afghan Security Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: Self-Gifting? Please
description: To the Editor:

title: The App Age Comes to a Longstanding Tradition
description: These days, even many of the most ingrained holiday traditions are subject to technological advances.

title: Keep the Old-Style Phones!
description: To the Editor:

title: Activists Fear Egypts Police Force, First Target of Protests, Is Out for Revenge
description: As they have for nearly three years, activist filmmakers in Egypt continue to document the death of protesters at the hands of the security forces.

title: Director of Barnes Foundation Steps Down
description: The Barnes Foundation announced on Tuesday that Derek Gillman will step down as executive director and president as of Jan. 1 to become a visiting professor at the Westphal College of Media Arts & Design at  Drexel University.

title: We Hear You. You Dont Want to Hear Us.
description: My column this week, Disruptions: Want Calls on Planes? Youll Need to Speak Up,generated quite a vociferous response from readers. I noted in the column that the Federal Communications Commission was considering allowing the use of cellphones on planes, and readers noted in the comments that they were vehemently against such an idea.

title: For the First Time, a Former Player Will Lead the Baseball Players Union
description: Less than two weeks after the death of the union leader Michael Weiner, the executive board of the baseball players association named Tony Clark as his replacement on Tuesday. PETERSBURG, Russia  An odd thing about the investigation into what exactly happened in the Arctic on Sept. 18 between activists on a Greenpeace International ship and the Russian authorities was how little the investigators asked about the episode when they called the 30 crew members in for questioning, one by one, from their isolated holding cells.

The fishery for northern shrimp, also called pink shrimp, was worth an estimated $1.2 million in its limited 2013 season; in 2011, according to regulators, it was worth more than $10 million.

description: The Metro-North Railroad train that derailed on Sunday included a system designed to warn an operator of a potential accident. But such an alerter, which can automatically apply the brakes if an operator is unresponsive, was not in the cab where William Rockefeller apparently fell into an early-morning daze at the controls. It was at the other end of the train.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: To Make Hospitals Less Deadly, a Dose of Data
description: Going to the hospital is supposed to be good for you. But in an alarming number of cases, it isnt. And often its fatal. In fact it is the most dangerous thing most people will do.

title: Truck With Radioactive Load Is Recovered in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  The theft of a truck carrying radioactive material, the kind used in hospitals but also potentially as a dirty bomb, unnerved Mexico and set off a two-day hunt before both the vehicle and its potentially lethal contents were found Wednesday at nightfall.

title: The 10 Best Books of 2013
description: The years best books, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

title: Brazuca: The World Cup Ball

title: A Three-Way Race Draws Delhis Young, and Everyone Else, Out to Vote
description: NEW DELHI  The polling stations were supposed to close at 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, just after sunset. But with thousands still waiting in the dark to cast their vote in the state assembly elections, the Delhi Election Commission decided to extend the voting until 6:30 p.m. Then to 7:30 p.m.

description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: U.S., Stepping Up Role, Will Present West Bank Security Proposal to Israel
description: CHISINAU, Moldova  American officials plan to present the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, with detailed ideas about security arrangements on the West Bank under a possible peace agreement with the Palestinians, senior State Department officials said on Wednesday.

title: The Souths Forgotten Painter
description: The Southern painter Conrad Wise Chapman is not nearly so well known as his Northern colleagues Winslow Homer and Sanford Gifford, but he deserves historical attention  if only because he appears to have been the only Southern artist to sustain a career while wearing the uniform of the Confederate Army.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Out of the Furnace
description: Scott Cooper narrates a sequence from his film featuring Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe.

title: Neon Works Light Up the Art Scene in Miami
description: Neon makes people happy, the British artist Tracey Emin said Tuesday night, Thats why you see it in Las Vegas, bars, brothels and theaters. She was standing in a darkened gallery at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami, surrounded by dozens of her signature neon works and looking very happy herself.

title: For Top Deputy, de Blasio Picks Government Veteran
description: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio made the first big appointment of his administration on Wednesday, naming Anthony E. Shorris, a former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a commissioner in the Koch administration, his top deputy.

title: Mandy Greenfield to Become Artistic Director of Williamstown Theater Festival
description: The Williamstown Theater Festival, a leading summertime destination for New York actors, directors, and writers to collaborate on ambitious productions, has chosen an Off Broadway leader as its new artistic director. Mandy Greenfield, the artistic producer of Manhattan Theater Club, will succeed Jenny Gersten beginning in September, the festival announced on Wednesday.

title: Times Minute: Dec. 04 at Noon
description: Vice President Biden arrives in China; a school in Queens battles the subway; and a refugee seeks a better life.

title: Surviving the Dark Side of Affiliate Marketing
description: The Santa Claus Christmas Store, in Santa Claus, Ind., was typical of a lot of brick-and-mortar businesses when it sought to expand its online footprint earlier this year. In addition to sprucing up its website and increasing its pay-per-click advertising budget, it joined an affiliate marketing network. This connected the 7,000-square-foot holiday emporium with the vast community of bloggers, coupon sites and other affiliates around the web that promote products in return for a percentage of each sale they encourage.

title: Think the E.R. Is Expensive? Look at How Much It Costs to Get There
description: Kira Milas has no idea who called 911, summoning an ambulance filled with emergency medical technicians. Ms. Milas, 23, was working as a swim instructor for the summer and had swum into the side of the pool, breaking three teeth.

title: Interference Costs Coach of Steelers $100,000
description: Pittsburgh Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin will presumably think twice about where he stands on the sideline this weekend when his team faces the Miami Dolphins.

title: Is Affiliate Marketing Worth the Risk?
description: When e-commerce retailers try to drive sales by introducing affiliate marketing programs, they frequently contract outside program managers to help them recruit the best affiliates and to ferret out the coupon abusers, the cookie-stuffers, and the other unsavory characters who drive up their commission costs and erode their bottom lines (the subject of a small-business guide just published by The Times).

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Parliament Versus the Press
description: Ever since Edward Snowden leaked documents on the National Security Agencys data-mining programs, governments of countries such as the United States and Great Britain have tried to dismiss the concern that mass, secret surveillance is incompatible with an open, democratic society. So it was chilling and more than a little ironic to see members of the British Parliament grill a newspaper editor on Tuesday for daring to publish information on government spying.

title: Were Heading to London! (But How to Take the Dog?)
description: When this newspaper decided to transfer me from upstate New York to London, the first question from my house was what would happen to our 2-year-old golden retriever.

title: Story First, Maps Second
description: Every tech start-up has its creation myth.

title: Beats Music Streaming Service Says It Will Begin in January
description: The music world has spent more than a year guessing when Beats Music, the new service from the makers of Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, would arrive. Now theres an official date, or at least a month: January.

title: Ebb in Uranium Enrichment in U.S. Raises Questions About Nuclear Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Energy Department officials will shake hands and exchange congratulations with Russian representatives at a Port of Baltimore dockside ceremony on Tuesday as a freighter from St. Petersburg is to arrive with the final shipment of enriched uranium that was once intended for Soviet warheads. The uranium will be turned into fuel for American power reactors, completing a 20-year program, called Megatons to Megawatts, that has eliminated enough highly enriched uranium to fuel about 19,000 warheads.

title: Classical Playlist: Anna Caterina Antonacci, Mivos Quartet, Matthew Brown and More
description: Times critics share what theyve been listening to lately.

title: Poetry, and Motion
description: Since we are now entering the time of year when theater producers turn to Rockettes and blessings from Tiny Tim, consider The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, a new staged reading of the harrowing 1798 poem by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, counterprogramming. The epic poem, performed by the illustrious Irish actress Fiona Shaw, features a sailor stopping a man on a way to a wedding to tell of a trip at sea that becomes cursed after he shot an albatross. His crew mates force him to wear the dead bird, which gives us the expression albatross around your neck.

title: Libor Bank Fines Reflect Rewards of Cooperating
description: The rewards of early settlement in the scandal involving manipulation of the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, are becoming more obvious.

title: Three Rockwell Classics Bring Nearly $57.8 Million
description: Three paintings by Norman Rockwell celebrating homey, small-town America, among the most popular of his 322 covers for The Saturday Evening Post, sold at Sothebys on Wednesday morning for a total of nearly $57.8 million, about twice their high estimate.

title: Below the Line: Making Gravity
description: With its immersive feel, large-scale visuals and adventurous pacing, Alfonso Cuarns sci-fi drama Gravity has won over critics and audiences alike  a good sign its Oscar possibilities. And with its long-take action sequences set in zero gravity, it has become one of the most how did they do that? movies of the year. Heres a little on how they did it.

title: Serbian-Born Composer Wins $100,000 Prize
description: Djuro Zivkovic, a 38-year-old composer who was born in Serbia and lives in Stockholm, has won the 2014 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition for his work On the Guarding of the Heart. The prize, awarded annually by the University of Louisville, is among the most prestigious international prizes for classical composition and carries a cash award of $100,000.

title: Lundqvists Deal With Rangers Is From the Heart
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Henrik Lundqvist said he wanted to be a Ranger for life, and now he will have that chance. The Rangers announced Wednesday that Lundqvist had signed a seven-year contract extension, ending speculation that he might depart when his contract expired at the end of the N.H.L. season.

title: The Magic of West Point
description: My students jest that I earned my degree from Hogwarts. I dare not correct the record.

title: A New Plan for Norton Museum of Art From Norman Foster
description: The Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday unveiled a new master plan designed by the British architect Norman Foster that will nearly double its gallery space and add an education center, auditorium and restaurant.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Redfeather Snowshoes
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Student Debt Load Found to Vary by College and State
description: Rising student debt has become a national concern, but the picture is far from uniform, with students at some colleges borrowing 10 times as much as their counterparts at other colleges, a report released Wednesday says.

title: Super Bowl Advertising Is Already Sold Out, Fox Executives Say
description: The phrase going, going, gone is associated with baseball rather than football, but Fox Broadcasting is telling advertisers that commercial time during Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2, 2014 is, finally, gone.

title: Student Debt and the Class of 2012
description: The Institute for College Access and Success reports not only enormous variation in student debt from school to school, but also wide differences by region.

title: Video: Classically Structured in Bucharest
description: Recently, Victor Placinta was strolling in the old center of Bucharest, Romania, an area known for its historic architecture, and, in more modern times, as a cultural hub where coffee-guzzling intellectuals gather.Wearing a tailored green blazer, a pinstriped shirt, a yellow tie and cuffed jeans, he described his style to an interviewer as classic.

title: Russias First Smartphone Goes on Sale
description: MOSCOW  Russias first smartphone  a quirky, dual-screen device with a traditional LCD-color display on one side and an electronic-paper display similar to the Amazon Kindle on the other  began selling in Russia and several other European countries on Wednesday.

title: Poll Finds Young People Souring on Health Law and Obama
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of 18- to 29-year-olds  a constituency crucial to the success of President Obamas health overhaul  disapprove of the law, and fewer than a third of those who are uninsured are likely to sign up for coverage, according to a new poll by Harvard Universitys Institute of Politics.

title: Image of the Day: December 4
Majority of Silent Films Are Lost, Study Finds
description: The Library of Congress announced on Wednesday the results of a survey that found that 70 percent of the feature-length films made in the United States during the silent era have been lost. The reasons range from the natural deterioration over time of highly flammable nitrate film stock to outright neglect.

description: The N.F.L. has banned an adby a gun components distributor from airing during the Super Bowl, despite the fact that it was specifically designed to fit the rules that would allow it to be broadcast.

description: Is it this nostalgic time of year that inspires people to cloak technology in a rustic covering?

title: Enrollment Numbers Rise After Website Improves
description: WASHINGTON  About 29,000 people successfully navigated HealthCare.gov and selected an insurance plan on Sunday and Monday, more than the entire number of people who were able to enroll through the federal exchange during the month of October, according to a person familiar with the project.

title: Baffling 400,000-Year-Old Clue to Human Origins
description: Scientists have found the oldest DNA evidence yet of humans biological history. But instead of neatly clarifying human evolution, the finding is adding new mysteries.

title: Two Brothers to Lead Bowdoin Music Festival
description: The cellist David Ying and his brother, the violist Phillip Ying, have been named artistic directors of the Bowdoin International Music Festival, a summer festival and music school with a strong current of contemporary music running through its chamber and orchestral programs. The festival, held at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, was founded in 1964 by the violinist Lewis Kaplan, who will hand over the reins to the Yings at the end of the 2014 season.

description: In this video, the writer and director Scott Cooper narrates a sequence from his drama featuring Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe. He discusses where he shot the scene and how he gave direction to the actors to create a particularly tense moment between them.

description: Frances McDormand leads us on a brisk docent tour of the life, career and varied obsessions of the artist Suzanne Bocanegra in Bodycast, an odd but highly enjoyable dramatized lecture being presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Fishman Space through Saturday.

description: Adam Fleming and Julia Sommer were surprised by how much they loved Brooklyn.

description: The National Board of Review did little to provide clarity to a jumbled race with its best-of picks, announced Wednesday. The organization chose Spike Jonzes near-future romance, Her, as best film, with Mr. Jonze as best director.

description: Players throughout the league are exploring tonsorial frontiers that make a mockery of the sports rigid, militaristic heritage.

title: A Supernova of Bad Sex? Manil Suri Wins Uncoveted Award

description: People who use statin drugs to lower their cholesterol sometimes complain of muscle pain and soreness. But a new study suggests that in some cases these side effects may be a result of combining statins with other medications.

title: Kiev Protesters See Potent Ally Under a Spire
description: KIEV, Ukraine  After riot police officers stormed Independence Square here early Saturday, spraying tear gas, throwing stun grenades and swinging truncheons, dozens of young protesters ran, terrified, scattering up the streets. It was after 4:30 a.m., the air cold, the sky black. As they got their bearings, the half-lit bell tower of St. Michaels Golden-Domed Monastery beckoned.

title: Lawmakers in France Move to Discourage Sex Trade
description: PARIS  After months of heated debate, the French Parliaments lower house on Wednesday took the first step in criminalizing the purchase of sex, approving a package of legislation to discourage prostitution.

title: Text to Text | How Photography Helps Astronomy and Comet Nears Sun
description: What are comets, and why should we care about them? How have scientists studied them in the past, and how do they study them now? In this Text to Text, we pair an article from the Times archives about the then-cutting edge technology that allowed astronomers to photograph Halleys comet in 1910 with a recent Times article highlighting what astronomers hope to learn about the origins of the solar system from space-based observations of Comet ISON.

title: This Weeks Cant-Miss Events Around Miami
description: The 2013 edition of Design Miami throws open its doors today, and Art Basel Miami Beach  follows suit tomorrow, but the city has been packed with fairgoers since Monday who have been flocking to the countless ancillary happenings. Below, a few destinations not to be missed. T will bring continuing coverage of whats happening around Miami throughout the week, with some additional wrap reports early next week, so stay tuned, and be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram at @tmagazine for more.

title: More Than Words Can Say
description: Last Friday, Peter Kaplan, one of the greatest editors of his generation, and a name to rank among those like Gingrich, Felker and Shawn, died of cancer at the age of 59. Within hours, fellow journalists had taken to Twitter to mourn his loss and celebrate his life.

title: Heady Days for Hair in the N.F.L.
description: It was a scene worthy of the Roman Colosseum. After stuffing a run by Arizonas Andre Ellington in a game Nov. 17, Jacksonville defensive end Jason Babin emerged from the pile of bodies clutching a mysterious black tangle of what looked like snakes; he thrust it into the air like a victorious gladiator.

title: Would a South Korean Lars Peter Hansen Have Won the Nobel Prize?
description: Nobody (in the United States) likes the results of the PISA tests (the Program for International Student Assessment). As Motoko Rich writes elsewhere in The Times, 15-year-olds in the United States scored in the middle of the developed world in reading and science, while lagging in math, setting off a familiar round of hand-wringing (in the United States), blaming (ditto) and credit-taking (that would be in other, more successful countries, like South Korea, Japan and Singapore).

title: Connecticut High School Cancels Student Production of Rent
description: The principal of Trumbull High School in Trumbull, Conn., has become the latest administrator to cancel a drama club production of the musical Rent, which deals frankly with sexuality, drug use, HIV and love in the lives of straight and gay characters.

title: The Image Chaser
description: In the late 1990s, when Pascal Dangin was one of the few people who knew how to retouch digital images  fixing the folds of a dress, adding more sunshine  he was something of a genie in a bottle. A former hairdresser, he had taught himself to perform a new kind of magic in a world of artifice. It brought him wealth and the top fashion photographers and art directors.

title: Martin Bashir Resigns From MSNBC Over Palin Comments
description: Following a firestorm over his recent comments about Sarah Palin, the MSNBC host Martin Bashir resigned on Wednesday, citing what he called his ill-judged comments.

title: Snowboarders Hike All Night for Descent
description: In this companion piece to Teton Gravity Researchs Higher Unplugged series, the snowboarder Jeremy Jones traveled to the French Alps to join big mountain rider Xavier de Le Rue.

title: NATO Cites Urgency in Reaching Pact Between U.S. and Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  International officials signaled new urgency on Wednesday for the United States and Afghanistan to reach an agreement on a long-term security deal, but officials suggested that there had been little movement on either side of the deadlock.

description: A dual review of whats new, starring Michael Kors and Amy Sedaris.

title: Scene City: Another Stop on Hillary Clintons Gala Circuit

description: WHAT WILL 2023 LOOK LIKE? Or 2061? If you take your cue from Her, Spike Jonzes cinematic fantasy set in an indeterminate time and place, the future wont look so very different from the here and now.

title: Video: Snowboarders Hike All Night for Descent
description: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: Deeper, Further and now Higher. These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

title: Icahn Discloses Latest Push for an Apple Buyback
description: Carl C. Icahn hasnt exactly been quiet about his efforts to persuade Apple of the wisdom of a giant share buyback. Now, hes on the cover of Time magazine pressing his case.

title: One Direction Tops Album Chart
description: One Direction shot to the top of the Billboard album chart this week, as record sales rose over all, thanks in no small part to abundant Black Friday discounts.

title: 12 Years a Slave and Our Hopeless Conversation About Race
description: In the past month, two prominent liberal writers  my former colleague Frank Rich and my frequent sparring partner Jonathan Chaithave written pieces for New York Magazine linking the film 12 Years a Slave to contemporary debates about race and conservatism. Both pieces, unfortunately, are textbook examples of why those debates tend to go nowhere in a hurry.

title: Dialysis Raises Hard Questions for Older Patients
description: The population of people on dialysis is graying; adults aged 75 and older are the fastest growing group beginning this treatment. But often doctors dont answer their key question: How long can I expect to live?

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Ukraine, Gabon, Syria and Thailand.

title: Indian Voters Poised to Weaken Governing Congress Party
description: NEW DELHI  Voters in the Indian capital turned out in record numbers on Wednesday to vote in a closely watched state election, forcing officials to keep polling places open for two or three extra hours to accommodate tens of thousands of people still waiting to vote.

title: A New Artisan Trail in Virginia
description: Arts, food and farm lovers can explore 75 stops in Shenandoah County, Va., along the new O Shenandoah County Artisan Trail. The easily accessible region, part of the mountainous Shenandoah Valley, flanks Interstate 81 on both sides.

title: AMC Singles Out Fans With Coming I.P.O.
description: For serious moviegoers, the viewing experience might not be complete without popcorn, soda and now, perhaps, a share or two of stock.

description: Banking trade groups, fearful of a push by the United States to scrutinize the overseas trading activities of large international banks, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday that challenges new guidelines put in place recently by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

description: Mark Pryor of Arkansas holds one of the more vulnerable seats in the Senate. A Democrat in a state that voted for Mitt Romney in 2012, hes facing an opponent, Rep. Tom Cotton, whos supported by both the Tea Party and the Republican establishment.

title: Dismissing Free Speech Claims, Justices Turn to Plain Line-Drawing
description: WASHINGTON  John D. Apel says his First Amendment rights were violated when he was convicted of breaking federal law by entering an area set aside for protests near the main entrance to Vandenberg Air Force Base, from which he had been banned.

title: The Path to Happy Employment, Contact by Contact on LinkedIn
description: If youve ever attended a local business networking breakfast in hopes of making new contacts or finding a new job, youll be excused for wondering why you were there.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New by Michael Kors and Amy Sedaris
description: The fashion designer, known for his all-American style and his wit as a judge on Project Runway, and the best-selling writer-actress share their thoughts on custom-made tees, 24 samples of gin and artsy Converse shoes.

title: Service? Maybe Its a Danish Thing
description: FIRST, A WORD ABOUT SERVICE. Shops of New York City: I would like your help sometimes.

title: At Every Stop, Drawing a Crowd
description: Have you run into Hillary Rodham Clinton lately? If not, you clearly havent been getting out enough.

title: Jean-Michel Cousteau Designs a New Ritz Kids Program
description: The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company said Wednesday that it had revamped its Ritz Kids program, designed for children between the ages of 4 and 12, in its 80 hotels around the world.

title: That Splendid Swing, and Yet So Many Errors
description: So the hero gets his head cut off on Page 11. Some baseball book!

title: Heres to Good Health (but No Toast)
description: Not long ago, at a Midtown luncheon hosted by Arianna Huffington and Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self magazine, Dr. Frank Lipman, 59, was settling into his seat on a panel along with the wellness stars Deepak Chopra and Joy Bauer.
