description: The Chinese Internet firm Qihoo 360 Technology Company has significantly increased its bet on a Brazilian cloud-based online security company, PSafe Tecnologia, by leading a $30 million round, the company said Wednesday.

title: Elixir, a New Gay Bar in Queens
description: The diverse borough of Queens is now home to an equally diverse gay bar. Opened earlier this year in the bustling neighborhood of Astoria, Elixir is owned and operated by two transgender women, Lidia Jimenez and Marilyn Sulay, who have created a place popular with that branch of the LGBT community, too.

title: Work Inspired by Trayvon Martin Case to Have Premiere on Thursday
description: A free showcase of short plays and a folk opera about race in the United States, inspired by debates over the Trayvon Martin case, will have its premiere on Thursday at the City University of New York Graduate Center. Called Facing Our Truth: 10-Minute Plays on Trayvon, Race and Privilege, the project comes from the New Black Fest, which supports innovative plays by and about black people.

title: Giving Fans the Hits, of Course, but Including Some Reflection
description: The album Elton John released this year, The Diving Board (Capitol), was radically stripped down and introverted. Most of the music is acoustic: just piano, bass and drums behind exposed vocals. Would that approach carry over to his latest arena tour?

title: For News Media, a Mostly Cautious Approach to Newtown Tapes
description: Media outlets reacted mostly with caution on Wednesday to the release of 911 calls from inside Sandy Hook Elementary School during last years shooting rampage in Newtown, Conn.

title: G.M. Said to Plan Sale of Stake in Ally
description: General Motors plans to sell the last of its holdings in Ally Financial, its onetime financing arm, through a private placement of shares, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

description: President Obama spoke at the Center for American Progress about the hurdles faced by some Americans, like income inequality and a growing lack of upward mobility.

title: A Sundance Lineup Laced With Race, Horror and Family Turmoil
description: LOS ANGELES  What will art house theaters be playing in 2014? Sundance programmers on Wednesday threw their weight behind a cluster of new films that largely explore race and messy families, two tried-and-true indie themes.

title: Sundance, Film by Film
description: The Sundance Film Festival has released its competition lineups for its 30th edition in January, and as the Baggers colleague Brooks Barnes reports here, though the programmers largely opted for films along themes they know well  race and family  they also took an unusual turn into horror. Over all, were seeing films that are of much higher quality, John Cooper, Sundances director, said. We think a lot of that is coming from technology, which has freed filmmakers from limitations, including financial ones. You can do special effects now.

title: Winners Crowned at Fall North American Championships
description: PHOENIX  Several national titles have been gained here over the last few days at the Fall North American Championships.

title: Big Composer on Campus: A Vocal Tribute to That Curriculum Mainstay, Britten
description: One hundred years after his birth, Benjamin Britten has been firmly propelled into the canon through his acceptance by major opera companies and orchestras. But what has fed and continues to feed the fire of interest is the attractiveness of his works to young musicians, and particularly young singers. It is because he has been embraced by conservatories that he has truly entered the musical bloodstream.

title: Fifth Third Bank and Executive Settle Charges With the S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it had settled with Fifth Third Bancorp and its former chief financial officer, Daniel Poston, in a case involving improper accounting for soured mortgages around the time of the financial crisis.

title: Miami Museums Challenge: The Beach
description: MIAMI  Visitors who turn off Biscayne Boulevard at the entranceway to the new Prez Art Museum Miami may wonder for a moment if they are in the right place. The dust-covered road runs past a huge construction site, where a science museum two years from completion is still just a structural skeleton.

title: Not Just for Breakfast Anymore
description: It started simply enough: Some months ago, I needed to make myself something to eat, and I had a few ounces of leftover scallops from dinner the night before. I remembered something I learned in Madrid called a tortillita, which inspired me to produce a kind of eggy pancake  or, if you like, a floury omelet  laced with shrimp, parsley and onion. I beat together an egg and a little flour until smooth, wanting to thicken the mixture just enough so that it wouldnt run in the pan. I chopped the scallops and added them to the batter, along with a bit of onion, some parsley, salt and chopped fresh chile, shallow-frying all this by the spoonful in abundant oil. Predictably, the little guys  eight in total  took a couple of minutes per side to become gorgeously golden. I sprinkled them with salt, squeezed a few drops of lemon over each and ate the entire batch by myself, in about the same amount of time they took to cook.

title: Apps to Smooth Your Journey
description: Many travel apps, while great in principle, are too complicated, wonky or simply not helpful enough to earn a spot on your smartphone home screen. Some, however, can make travel easier. And who doesnt want that during the frantic holiday season? Besides, now that smartphones can be used during takeoff and landing, theres no time like the present to turn yours into a personal travel assistant. So whether this seasons travels take you up in the air or on the road, here are a few of my favorite apps to make the journey smoother.

title: Lawson, Celebrity Chef, Admits Cocaine Use, but Denies Ex-Husbands Claims
description: LONDON  Nigella Lawson, the celebrity chef, acknowledged in court on Wednesday that she had taken cocaine and other drugs from time to time. But Ms. Lawson said she was not the kind of habitual user that her former husband, the advertising executive Charles Saatchi, had described in a private email.

title: Suspect in Killing at Los Angeles Airport Is Held Without Bail
description: RANCHO CUCAMONGA, Calif.  The man charged with opening fire with an assault rifle, killing an airport safety officer and shooting three others at Los Angeles International Airport last month made a brief initial appearance before a federal judge here on Wednesday, his face scratched and his neck bandaged.

title: A Plus-Size Falstaff Grows Into His Outsize Part
description: His mounting unpaid bar tab at the Garter Inn will run to its 6,000th bottle of sherry. He will send off his 400th love letter to Windsors merry wives. And, before his final comeuppance and joyful last laugh, he will hear his 2,400th chime at midnight in Windsor Park.

title: Hagel Details 20% Cut in Personnel Who Report to Him
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday unveiled details of a plan to save at least $1 billion in personnel costs over five years through a 20 percent reduction in the number of Pentagon staff members who report to him.

title: Swiss Open Inquiry Into Collection That Was Transferred to Unicef
description: ZURICH  The authorities here are investigating the transfer to Unicef in Germany of one of Europes largest and finest private art collections, a vast trove amassed by Dr. Gustav Rau, an eccentric collector and philanthropist who died in 2002.

title: Listen Up | A New Voice for the Girl-Pop Revolution
description: Its safe to say, in the wake of the success of artists like Lorde and Icona Pop, that were currently in the midst of a girl-pop revolution, and hot on the heels of this trend is Femme, a 25-year-old from London who cites her inspirations as a proper mishmash of Motown and Destinys Child. I only started messing around with music when I was 16, she said yesterday while waiting for a flight to New York, where she performs tonight at the Mercury Lounge, the second stop on her debut United States tour. For me, making music was always just for fun.

title: Michael Urie: Lessons From a Master Shopper
description: On a recent Saturday morning, the actor Michael Urie was part of the throng filtering past the ticket takers in the opening hours of the Pier Antique Show on the West Side of Manhattan. The reed-thin Mr. Urie, who is around six feet tall (I say 5-11, so not to get typecast as tall) seemed to feel at home among the sharp-eyed shoppers, being a frequent visitor to flea markets and vintage clothing stores.

title: A Futuristic Exercise
description: The Hunger Games is set in a dystopian future, but the characters are dressed to the hilt for it. In the second installment of the series, they wear clothes by Alexander McQueen, the Indonesian designer Tex Saverio (whos outfitted Lady Gaga) and  to practice survival skills in the training center  Lucas Hugh, a luxe London-based workout brand.

title: Perfect Lip Shades, Created by You
description: In this age of customized everything  lattes, sneakers, Monopoly boards  its perhaps surprising that most women still leave their cosmetics colors to the experts.

description: Michael Bastians advice: Dont abandon every shred of your regular style just because its a holiday. Its not Halloween. Here are some options.

description: Even in a world where nothing should be taken for granted  banks, climate, Miley Cyrus  one may persuasively argue that most people are pleased to receive a party invitation. The old joke still holds: What are the two saddest words in the English language? What party?

title: Dear Internet, Thank You for Introducing Us
description: Every couple has a how we met story, usually a sweet account of the moment their eyes met across a crowded room or how a chance encounter led to love. How many of those tales now include a mention of dating apps like Tinder, messages exchanged on a dating site, or a particularly thoughtful remark on an Instagram photo that led to coffee and beyond?

title: In Miami, a House Comes to Visit
description: Patrick Seguin is known for his Paris gallery, his friendship with Jean Nouvel, who designed it, and his treasure trove of 17 restored houses by Jean Prouv. He has exhibited a house here and there, in Paris and Turin, but he has never before had his workers pack a whole Prouv house into 10 crates and ship it to America. The 8X8 house (8 meters by 8 meters, or about 26 feet by 26 feet) is one of two 1945 Prouv houses Mr. Seguin found in Bezaumont, France. (The other is a historical monument.) Made in a factory and easily assembled and taken apart, they were an elegant, thrifty solution to the postwar housing crisis in France. The 8X8 house is on display at Design Miami in Miami Beach through Sunday, furnished with pieces by Prouv and Pierre Jeanneret. In Miami, it would make a high-status pool house. No need to be a billionaire to go for one of these houses, he said, but the price is $2.5 million. Information: patrickseguin.com.

title: Patterns With Stories to Tell
description: Bisazza, a leading Italian producer of tile, is introducing two glass mosaic patterns by the Milanese designer Paola Navone, whose globally inflected style is becoming familiar to American audiences, thanks to her collaborations with Anthropologie and Crate & Barrel. For one pattern, Affresco, she translated a traditional floral design into something colorful, grainy and surrealistic, aiming to make the images look as if plaster had been peeled away to unveil frescoes beneath the surface. Halo-Halo, her black-and-white take on Pop Art and graffiti, which she describes as perhaps pictograms by some distant civilization or a board game from an imaginary place, is available in nine motifs that can be used in a multitude of configurations. Bisazza also introduced its first ceramic tiles, designed by Antonio Citterio, collaborating with Patricia Viel, and Marcel Wanders. Affresco is $44 to $68 a square foot; Halo-Halo is $324 a square foot. Information: 212-334-7130 or bisazza.com.

title: Pretty, but Wheres the Kandinsky?
description: Readers will be forgiven for not immediately seeing the connection between Vasily Kandinskys paintings and Madeline Weinribs new napkins for the Neue Galerie, where an exhibit of the Russian artists work is on view. The idea was to collaborate, not copy Kandinsky, Ms. Weinrib said via email from India. I decided to reimagine one of my favorite patterns, using colors from Kandinskys Fugue painting. I thought the combination of colors would complement a variety of dishes, with a modern unexpected punch. That pattern, called Daphne, is usually hand-woven in silk Ikat. Ms. Weinrib used hand-printed cotton instead, which made possible the intricate design, as well as machine washing. A set of four napkins, one each in blue, celery, iris and navy, is $100 at the Neue Galerie Design Shop. Information: 212-628-6200, extension 496, or shop.neuegalerie.org.

title: A Millennial D.I.Y.-er With the Digitized Touch
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On the morning of Oct. 4, a line of women snaked out the doors of the Festival Pavilion at Fort Mason Center, a space the size of an airplane hangar at the edge of the bay here. They were waiting to get into a conference for makers  artists, designers, chefs and other do-it-yourselfers, headlined by Brittany Morin.

title: Classics From Midcentury Given a Second Chance
description: While developing a line of midcentury-inspired products, employees of Stanley Furniture in North Carolina collected 40 of the companys original pieces from the 1950s and 60s by scouring sources like eBay and Craigslist. Each item was stripped down and restored to its original condition with updated paints, finishes and upholstery. Twenty-nine of the pieces  part of a group now known as the Heritage Collection  will be sold online starting Thursday at One Kings Lane. The pieces are true to what midcentury furniture was all about: a great attention to detail, a precise design, honest materials and construction that can withstand the test of time, said Adam Tilley, Stanley Furnitures vice president for product. Its nice to see that all those things we held dear are still alive today. The MixN Match Armchair is $1,199. Information: onekingslane.com.

title: Reassessing an Uproar in Architecture
description: Adolf Loos, the enigmatic Moravian-born architect, is better known for his writings than his buildings. A century after the publication of his polemical essay Ornament and Crime, a Columbia University exhibition called Adolf Loos: Our Contemporary examines his enduring relevance. Loos provoked a furor in 1910 with the severe facade of a mens tailoring shop and apartment block facing the imperial palace in Vienna. It became known as the house without eyebrows for its lack of decoration, and Emperor Franz Josef was said to have drawn his carriage curtains when he rode past. By contrast, Le Corbusier acknowledged the Modern movements debt to Loos, saying he scrubbed under our feet; it was a Homeric cleansing  precise, philosophical and logical. Yehuda E. Safran, who organized the show, had more to say about him. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

The caller was Sheikh Hasina, the prime minister. The recipient was Begum Khaleda Zia, the leader of the political opposition.

title: Alan Wanzenberg: A New View on Life
description: One was self-taught, his hungry, intuitive eye shaped by his years at Andy Warhols Factory, and by curating the artists multifarious acquisitions, creating order and beauty at Warhols townhouse. The other was more formally (if not quite traditionally) educated, at Berkeley, Harvard and by a fresh-out-of-grad-school job as a young architect at I.M. Pei. Together, Jed Johnson and Alan Wanzenberg formed one of the most influential design partnerships of the 1980s and early 1990s, making sensuous, modern environments for celebrity and art world heavies like Richard Gere, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall, Peter and Sandy Brant, and Beth Rudin De Woody.

One of those weird steppingstones that youve got to go through as an actor.

title: Mobile Payments Gain Traction Among Indias Poor
description: MUMBAI, India  In a narrow room filled with acrid fumes in one of the worlds largest slums, Chinak Ramtheol earns about $4 a day tending machines that melt and slice plastic trash into pellets for recycling.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has never visited the rugged mountains of Chechnya, but if he digs into one of the novels he bought last weekend, A Constellation of Vital Phenomena, he will be transported to a land of unremitting violence and tragedy, where the innocent are caught up in war as often as the guilty.

Other people in the crowd of about 200 did the same, puffing on devices like a red-tipped cigarette clone, a green glass hookah and something that looked like a black pencil with a glowing blue tip.

description: In its ongoing effort to protect the American public from the War on Christmas, Fox News has a special online map highlighting current reported atrocities. I am looking at it now, and the message is clear: as problems go, this one is imaginary.

description: IN just over a decade the United States will need 130,000 more doctors than medical schools are producing. So says the Association of American Medical Colleges, which warns of a doctor shortage that will drive up wait times, shorten office visits and make it harder for Americans to access the care they need.

title: Food Carts in Los Angeles Come Out of the Shadows
description: LOS ANGELES  The dance plays out daily in MacArthur Park, Boyle Heights, South Los Angeles and elsewhere across this sprawling metropolis: A lone police car rolls slowly past a popular corner, sending dozens of street vendors scrambling for cover, pushing tamale carts around corners and into the doorways of nearby shops.

title: Recalling TVs Golden Age, Stars Pitch Products Tied to Their Shows
description: DURING the golden age of radio and the early years of television, when advertisers and agencies owned the programs they sponsored, a popular way to pitch products was with what were known as cast commercials: Cast members of the programs would deliver a spiel or two during their shows, often in character and usually with a gentler touch that soft-pedaled the hard-selling tactics of typical commercials.

description: Jon Horvaths memory failed him again during the insider trading trial of his former boss, Michael S. Steinberg, once a top trader at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

description: For 17 unholy years, Mary Woods, 56, called the streets of Manhattan her home. Crack cocaine was her sustenance, prostitution her trade. That all changed in 2009, when an arrest for the criminal sale of a controlled substance put a more permanent roof above her head: that of a jail cell on Rikers Island.

description: Any longtime Red Sox fan can ritually recite the list. When I heard that Jacoby Ellsbury, who was last seen running toward the World Series dog pile at Fenway Park, agreed to sign with the Yankees, I immediately thought of the others who have played for both teams. It is not a happy list.

description: As fast-food workers plan yet another round of one-day strikes on Thursday in cities around the country, labor leaders, economists and industry officials continue to debate the potential effects of raising wages at companies that often assert that such increases would raise consumer prices and shrink the work force.

title: Amsterdam Has a Deal for Alcoholics: Work Paid in Beer
description: AMSTERDAM  After more than a decade out of work because of a back injury and chronic alcoholism, Fred Schiphorst finally landed a job last year and is determined to keep it. He gets up at 5:30 a.m., walks his dog and then puts on a red tie, ready to clean litter from the streets of eastern Amsterdam.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 4, 2013
The President on Inequality
description: The issues that have obsessed Washington for the last few months  the government shutdown, the broken health care website, the unrelentingly bitter tone of a stalemated Congress  mean very little to most Americans. For a broad swath of the country, what matters hasnt changed since the recession, and it is economic anxiety. Six in 10 workers in a Washington Post poll last week said they were worried about losing their jobs, the highest number in decades. Many of the millions who are unemployed have reached new depths of despair.

title: As Yankees Take Big Bites, Mets Nibble
description: The Mets are confident in their starting rotation. They have a left-hander and four right-handers, power arms for the front end and proven, solid options for the back. All of the starters are younger than 30.

title: Egypts Latest Constitution
description: Egyptians are squandering another chance to build a broadly inclusive democratic system with the latest constitutional revisions. The new charter defies the revolutionary promise of the Arab Spring by reinforcing the power of institutions that have long held Egypt in an iron grip.

title: New Yorks Legalized Bribery
description: The panel deputized this summer to investigate corruption in Albany released its first report this week. It is, quite properly, scathing  a damning list of the ways that New York State politicians twist, abuse and sometimes break the law to enjoy the fruits of a pay-to-play government where large donors set the legislative agenda. The 25-member panel  The Commission to Investigate Public Corruption  has done New Yorkers a great service. It has provided one of the best guidebooks for reforming Albanys corrosive culture in many decades.

title: SolarCity to Use Batteries From Tesla for Energy Storage
description: Commercial building owners, even those who reduce their overall energy use, have long struggled to cut special power fees that are based on periods of highest demand.

description: CHISINAU, Moldova  In a lightning visit to Moldova, Secretary of State John Kerry pledged American support on Wednesday to help this former Soviet republic develop closer political and economic ties with the European Union.

description: An unarmed, emotionally disturbed man shot at by the police as he was lurching around traffic near Times Square in September has been charged with assault, on the theory that he was responsible for bullet wounds suffered by two bystanders, according to an indictment unsealed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: U.N. Official Details Plans for Removing Syrias Chemical Arms

description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.  First came the State of Illinois, now comes the City of Chicago.

title: Paul Aussaresses, 95, Who Tortured Algerians, Dies
description: Gen. Paul Aussaresses, who stunned France in 2000 when he asserted that he coldbloodedly tortured and summarily executed dozens of prisoners during his countrys brutal colonial war in Algeria decades earlier, died Tuesday in La Vancelle, France. He was 95.

title: Massachusetts: Warren Rules Out a Run for President
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the freshman Massachusetts Democrat who has been mentioned as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, said Wednesday that she would not run. I pledge to serve out my term, which expires in January 2019, she told reporters. I am not running for president, she said. I am working as hard as I can to be the best possible senator that I can be. She had been promoted by some liberals, without her encouragement, as a populist alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Rediscovering Form, McIlroy Also Finds Some Perspective

A Sudanese man who in 2011 pleaded guilty before a military commission at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to charges of conspiracy and providing military support to terrorism has finished the portion of his sentence he was required to serve and will be sent home soon, the Pentagon announced Tuesday.

title: How Yanks May Proceed, Cano or No Cano
description: Jacoby Ellsbury had his physical exam Wednesday, one of the final steps before completing his seven-year, $153 million contract with the Yankees. Now that he is essentially a member of the team, there is still the matter of who will be playing alongside him.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 5, 2013
description: In the black community, the image that gay men are sissies is amped up a billion times. And we all have an aunt who goes to church and says, Being gay is wrong. That makes young men hide.

title: China Pressures U.S. Journalists, Prompting Warning From Biden

And there were also legions of living ants shuffling over the dead ones  though Mike the Hog-a-Nator had to bend down to see these. Otherwise, so many individual ants were moving so chaotically, and so fast, that the entire reddish-brown tangle at his feet looked as if it were shimmering. description: Loyal readers and commenters here in Baggerland have been wondering about the late-breaking additions to the awards melee, like American Hustle and Wolf of Wall Street, films that have yet to be released. Do the critics groups, voters and other all-important prognosticators get a chance to see them on the big screen before they make their pronouncements about what they liked best this year?

title: At the Broadmoor, Free Lessons in Tango and Tennis
description: The Broadmoor, the 744-room, 3,000-acre resort in Colorado Springs, recently introduced more than a dozen weekend activities and classes that its guests can participate in for no cost through the end of April.

title: German Official Assails Unrepentant Bank Executive
description: BERLIN  Wolfgang Schuble, the German finance minister, made a sharp and unusually personal attack on Thursday on the co-chairman of Deutsche Bank, Jrgen Fitschen.

title: Nominee for E.U. Bank Regulator Moves Closer to Post
description: FRANKFURT  Danile Nouy, the French official proposed to lead Europes new banking regulator, on Thursday received the overwhelming backing of a key committee of the European Parliament, virtually assuring she will get the job.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: male doulas, sleep hormones and feeding baby. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Living With Cancer: Nude Mice
description: A tense moment at a meeting of my support group convinced me that cancer patients have wildly divergent needs for information about their condition. This is especially true when the disease is considered chronic, rather than curable.

title: Downton Abbey, the Long Island Version
description: Among the most noticeable residents of Southampton in the early 1900s was Samuel Longstreth Parrish, a local benefactor who donated the land for Southamptons hospital, helped establish its library and founded its art museum. His former home, headquarters of the Southampton Historical Museum, is now the setting for Downton Abbey Style in Southampton: 1900 to 1920, an exhibition about mansions and millionaires and their many servants.

title: Aficionados on Walkabout at Art Basel Miami Beach
description: And then on the second day, they had brunch. After the frenzied opening hours of the Art Basel art fair in Miami, ambitious shoppers and browsers ambled into Thursday a bit more leisurely, taking in coffee and bagels with their art at the homes of some of Miamis top collectors. Dennis Scholl, a vice-president at the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, and his wife, Debra, have donated 300 works to the newly christened Prez Art Museum Miami. But they still had plenty left to show off at their terraced apartment, which sits a stones throw from the convention center, home base for the fair.

title: Two Remaining Rebel States
description: What a difference a day (sometimes) makes. On Tuesday, I reported here that three states  Mississippi, Georgia and Louisiana  were still refusing to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels order issued in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given spousal and family benefits. That was down from eight states as of mid-November that were refusing to process applications for benefits at Guard facilities, or issue identification cards required to claim benefits, includingmedical services on the Guard members home base.

title: Old Enough at Heart
description: I am a seventh grader in New York City, and I love going to the theater, especially with my friends. Now that I can no longer buy under-12 tickets, mine cost just as much as everyone elses in the theater, but I am still treated like a child who cant behave. How should I respond when anxious ushers tell me not to kick the seats in front of me before Im even seated? Or when adults warn me that taking pictures is not allowed, which everyone knows? I dont want to whine (like a child), but I dont want to be patronized, either. Any suggestions?

title: Rough Trade NYC Puts Live Music On Hold
description: Rough Trade NYC, the record store and live music club that opened last week in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has canceled shows in its performance space, apparently to improve its soundproofing after noise complaints, the store announced Thursday.

title: Kozlowskis New Job: Software Company Clerk
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski was once a high-flying chief executive, perched atop Tyco International.

title: On Other Side of Country, a Lesson in Chemistry
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  While everyone in the East is trying to figure out what is going so sideways with the Knicks and the Nets, the West is puzzling over how the Portland Trail Blazers, who won 33 games last season, are off to a 16-3 start, the best in the conference. If there was any question that their start was a fluke, the Blazers answered by dealing the Indiana Pacers their second loss of the season on Monday and outgunning the Oklahoma City Thunder, 111-104, on Wednesday.

title: Tapas, and More, by Brothers From Spain
description: When Sangria 71 opened in early September, it took Williston Park by storm, and the deluge of patrons continues. On a recent Tuesday night (an off night at most restaurants), Sangria 71 was packed. A man at a table near the center of the room complained, I feel like Im in the middle of the New York City Marathon. He was talking about the swarm of waiters whizzing by, trying to keep up with the crowd of customers.

title: Take Your Best Voice to the Singalong at BAMcaf
description: Millions know the actor and comedian Harry Shearer as the voice of multiple characters on The Simpsons; still others recognize his work on Saturday Night Live or Le Show on NPR. For the Miser, however, none of those achievements compares with his tour de force performance as Derek Smalls, the hapless bass player for the heavy-metal outfit in This Is Spinal Tap, Rob Reiners wildly influential 1984 mockumentary.

title: New Zealand Vampires and Nazi Zombies at Sundance
description: A feral swarm of mass savages.

title: Seeing New Jersey as a State of Inspiration
description: The New York art worlds attitude toward New Jersey has not changed much since the art critic Ted Castle wrote in 1978, New Jersey is practically not a place.

title: Larb Ubol
description: Inside the Hells Kitchen Thai restaurant where the focus is on the food.

title: Awaiting Worst Storm Surge in 60 Years, Britain Closes Thames Barrier
description: As Britain braced for the worst tidal surge in more than half a century, the massive steel barriers that protect London were being shut to save the capital from the possibility of deadly and damaging floods.

title: 3 Concert Halls Complement and Compete
description: Still riding a wave of popularity after 50 years of touring, the Beach Boys are very likely to sell out both shows they have booked at the Tarrytown Music Hall on Dec. 14, according to Bjorn Olsson, the halls executive director.

title: Afghan Policewoman Is Killed, Fourth in Last Six Months
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed a policewoman in western Afghanistan on Thursday, wounding her daughter and two other family members who were with her. It was the fourth killing of an Afghan policewoman in the last six months.

title: And You Thought You Knew Thai
description: To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hells Kitchen.

title: Gym or Dance Floor? Either Works
description: EVER since I got a C+ in a modern-dance class in college  despite my sincerest effort  I have been keenly aware that I am no dancer. Attempts over the years to learn other forms, including hip-hop and salsa, confirmed this. Yet I stubbornly persist. So when I learned about a K-pop dance class, I decided to give it a whirl.

title: Casing the Greenwich Village Exteriors of Inside Llewyn Davis
description: In order to recreate the look of Greenwich Village in the early 1960s for their new movie, Inside Llewyn Davis, the Coen brothers filmed on real streets in present-day New York, installing props and adjusting the cameras lens in ways that made the environment seem true to the time period. As the magazines culture editor Adam Sternbergh writes in this weekends magazine, finding the right location for each shot was crucial (the filmmakers avoided using special effects).

title: A Warhol Is Said to Be Bought by a Walton
description: As the dust settles after last months enormous fall auction season, it remains a mystery who bought Francis Bacons Three Studies of Lucian Freud, for $142.4 million, and Andy Warhols Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster) for $104.5 million.

title: Too Late to Book a Holiday Getaway? Not Necessarily
description: Were into December, when last-minute planners from New York and other scarf-wearing regions start dreaming of spending Christmas break on a Caribbean beach somewhere, anywhere. Or, to put it more accurately, dream of having had the foresight to plan such a trip in August, when prices  both flights and hotel rooms  were still reasonable. Conventional wisdom has it that booking now for a late December getaway is a fools errand, and a rich fool at that.

title: Old World Butchers, Preserving Traditions at the Holidays
description: Like a lot of Italian-Americans, David Perrotti enjoys the Feast of the Seven Fishes on Christmas Eve. But for Mr. Perrotti, 66, of Martinsville, the annual seafood extravaganza is not just a way to preserve tradition. It is also a night off from worrying about the centerpiece of a holiday dinner. Scores of dinners, actually.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Cassina x Louis Vuitton Chaise Longue
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: High Body Mass Linked to Hearing Loss in Women
description: A high body mass and a large waist are both associated with self-reported hearing loss, a new study has found.

title: Antiques Stores Fall to Online Offerings
description: Manhattan antiques shops founded decades ago are vanishing at an alarming rate, unable to compete with online offerings. No trace remains of Elliott Galleries presence on East 79th Street; its white marble storefront has been razed. Yale R. Burge Antiques, on East 62nd Street, is closing and will auction inventory at Doyle New York in January. The former home of Cove Landing, on Lexington Avenue, has sat empty while the proprietor, Angus Wilkie, tucks inventory into his apartment storage spaces and organizes short-term displays at the W. M. Brady gallery on East 80th Street.

title: Where Babysitting Is Truly an Art
description: LET grown-ups have their personal chefs, personal shoppers and personal pilots. For waist-high tykes like Andrew Wang, 5 and fizzy, New York now offers something better: the personal artist, rentable by the hour as babysitter.

title: Deal Lawyer Joins Willkie
description: For decades, attorney Kirk A. Radke has worked behind the scenes helping to arrange private equity deals. Now the noted corporate lawyer is pulling off a deal for himself with a move to law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher after a long tenure at Kirkland & Ellis, another large law firm.

description: Photos from the Central African Republic, Israel, Thailand and New York.

title: Mandelas Death Leaves South Africa Without Its Moral Center
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela, South Africas first black president and an enduring icon of the struggle against racial oppression, died on Thursday, the government announced, leaving the nation without its moral center at a time of growing dissatisfaction with the countrys leaders.

title: Bulls Derrick Rose Vows Injury Wont Change Him
description: CHICAGO  Derrick Rose, the Chicago Bulls point guard, hobbled on crutches into a room in the basement of the United Center on Thursday morning to meet the news media for the first time since he had surgery last week to repair a meniscus tear in his right knee. He wore a red hooded sweatshirt with his trademark logo, a design with the letter D inside a rose.

title: Mandelas Struggle in Posters
description: Nelson Mandela spent 27 years in prison before his release in February 1990. During that time, a global anti-apartheid campaign took off, and his international influence grew exponentially.

description: Nelson Mandela, the leading emancipator of South Africa and its first black president, died on Thursday.

title: A Poet Who Pushed (and Recycled) the Envelope
description: Like many a Connecticut Valley puritan, Emily Dickinson was practical, inventive and private. Dismissing the commercial marketing of poetry as an auction of the mind, she pioneered a very personal version of desktop publishing, creating 40 handwritten, stitch-bound volumes of her own poetry, each in an edition of one.

title: Funny Lady
description: There was a time when Nora Ephron was frequently compared to Dorothy Parker, even by Nora Ephron. (All I wanted in this world was to come to New York and be Dorothy Parker. The funny lady. The only lady at the table. The woman who made her living by her wit.) I believe we have all gotten over that. As Ephron herself figured out long ago, the idea of Dorothy Parker was far superior to the living version, who was good with a one-liner but not much fun to be around. The real Nora Ephron was the person everybody wanted to hang out with, in part because she was funny and charming but more critically because she made the people she was with feel funny and charming. (I certainly wanted to hang around her, and we were friends for years.) She was never the life of the party in the classic center-of-the-crowd sense. She was the one who listened and then finally tossed in the one fabulous line that brought everything together. Her best writing was exactly the same.

title: Vanities
description: I feel deeply underqualified to review the two coffee-table behemoths that landed on my desk: Vanity Fair 100 Years and 85 Years of the Oscar.

title: A Season of Scrooges (and a SQuja)
description: A look at 61 actors from holiday productions of A Christmas Carol across the country, including a Klingon and one in drag.

title: Shell Opts Not to Build Plant on Gulf Coast, Citing Costs
description: Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it would not build an immense gas-to-liquids plant on the Gulf Coast because of concerns over its cost. Shell had been studying the possibility of building a plant to take advantage of cheap shale gas in the United States for at least two years.

title: The Life and Legacy of Nelson Mandela: 1918-2013
description: Nelson Mandela, whose activism made him a central figure in ending apartheid in South Africa, went from a prisoner to president in his lifetime.

title: Just a Sweet Pair of Sociopaths
description: Among the inventions of the new Bonnie & Clyde  a four-hour extravaganza on Sunday and Monday nights, shown simultaneously by A&E, History and Lifetime  one of the less fortunate is a voice-over narration for the young killer Clyde Barrow. At turning points in the story, Barrow muses about fate, love and the reasons for the deadly two-year crime spree he carried out with Bonnie Parker and other associates in the early 1930s.

title: Mandela Taught a Continent to Forgive
description: ACCRA, Ghana  FOR years, it seemed as though only one photograph of Nelson Mandela existed. It showed him with bushy hair, plump cheeks, and a look of serious determination. But it was a black-and-white shot, so grainy it looked ancient  a visual documentation of an era and an individual whose time had long passed.

title: Nelson Mandela, South Africas Liberator as Prisoner and President, Dies at 95
description: Nelson Mandela, who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and served as his countrys first black president, becoming an international emblem of dignity and forbearance, died Thursday night. He was 95.

title: Conservatives and Structural Racism
description: Responding to some of the discussion(my own contribution perhaps included)around Jonathan Chaits controversials thoughtson conservatives and 12 Years a Slave, The Daily Beasts Jamelle Bouie tweeted: Empathy about racial issues is nice, but actual policy to ameliorate effects of structural racism would be better, and Im not sure conservatism is equipped to do that. I would be happy to be wrong though.

title: The Making Of
description: The designer opened up his New York studio on the eve of his prefall presentation to share his personal inspirations and how it all came together.

title: The Contradictions of Mandela
description: I REMEMBER Nelson Mandela. No, not the universally adored elder statesman who successfully resisted the megalomania that comes with deification, and who died Thursday at age 95, but the young lawyer who used to sit in my parents living room until the early hours of the morning, debating African nationalism with my father, Ashby Peter Mda.

title: The Voice of Mandela
description: Major speeches and letters from the life and career of South Africas first black president, organized by date, topic and readers favorites.

title: In Reversal, White House Says Obama Did Meet Uncle
description: WASHINGTON  White House officials on Thursday abruptly changed their story about whether President Obama had ever met his fathers half brother, a Boston man who faced deportation to Kenya after a drunken-driving arrest in 2011.

title: Champagnes That Leave the Sweetness Behind
description: As with clothing and hair, wine knuckles under to fashion. Different styles, regions and grapes all have their moments in the marketing spotlight, although the rationales for these sudden blasts of commercial heat can vary wildly.

title: Fragonard Portrait Draws $28 Million at London Auction for Unicef
description: Unicef of Germany on Thursday auctioned off part of what had been one of Europes largest private art collections, reaping $31 million for the charity, much of it from the sale of a Fragonard portrait of a French general that drew nearly $28 million in bidding at Bonhams in London.

title: Updates: First Reactions to the Death of Nelson Mandela
description: The Lede is following global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela on Thursday. The New York Times obituary, From Rebel to Prisoner to President, was written by Bill Keller, the former executive editor who covered the end of apartheid as Johannesburg bureau chief from April 1992 until May 1995.

title: Venetian Glass by Carlo Scarpa
description: A look at a new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Clear, Opaque and Oh, So Delizioso
description: Craft. Decorative. Functional. Well made. Words like these are often used to keep objects in their place, carefully segregated from the realm of art.

title: Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthrough
description: A look at works from an exhibition at Scandinavia House.

title: Desire and Prudery, Wrestling to a Draw
description: In the movie Babettes Feast, a Frenchwoman comes to a remote Danish fishing village seeking political asylum after losing her husband and son in the Paris Commune of 1871.  The local residents are puritanical Protestants; Babette is a Roman Catholic sensualist. She wins over her gloomy hosts by staging a lavish multicourse dinner that awakens them to their own bodily appetites.

title: Memories of Mandela: John F. Burns
description: John F. Burns was Johannesburg bureau chief from 1976 to 1980.

title: A Day of Adulation and Hope
description: It was late afternoon on one of the sky-blue summer days common in the verdant landscape of South Africas Western Cape, during a return visit nearly a quarter of a century ago, that I first glimpsed Nelson Mandela as a free man, walking to his destiny through the gates of Victor Verster Prison after 27 years as the worlds most celebrated political prisoner.

title: Warring Emotions Play Out in a Universe Torn by Conflict
description: As an actor, Sergio Castellitto, a brooding and playful screen presence, especially in films directed by Jacques Rivette, is capable of impressive subtlety. As a director, though  notably of Dont Move (2005) and now Twice Born, both starring Penlope Cruz  he seems to go out of his way to discourage precisely that quality. A throbbing melodrama set partly during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s (and based on a novel by Margaret Mazzantini, Mr. Castellittos wife), Twice Born generously allows each member of its talented, cosmopolitan cast an opportunity to howl and scream and tremble and generally overdo it.

title: Memories of Mandela: Alan Cowell
description: Alan Cowell was Johannesburg bureau chief from 1983 to 1987.

title: A Hero, Everywhere and Nowhere
description: From the moment of my arrival in South Africa in late 1983 to my enforced departure at the insistence of the apartheid government in early 1987, Nelson Mandela was everywhere and nowhere: a name on protesters lips, but unseen and unheard, a potent refrain in the clamor for liberation, a hidden presence in a remote prison cell, the anchor on a dream of freedom.

title: Memories of Mandela: Suzanne Daley
description: Suzanne Daley was the Johannesburg bureau chief from 1995 to 1999.

title: Statesman, Dandy, Flirt
description: As president, Nelson Mandela had so many requests for interviews that he frequently met with journalists in groups of three or four  often at 7 a.m. too, because he got up early. He never allotted much time for questions, sometimes just half an hour, and his temper flared easily, so watch out. In many ways, he was more a chief statesman than the head of a government. He didnt like defending  or talking about  policy. And he had no patience for critics.

title: Lodgings That Will Light Your Stay
description: Hotels around the world are getting into the festive spirit of the season by paying extra attention to their Christmas trees.

title: Three Neighbor Problems
description: Evict Thy Neighbor?

title: Memories of Mandela: Donald G. McNeil
description: Donald G. McNeil Jr. was a Johannesburg correspondent from 1995 to 1999.

title: (Almost) Meeting Mandela
description: I never interviewed Nelson Mandela, but toward the end of my time in Johannesburg, he spoke at the annual dinner of the Foreign Correspondents Association. At the end, everyone got in line to shake his hand as he exited. Normally, I dont buddy up to important people  I think its compromising. But this time I was telling myself off: Oh, for Christs sake, Donald, stop being such a prig. Its Madiba, hes a living saint, and hes 80 years old. Hes not going to be around much longer. Get in line and shake his hand.

title: Memories of Mandela: Ian Fisher
description: Ian Fisher was Nairobi bureau chief from 1998 to 2001.

title: The Making Of | A Wardrobe Fitting for Joseph Altuzarras Fictional Leading Lady
description: On Monday, Joseph Altuzarra was hard at work in his New York studio, putting the finishing touches on the prefall 2014 looks he began designing in September, right after his spring/summer 2014 runway. For this fifth anniversary collection, which hits stores in May 2014, the newly engaged designer is looking back to move forward. In the past couple of years we were really developing the brand around this kind of woman, says Altuzarra about his imaginary muse, who balances French sensuality with effortless American style. I think it is a powerful thing to look at a show and have it superdesirable and have it superwearable. To achieve that balance this time around, his nearly 80 designs are fraught with layers of contrast. Body-hugging sheath dresses are understatedly sexy thanks to preppy madras fabric. Innocent, collegiate-striped skirts have dangerously high slits, an Altuzarra signature. The resurfacing of his other popular standbys  cropped peacoats, oxford shirt dresses, simple knits and soft, draped cocktail dresses  round out the collection so that it essentially becomes a complete wardrobe for the Altuzarra woman. Here, a look at just who that is, along with a behind-the-scenes look at how it all come together.

title: The Downside to F.H.A. Loans
description: Mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration are the go-to product for borrowers who dont have much cash for a down payment. But the required mortgage insurance premiums have become so costly that some critics argue that the agency is taking advantage of borrowers who have few other options.

title: The Power of a Man Speaking Truth
description: I will give away the story of my only encounter with Nelson Mandela by saying my wife was just pregnant at the time with our second child. We saddled this small creature with the very big name of Nelson, and here is why:

description: The Willows, in the DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel in Bristol, has the antiseptic look of an airport lounge, with cookie-cutter industrial art and vinyl-surfaced furniture, but there is nothing institutional about its food.

title: Bubbles Make Rillettes Even Better
description: I have always believed that slices of prosciutto rimmed with creamy fat are best eaten with a bone-dry sparkling wine. And if the sparkler is Champagne, so much the better.

title: Memories of Mandela: Lydia Polgreen
description: Lydia Polgreen has been the Johannesburg bureau chief since 2012.

title: A Racial Acceptance That Resonates
description: In 1980, when I was 4 years old, my family moved to Kenya for my fathers job as a development consultant. My mother is from Ethiopia, and my father is a white American, but in the swirl of expat life in Nairobi, there was nothing unusual about that. My elementary school classes were full of kids who were half Kenyan, half British; half Chinese, half Rwandan; half Indian, half Filipino.

title: Not Breaking Ties: Retaining Rockwell Family Heirlooms
description: Although all eyes were on three of Norman Rockwells best-loved paintings, which brought a total of $57.8 million at Sothebys on Wednesday morning, two smaller works by the artist were snapped back up by William Stuart, one of the brothers who had inherited them from their father, Kenneth J. Stuart, Sr., the Saturday Evening Posts longtime art director. The elder Mr. Stuart died in 1993.

title: Nelson Mandela
description: Nelson Mandela, who died on Thursday at age 95, fully deserved the legendary stature he enjoyed around the world for the last quarter-century of his life.

title: Clinging to a Frail Presence, a Living Symbol
description: By the time I arrived in South Africa in 2008, a frail and declining Nelson Mandela was rarely seen in public anymore, and yet his presence was everywhere, his name on every set of lips and his face never far from any minds eye.

title: On the 42nd Floor, a Menu Worthy of the Views
description: When 42 opened six years ago, jackets were required and guests were treated to complex molecular gastronomy designed to dazzle and even shock, like a vinegar turned into powder and served on a mirror with octopus. Tweaks came after the financial crisis (jackets were no longer necessary, and a $79 prix fixe menu was offered), but the restaurant remained, in the words of its celebrated chef-owner, Anthony Goncalves, a special-occasion place.

title: A Maniac Fights to Prove Murder by the Police

title: For a Village Troubadour, a Late Encore
description: He was the big fish in the small pond that was the Greenwich Village folk music scene circa 1960, sought out and emulated by newcomers like Bob Dylan and Tom Paxton. But by the time his memoir, The Mayor of Macdougal Street, was published posthumously in 2005, Dave Van Ronk had been relegated almost to a footnote in the history of American popular music, better known for the many singer-songwriters whose careers he had fostered than for his own work.

title: Mandela Lives
description: My favorite fact about Nelson Mandela is that he invited one of his white jailers, who had helped imprison him for 27 years, to his inauguration as South Africas president. It was a sign of the magnanimity, warmth and absolute lack of vindictiveness that marked Mandela.

The feature film debut of the Irish director Ruairi Robinson, it was adapted by Clive Dawson from Sydney J. Boundss short story The Animators.

title: A Warrior Learns a Different Pose
description: Its important to understand that my husband, Peter, refuses to take baths. He does shower, yes, but he finds baths unmanly, just like soccer  or any other sport that does not require players to crash into one another like angry apes and beat their chests.

description: Early in Night Train to Lisbon, Raimund Gregorius (Jeremy Irons), a stuffy academic, remarks that his wife left him because she found him boring. Oh how right she was!

title: The New Girl, in Proverbial Pursuit of Popularity
description: The teenage mating game, as portrayed in the smart, chilly S#x Acts, is a perilous sport, and woe to the girl who doesnt abide by its tricky rules. The films protagonist, Gili (Sivan Levy), is a wide-eyed, flirtatious high school student whose family recently moved to an upscale neighborhood in Tel Aviv, which could stand for any affluent city where bored, sexed-up youths communicate via smartphone. Acutely aware of her outsider status, Gili, whose family is not wealthy, has her dates drop her off at a luxury apartment building across the street from her actual address. She seems to have unlimited freedom to come and go as she pleases.

title: Wastewater Case Raises the Concept of Underground Trespassing
description: A case involving the disposal of industrial wastewater pits two interests that are dear to many Texans against each other: oil and gas resources versus private property rights.

title: Good Samaritan Ensnared in a Web With No Exit
description: Swerve, a would-be thriller set in the Australian outback, throws a handful of familiar genre bits at the screen, including a very bad man, a menacing husband, a wily wife, a rootless stranger and a chunk of change. Certainly theres promise in the setting, which with its swaths of desert and roads to nowhere evokes the violent sun-scorched world of Red Rock West, John Dahls 1993 cowboy noir about a chunk of change, a rootless stranger, a wily wife, a menacing husband and a very bad man. Yet to say that the films have similar parts is about as meaningful as pointing out that a 1970 Pontiac G.T.O. and a 1971 Ford Pinto both have internal combustion engines, when only one is worth the ride.

title: President Jacob Zuma on Mandela
description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave the news Thursday night that former President Nelson Mandela had died, calling him their nations greatest son.

title: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Attacks Convoy in the North

The convoy, which was attacked in the town of Boosaaso in the semiautonomous region of Puntland, included members of the Puntland Marine Forces and two foreigners who were training the local security forces. Details about the casualties were not immediately available, and no group claimed responsibility after the explosion. President Hassan Sheik Mohamud of Somalia condemned the attack, saying that terrorists have lost the war on the battlefield and are now devoting all their efforts in harming innocent civilians. The Shabab rebel movement has been waging an insurgency for years to impose a strict interpretation of Islamic law in Somalia, but Puntland has been relatively peaceful compared with other parts of the country.
