Now, after an unhappy interlude in which he made a Hollywood action film called The Courier, Mr. Abu-Assad is back in the thick of awards season with Omar, which looks again at the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but from a different angle.

title: Yuval Adler on Bethlehem and Heidegger
description: Updated, 4:54 p.m. | Before beginning a career in film, Yuval Adler, the director of Bethlehem, Israels submission for the foreign-language Oscar, worked in a lot of different fields. After earning a degree in mathematics in Tel Aviv, he was a numbers cruncher in New York for some guy who was doing hedge fund stuff, while simultaneously trying to develop himself as an artist, living in a studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He also earned a Ph.D in philosophy from Columbia University, writing his dissertation on finger-pointing as an example of a linguistic phenomenon called indexicality.

title: Lighting Up the Night
description: In the interval between Hanukkah and Christmas, as we head toward the winter solstice, light  fromthe sun,streetlamps, orcandles  seems more precious than ever. In his new picture book, Dusk, the Warsaw-born author and illustrator Uri Shulevitz follows a little boy and his grandfather on their afternoon walk through the streets of New York, following the shifting lights of the short day as they go.

title: 7 Reasons Not to Buy Your Child an iPad for Christmas
description: When it comes to Christmas, Im a sucker for the wow gift (and if anyone has any ideas for my 8-year-old daughter, let me know). I want to surprise and delight as much as anyone (and as an interfaith family, we alternate doing the big gifts for Hanukkah or for Christmas  the timing means its Christmas this year). But theres one big gift I wont go for: the tablet computer in any form, and that includes the game-and-video playing Kindle Fire.

title: F.D.A. Restricts Antibiotics Use for Livestock
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday put in place a major new policy to phase out the indiscriminate use of antibiotics in cows, pigs and chickens raised for meat, a practice that experts say has endangered human health by fueling the growing epidemic of antibiotic resistance.

title: Louisiana Locksmith Supports Auto Library, Wins a Ferrari
description: If youre going to keep a racing library and archives going, the best way to raise money is probably going to have something to do with cars. That is why it isnt surprising that the International Motor Racing Research Center in Watkins Glen, N.Y., raffles off a classic car every year to raise money.

title: Pilots in Crash Were Confused About Control Systems, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON  The pilots of the Asiana jumbo jet that crashed in San Francisco on July 6 were deeply confused about the planes automated control systems, and that is a common problem among airline pilots, according to experts who testified Wednesday in a National Transportation Safety Board hearing on the crash.

title: Googles Road Map to Global Domination
description: Fifty-five miles and three days down the Colorado River from the put-in at Lees Ferry, near the Utah-Arizona border, the two rafts in our little flotilla suddenly encountered a storm. It sneaked up from behind, preceded by only a cool breeze. With the canyon walls squeezing the sky to a ribbon of blue, we didnt see the thunderhead until it was nearly on top of us.

title: Times Minute | Fragile Calm in Kiev
description: Also on the Minute, the Syrian refugee crisis causes housing problems in Lebanon and exercising may be more potent than medicine.

title: Image of the Day: December 11
Times Minute | Fragile Calm in Kiev
description: In the Video

title: Whats That Noise? Well, Think Again
description: A scrappy troupe of polymorphic performers are coming to town this week to ask New Yorkers to see with their ears. Or is it to hear with their eyes? Either way, Squonk Opera, a multimedia troupe of infinite jest with an imagination to match, is determined to blur the lines of our sensory responses to music with its Mayhem and Majesty, which openson Dec. 18 at 59E59 Theaters.

title: Cracks in Air Travel May Widen
description: Two new studies have found that rough days may be ahead for air travel congestion.

title: Classical Playlist: Anne-Sophie Mutter, Christian Tetzlaff, Richard Egarr and More
description: DVORAKAnne-Sophie Mutter, violin, with Berlin Philharmonic, Manfred Honeck, conductor(Deutsche Grammophon)With a sound like molten chocolate and a romantic temperament to match, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is in her element here in a glowing recording of works by Dvorak including the darkly heroic Violin Concerto and the gorgeous Romance in F minor. The Berlin Philharmonic under Manfred Honeck tempers the sweetness with playing that is rich, intense, but also edgy where needed. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

title: Congress Needs to Extend Unemployment Insurance
description: There is a lot to say about the Congressional budget deal, and we do that later on the editorial page. For now I wanted to dwell on the outrageous failure of Congress to extend federal long-term unemployment benefits.

title: Dropping Health Plans, to Pick Better Coverage
description: For nearly 20 years, Keith Perkins offered health insurance to employees of his small electrical contracting company in Greencastle, Pa., and footed most of the bill. This year, with the arrival of the Affordable Care Acts insurance marketplace, he decided to stop.

title: Selfie of Obama Was Misinterpreted, Photographer Says
description: This is an era when one honest image can ignite viral misinterpretation. So an Agence France-Presse photographer, Roberto Schmidt, has provided invaluable context for his photograph of a grinning President Obama joining two prime ministers in taking a snapshot of themselves at Nelson Mandelas memorial ceremony.

title: Have You Considered Dropping Your Companys Health Coverage?
description: In an article weve just published, Stacy Cowley writes about small-business owners who are choosing to stop offering health coverage not just because it removes an administrative burden but because many of their employees come out ahead.

title: Kidd, Woodson and the Game of Survival
description: It is no great revelation to say that many coaches in professional sports come upon their jobs primarily because their predecessors were blamed for someone elses failures or foibles.

title: No Farm Bill in Sight as Recess Looms for Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Prospects for passage of a new farm bill before the end of the year appear dim, with just a week left before Congress adjourns for the holidays, although lawmakers insisted they were close to a deal.

title: A Social Diary of This Years Miami Art Fairs
description: Lets be honest about the art fairs that concluded on Sunday in Miami. They were about one thing: money  the making of it, by selling art, and the spending of it, on having a decadently good time. And the art sold well. Very well. Dealers at the two biggest fairs, Art Basel in Miami Beach, at the Miami Beach Convention Center, and NADA (the New Art Dealers Alliance), at the Deauville Beach Resort in North Beach, boasted that despite predictions of Basel burnout, plenty of collectors attended and sales were stronger than in recent years. So rest assured that these tropical rituals of end-of-year excess will continue for the foreseeable future.

title: Today in Small Business: Who Wants to Be a Teen Millionaire?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Moncler Prices I.P.O. at Top of Range
description: LONDON  Moncler, the Italian designer of luxury winter jackets, is set to raise $938.8 million in its initial public offering, which was priced at the top end of the range late on Wednesday.

title: 20 Recipes for Cookies and Bars
description: Everyone loves a good cookie (or a chewy brownie, or a stick of biscotti). Here are recipes to keep your sweet tooth satisfied through the holidays.

title: Capitals Ovechkin Scores Four Goals and Celebrates in Style
description: Alex Ovechkin of the Washington Capitals has been such a productive goal scorer in his eight N.H.L. seasons that it takes something truly special to make his goals noteworthy these days. The fact that he is leading the league in goals with 26 after 29 games? Yawn. That he became the Capitals career leader for power play goals? Insert crickets chirping.

title: This Guys in Love With Your Songs
description: Burt Bacharachs canon of effervescent pop classics belongs to the world, no question; a guy who could turn out hits for artists encompassing Perry Como and El DeBarge clearly has no trouble writing for a wide audience. But for generations of pop-music obsessives and fellow musicians, Mr. Bacharachs distinctive compositional sophistication  those uneven time signatures, the rich jazz chords  has made him a folk hero.

title: Denmark, Where Joy Is Always in Season
description: There appears to be nothing rotten in the state of Denmark these days. For the second straight year, Denmark has been named the happiest country, according to a survey of 156 nations called the World Happiness Report.

title: Cuisine and Crowds Along a Stretch of Singapore
description: Named for its storied past as the home of exclusive clubs for Chinese businessmen in the 1800s and early 1900s, the stretch of Club Street that extends to Ann Siang Road, on the fringe of Singapores Chinatown, is making a comeback. With trendy new restaurants and bars and attractive boutiques sprouting up in the historically preserved shop houses lining a winding slope, crowds are thronging to the area. On weekend nights, the enclave is conveniently off limits to cars.

title: A Popular Noncandidate Keeps His Options Open and the Voters Guessing
description: LONDONDERRY, N.H.  The trademark pickup truck rolled up to the Harold Square restaurant here one rainy night last week and out popped Scott P. Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts. He had been a senator for only three years, but that was long enough to whet his appetite for more.

title: Obamacares Many Possible Futures
description: The latest data on Obamacare signups is yet another rorschach test for the laws supporters and skeptics: The accelerating rate of signups is either evidence that enrollment might yet achieve escape velocity or an indicator (given how low, in absolute numbers, private enrollment remains) that even with a smoother website experience the program is never going to reach its multiple millions of private enrollees goal. Ive been writing lately about the latter possibility, and sketching scenarios where low enrollment leads to adverse selection and makes the entire mandate-regulate-subsidize setup unsustainable. But the new numbers provide a good opportunity to note that unsustainability is a shorthand phrase that obscures as much as it reveals, and there are many, many likely outcomes for Obamacare that fall somewhere between meets its supporters expectations and collapses under its own weight.

title: Soothing Words on Too Big to Fail, but With Little Meaning
description: This summer, President Obamas new Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, offered a financial reform litmus test: By the end of 2013, could we say with a straight face that we have solved the too big to fail problem?

title: A Literary Look Back at 2013
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, all 10 columnists look back at 2013 and answer: What was the most interesting literary development  welcome or lamentable  of the year?

title: Acrostic
description: Acrostic puzzle for December 15, 2013

title: A Happy Hour for Private Equity
description: Oriental Brewery may produce a happy hour for its private equity investors.

title: Acrostic Answer
description: Acrostic answer for December 15, 2013

title: Escape From the Pink Shag Rug
description: Back in 2008, Beth Antonelli  then Beth Freedman  bought a one-bedroom in Carroll Gardens. I thought it was the practical thing to do, she said. Her co-op cost $337,000, with monthly maintenance in the $500s.

title: U.S. Suspends Nonlethal Aid to Syria Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  Just a month before a peace conference that will seek an end to the grinding civil war in Syria, the Obama administrations decision to suspend the delivery of nonlethal aid to the moderate opposition demonstrated again the frustrations of trying to cultivate a viable alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Just the Facts, but Which Ones Are Included in Times Articles?
description: Now that we know the person of the year (at least according to Time magazine), I have a nomination for the understatement of the year. Its this: New York Times readers examine the paper closely.

title: Two Hirst Dot Works Are Stolen in London
description: LONDON  Two signed prints by Damien Hirst were stolen early Monday from a west London art gallery, the police said Wednesday. The two prints, part of Mr. Hirsts series of multicolored dot artworks, were estimated by the manager of the Exhibitionist Gallery to be worth about $54,000. The larger of the two, Pyronin Y, measures 40 inches by 46 inches and was produced in 2005; the smaller one, Oleoylsarcosine, is 26 inches by 35 inches and dates from 2008.

title: Carven: SoHo, by Way of the Gare du Nord
description: In the short four and a half years since Guillaume Henry set out to revive the venerable house of Carven, he has given the label a youthful new look, with the kind of flirty and flattering designs a cool young French girl would want to wear. There are 16 stores worldwide, including, now, its first in the United States, just opened in SoHo. For the new store, which was designed in collaboration with the architect Eric Chevalier, Mr. Henry (above right) was after something familiar and approachable, like a train station, perhaps, or an old theater. Along the wall as you enter the shop, theres a long black leather bench made for Carven by the design house Domeau & Prs. The plywood flooring is dyed red, and overhead, a captivating light installation gives the space a cheerful ambience.

title: Police Question Parents in Babys Death
description: New York City police detectives on Wednesday questioned the parents of a 4-month-old boy who died on Tuesday night after he was taken to a Manhattan hospital unconscious and with signs of bruising on his hands, feet and back.

title: Garth Brooks Hits No. 1 With a Walmart-Only Collection
description: Garth Brooks has scored his ninth No. 1 album on the Billboard chart with an eight-disc boxed set available only at Walmart.

title: Are Women Just Choosing Not to Pursue Science Careers?
description: The second editorial in our series about science and math education, which focuses on women and minorities, has sparked an impassioned debate among online commenters about the career choices women, and to a lesser extent minorities, make.

title: Beastie Boys Continue Copyright Battle With Toy Company
description: Despite an earlier effort to broker peace between the Beastie Boys and a San Francisco-area toy company, the legal battle over a viral video that parodied one of the rap groups songs goes on.

title: Judith Regan Returns to Publishing by Joining Phaidon
description: Judith Regan, the publisher who was fired by HarperCollins in 2006, has landed a new job in the book business.

title: An App That Will Never Forget a File
description: Some photos are on your smartphone. Others sit on your home computer. Your digital work documents, favorite web clippings and notes from meetings? Scattered like confetti after New Years Eve.

title: App Smart: Winter Games
description: Apps for iOS and Android let you enjoy winter-themed games, including skiing and snowboarding, from the comfort of the indoors.

title: Skier's Fresh Eyes Enable First Descent
description: In the third episode of Teton Gravity Research's Behind the Line, Angel Collinson impresses veteran athletes by skiing a technical line deep in the Neacola Mountains.

title: Playing in Ice and Snow, Without Ever Venturing Outdoors
description: Yes, its cold outside. And yes, its getting slushy and dark and snowy and wet.

title: Below the Line: Underwater With All Is Lost
description: J. C. Chandors drama All Is Lost is receiving accolades for the stoic, nearly wordless performance of Robert Redford. But the Indian Ocean, where Mr. Redfords character is stranded, gives a pretty strong performance itself. Working with water, particularly underwater, can be a challenge for filmmakers. So while Mr. Chandor used Frank G. DeMarco (Margin Call) as his cinematographer for the scenes outside the water, he hired a specialist in underwater photography for the wetter moments. That man, Peter Zuccarini, is one of the industrys go-to cinematographers for underwater photography.

title: Irans Hardliners, and Ours
description: There are several reasons to applaud  warily, provisionally  the first steps Iran, the United States and other world powers have taken toward a deal to prevent a Persian bomb. One reason for cheer is that the interim agreement has brought together the hard-liners, theirs and ours, in reciprocal dismay. When John Bolton, the most enthusiastic armchair warrior of the George W. Bush brigade, and Mohammad Reza Naqdi, the head of Irans brutal Basij paramilitary, are both unhappy, youve probably done something right.

title: Bitcoin Believers See a Role for Wall Street
description: A venture capitalist, a former regulator, a lawyer and a pair of entrepreneurs  Bitcoin evangelists all  gathered on Tuesday in the private dining room of an upscale Manhattan restaurant to discuss their vision of a world in which the currency plays a role in mainstream finance.

title: A Dancers Workout
description: Robert Fairchild, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, talks about his workout and his role in "The Nutcracker."

title: That Unskewed Feeling
description: It goes without saying that Obamacare had a disastrous rollout. But its not October any more. Enrollment is rising fast, and administration officials  who have every reason not to overpromise after what happened last time  are sounding increasingly confident.

title: The Gun Report: December 11, 2013
description: A year ago today, a gunman opened fire inside the Clackamas Town Center mall in Oregon, killing Cynthia Yuille, 54, and Steve Forsyth, 45, and seriously injuring 15-year-old Kristina Shevchenko. Clad in tactical clothing and a hockey mask, Jacob Tyler Roberts, 22, opened fire with a stolen AR-15 semiautomatic rifle near the food court and killed himself 22 minutes later. His motive is not known. There were between 8,000 and 10,000 shoppers in the mall that day.

title: Sellers in 'Insomnia Is Good for You'
description: A clip from a short film by Peter Sellers that was recently discovered. Video provided by Dimwittie Films.

title: The Workout: Dancing in The Nutcracker
description: Ballet looks elegant and effortless, but it is by far one of the most physically demanding professions. While all ballet dancers require flexibility, strength and stamina, male dancers also need tremendous core strength and stability to safely lift, carry and hold ballerinas in awkward positions.

title: Struggle for Kiev Square Unfolds Live Online
description: Updated, 3:02 p.m. | As my colleagues David Herszenhorn and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, the security forces failed to clear protesters from the citys main square overnight, despite dismantling barricades and shoving against lines of demonstrators for hours in the freezing cold.

title: Man Admits Role in Theft of $7 Million From Charity
description: The owner of a Long Island insurance company who was charged last month with helping a Jewish community leader loot more than $7 million from one of New York Citys most influential social service organizations pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges in the scheme.

title: House Hunting on Antigua
description: Moondance, a three-bedroom home with three guest cottages, is on the market for $3.25 million.

title: House Hunting on ... Antigua
description: A PLANTATION-STYLE HOME WITH GUEST COTTAGES AND SEA VIEWS

title: Sellers in 'Dearth of a Salesman'
description: A clip from a short film by Peter Sellers that was recently discovered. Video provided by Dimwittie Films.

title: In Cuba, Ice Cream and Tolerance in a Rainbow of Varieties
description: Two revolutions clash in Strawberry & Chocolate, Senel Pazs play set in Havana in the early 1980s: the Cuban one and a sexual one. This country belongs to the revolutionaries, says the bullying party-liner Miguel (Andhy Mendez), not to the softies.

title: R.B.S. to Pay $100 Million to Settle Inquiries Into Violations of Sanctions
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland is paying $100 million in fines to New York and federal banking regulators to settle civil investigations into accusations that some of its former employees helped conceal transactions involving customers from Iran, Sudan and other nations subject to international sanctions for about a decade.

title: Acrobatic Verbal Maneuvering
description: The Times Richard Sandomir asked Ray Hudson to describe his famously colorful style of calling soccer games, which he does from thousands of miles away, in a tiny booth in South Florida.

title: Video: Skiers Fresh Eyes Enable First Descent
description: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

title: After Clashes, Police Pull Out of Kiev Square
description: Ukraines authorities halted their crackdown in Independence Square after a night of clashes with protesters who have been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich.

title: Trash Can Yields Two Long-Lost Peter Sellers Films
description: Two 1957 films by Peter Sellers, long thought to be lost, have been found by the building manager of the now-defunct Park Lane Films in London. The master prints of Dearth of a Salesman and Insomnia is Good, were in 21 film cans that the manager, Robert Farrow, salvaged from a trash can outside the building when the studios were cleared before to refurbishment in 1996.

title: A Chef in the Field | Artisanal Cheese (and Crackers to Go With It)
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Whats Going on in San Francisco?
description: Its a city of very rich people and very poor people.

title: A Tasty (and Cheap) Escape to Dutchess County, N.Y.
description: Pure Mountain Olive Oils and Vinegars in Rhinebeck, N.Y., is a lovely place to buy a $17.99 bottle of basil olive oil, should that fit your budget. But its also a lovely place to try some free, as I did on a recent visit, dousing a cube of cheese and grape tomato  a modified caprese salad on a toothpick. Also: a piece of crispy baguette toast or three slathered with asparagus pesto. And dozens more olive oils to sample solo (tasting instructions provided) or with chunks of bread. Was I overindulging? Apparently not.

title: For Fashion Week, Striking Their Lincoln Center Tent
description: On Tuesday afternoon, a relaxed and witty Oscar de la Renta sat among a small group of fashion editors as models in matching black bobs showed 40 pieces from the designers pre-fall collection, a snow-dusted Bryant Park visible from the 25th-floor windows of his showroom.

title: Manchester United Faces Doubter in the Market
description: The English soccer team Manchester United has made a poor showing on the field this season. Now the British hedge fund manager Crispin Odey is making a multimillion-dollar bet that the clubs New York-listed shares are destined for a similar trajectory.

title: Wife Appeals for Release of Journalist Kidnapped in Syria
description: International news organizations, including the BBC, The Associated Press and The New York Times, have written a letter to the armed opposition in Syria asking for assurances that their journalists will not be abducted, as my colleague Ravi Somaiya reported.

title: An Apology to Ronaldinho
description: Ray Hudson recounts one particular outburst that may have gone too far.

title: What You Get For $1,250,000
description: This weeks homes include a farmhouse in Massachusetts, a brick house in Houston and a bungalow near the beach in California.

title: What You Get For... $1,250,000
description: SHEFFIELD, MASS.

title: In the Spirit of the Valley, Its Silicon This and Silicon That
description: The sliver of land in Northern California between salt ponds and the Pacific Ocean has for many come to symbolize all that is prosperous and innovative in the world. Silicon Valley. The land of Google and Intel and Jobs.

title: Vocal Acrobat Mixes Soccer Calls With Awe
description: MEDLEY, Fla.  About 4,400 miles from Spain, Ray Hudson is calling a Real Madrid game the way he always does: off a television screen in a tiny soundproof room in South Florida. Free from distractions, he delivers his analysis in the thick Geordie accent of his native Newcastle, and it is as ludicrous as it is informed, as grandiloquent as it is sharp-eyed.

title: Bitcoin Fever: Using Digital Currency to Understand the Nature of Money
description: Overview | What are bitcoins, and why are people buying them? What makes currency valuable?

title: Video: At a Bronx Fashion Bazaar
description: Lining Fordham Road in the Bronx are shops selling everything from bejeweled cellphone cases to the latest sneakers. Fordham is one of the Bronxs biggest fashion areas, so you see a lot of fashionable people around here, Ann McField said as she was making a run to a fabric store on Fordham Road and Walton Avenue. A lot of Jordans.

title: For Women, Hairstyles at the Barbershop
description: Like many women in New York, Katie Armour, editorial director of the digital magazine Matchbook, is absolutely devoted to her hairdresser. Hes so wonderful, I know all about his family, said Ms. Armour, 27, who travels from her apartment on the Upper East Side to the West Village once a month to get her hair done.

title: Keep an Eye on Children, or Other Valuables
description: I still remember the baby monitor my parents had  my friends and I used it as a primitive walkie-talkie.

title: A 'Fake' Sign Language Interpreter
description: The interpreter used at the memorial for Nelson Mandela was said to be an impostor.

title: Obamas Orwellian Image Control
description: THE Internet has been abuzz over the spectacle of President Obama and the prime ministers of Britain and Denmark snapping a photo of themselves  a selfie, to use the mot du jour  with a smartphone at the memorial service for Nelson Mandela in South Africa on Tuesday.

title: Fantasy Football: Daily League Advice for Week 15 and Beyond
description: Working in the fantasy sports world, one of my long-term goals is to introduce daily fantasy sports (salary-cap-based leagues that redraft every week) to traditional season-long fantasy owners. That is why I just published a book about it.

title: Detroit Symphony Hails Its Healthier Finances
description: The city of Detroit may be in bankruptcy, but the Detroit Symphony Orchestra is back in the black. The symphony planned to disclose on Thursday that it had balanced its budget for the first time since 2007. The orchestra ended the 2013 fiscal year with a small surplus after raising $18.9 million in contributions, a 43 percent increase over the year before. Ticket revenue rose to $6.26 million as the orchestra sold more subscriptions, it said.

title: Hoping to Save the Remains of a Ming Dynasty Temple
description: First a printing press, then real estate developers, now a welding-machine factory. Everyone has taken a piece of Nianhua Si, or Picking Flowers Temple, a Ming dynasty place of worship in the storied Drum Tower district of Beijing.

title: Fewer Psychiatrists Seen Taking Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  Psychiatrists are significantly less likely than doctors in other specialties to accept insurance, researchers say in a new study, complicating the push to increase access to mental health care.

title: Big Change for China and the World
description: During his trip to China last week  a visit important for its timing and the difficult issues it tackled, principally in five hours of talks with President Xi Jinping  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had breakfast with American business leaders.

title: Hilton Prices Its I.P.O. at $20 a Share
description: When Hilton Worldwide went private in a $26 billion deal with the Blackstone Group, it became one of the biggest companies ever to sell itself in a leveraged buyout.

title: American Hustle: These Looks? They Deceive
description: In the new film American Hustle, a fictionalized account of the Abscam scandal at the height of the disco era, the looks are over the top. Dresses are tight, tight, tight. Jewelry is oversize. The men have comb-overs or pompadours or perms.

title: Aide to Senator Is Arrested in Child Pornography Case
description: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officers on Wednesday searched the Washington home of a chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, for child pornography.

title: Sebeliuss Testimony in Two Minutes
description: As Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, testified before Congress, a Republican representative said that speaking to her was like talking to the Republic of Korea.

title: In Store | Pradas Vintage-Inspired Separates for a New Dover Street Market
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Baruch College Student Dies in Fraternity Pledge Ritual in Poconos
description: The game is called the Glass Ceiling, and it is played outside. It involves blindfolding a person and placing a heavy item on his back. He has to navigate to someone who is calling for him, and as he makes his way, others try to tackle him.

title: Beatles by the Volume, Not Shy on the Footnotes
description: On Oct. 12 or Oct. 13, 1961, Paul McCartney and John Lennon visited the Htel de Beaune in Paris, near the Seine, to have their hair cut by a friend. Mark Lewisohn, billed on his book jacket as the worlds only professional Beatles historian, may know more about this seminal pop-cultural event than anyone else on the planet, including Mr. McCartney. The budding Beatle might have been too caught up in the moment to remember its exact details. Mr. Lewisohn has had some 50 years to parse them.

title: Novelties at a Miami Art Basel Exhibition
description: MIAMI BEACH  Pharrell Williamss bulletproof vest might not stop a snowflake. But thats fine with Mr. Williams, who stopped at Art Basel Miami Beach last week to take in the art fairs and hawk a few wares of his own. His channel-quilted vests ($1,495) and mirrored shades ($595), created in collaboration with Moncler, were selling at a good clip at the Colette Art Drive-Thru, a pop-up installation by the influential Parisian retailer and the Alchemist shops on Lincoln Road here.

title: Nick Kristof Answers Your Questions
description: On Monday readers were invited to ask Op-Ed columnist Nick Kristof questions on any topic. Dozens of readers asked Nick about subjects like the freedom of the press in China, President Obamas second term agenda, whether the Middle East will ever have a Mandela-like figure, what he leaves out of his columns and more.

title: Weinsteins Sue Warner Over Proceeds on Hobbit Films
description: LOS ANGELES  Bob and Harvey Weinstein escalated a legal dispute over their claim to a share in the proceeds from the new Hobbit films by Warner Bros. with a lawsuit filed in a New York state court on Tuesday.

title: Soap, Perfume and Cosmetics With Spice Notes
description: When its cold outside, a touch of spice in beauty products can be appealing, without the guilt of visiting the airport Cinnabon.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Africa, Ukraine, Central African Republic and Syria.

title: Shopping for Investments in a Health Savings Account
description: HEALTH savings accounts have been around for a decade and more people are using them, but comparing the features of various accounts can still be challenging. Alternatives range from basic savings accounts offered by credit unions to those allowing investments in mutual funds or even individual stocks.

title: European Copyright Laws Lead to Rare Music Releases
description: Thanks to a provision in the European Unions new copyright law, fans of some musicians who made recordings in the 1960s are likely to be treated, for the foreseeable future, to annual batches of previously unissued material. But because artists and record labels are apparently unhappy about being forced to release material they would rather keep in the vaults, collectors need to be quick and alert: So far, the most tantalizing recordings have turned up in limited, hard-to-find editions. And where labels are normally eager to publicize their releases, they are doing their best to keep these ones secret.

title: Fall North American Championships
description: PHOENIX  On the final day of the Fall North American Championships here on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City, Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

title: Alvin Ailey Dancers at City Center
description: The company reprised works by Paul Taylor, Rennie Harris and Ohad Naharin.

title: Staying Aloft in Different Styles (With or Without Dress Suits)
description: For its second week in residence at City Center, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater reprised the three works that Robert Battle added to the companys repertory when he became artistic director in 2011. Paul Taylors Arden Court, Rennie Harriss Home and Ohad Naharins Minus 16 afford a thorough, generous look at three styles: American modern dance, hip-hop and Gaga, the movement form invented by Mr. Naharin, an Israeli choreographer. How can a performers presence alter the stages canvas? How does subject matter, however veiled, become universal?

title: Military Chief in Iran Scolds a Top Official
description: TEHRAN  The highest commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran lashed out at the countrys foreign minister on Wednesday, telling him to stick to diplomacy and stay out of military business.

title: For No. 2 at Fed, White House Favors Central Banker in the Bernanke Mold
description: WASHINGTON  Stanley Fischer, the former governor of the Bank of Israel and a mentor to the Federal Reserves chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is the leading candidate to become vice chairman of the Fed, according to former and current administration officials.

title: Prison Memoir of a Black Man in the 1850s
description: Years ago, a rare-books dealer browsing at an estate sale in Rochester came across an unusual manuscript, dated 1858. The family selling it said little about where it had been for the last 150 years. It appeared never to have left upstate New York.

description: MIAMI BEACH  Art Basel, I dont go, Roberto Cavalli said the other day. I dont like. The perma-tanned Florentine lifestyle impresario was in town to oversee construction on Cavalli Miami, his soon-to-open restaurant and lounge on Ocean Drive.

title: Serving Up Folky Americana With Holiday Toppings
description: In 2005, the songwriter Sam Beam, who records as Iron and Wine, and the Tucson band Calexico released an EP they recorded together, In the Reins, giving Mr. Beams songs some of Calexicos Southwestern, country-mariachi flavor. Christmastime brings family reunions, and for its annual Holiday Cheer benefit concert, on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, the Americana-loving public radio station WFUV (90.7 FM) brought Iron and Wine and Calexico back together, adding other sometime collaborators and kindred spirits: Kathleen Edwards, Beth Orton, Nick Lowe, Glen Hansard and Amos Lee. Calexico backed them all, jovial and versatile.

Now a Japanese-inspired nightclub called Tokya has joined the fray. Across the street from Lavo and next door to the reality-star hub Tao, this subterranean space may be smaller and more intimate, but it parties just as hard.

title: Mets Are Said to Spend Again, Agreeing to 2-Year Deal With Colon
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  When Matt Harvey, the Mets ace, was lost for the 2014 season to Tommy John surgery, it was generally assumed the Mets season would be lost as well. Sandy Alderson, the teams general manager, spoke about living with certain weaknesses on the roster and about spending wisely, which was interpreted to mean that the Mets would do more to sign free agents this off-season but maybe not a whole lot more.

title: A Continental Feast for the Eyes and the Ears
description: Imagine attending a circus, a dance performance and a world music concert, all in one day. It would be exhausting, not to mention mind-boggling to schedule. But now this feat can be accomplished in a single location in about 100 minutes: Its called Mother Africa.

title: One Best Actor, So Many Possibilities
description: Christian Bale more or less looks like himself in Out of the Furnace, which is something of a feat. As an ex-con mill worker in Scott Coopers working-class drama, Mr. Bale, a performer capable of extreme physical transformation, sports longish hair and a goatee, as he often does off screen. And, on his neck, a tattoo of the ZIP code of Braddock, Pa., where the movie is set.

title: Facebook to Join S.&P. 500
description: Facebook stock jumped close to 4 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday on news that the social media giant would join the Standard & Poors 500-stock index at the end of next week.

title: Major League Baseball Plans to Ban Collisions at Home Plate
description: It is an iconic part of baseball: A player rounds third base, sprints toward home plate and barrels into the catcher at full speed.

title: Hey, Mediocrity, Two Wizards Want You Gone
description: White-faced creatures in silver headpieces hand out beaded necklaces at the door, onyx-hued for those who choose to back the Black Wizard, navy for those cheering on the Blue. Just inside, color-coded cocktails are served in tiny cups: for Blues partisans, a concoction of rum, Blue Curaao and lime juice; for Blacks, bourbon and coffee liqueur. Later, for some, there will be doughnut holes.

title: Video Shows Moment of Impact of Asiana Flight 214
description: In  video of the July 6 crash of Asiana Airlines flight 214 that was newly released Wednesday by the National Transportation Safety Board, the plane can be seen tumbling down the runway and making a dramatic cartwheel after hitting the sea wall at San Francisco International Airport, breaking off the back of the fuselage.

description: BANGKOK  When Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatras former high school teachers learned she had become Thailands first female prime minister, they were concerned.

title: Met Opera Audition Winners, 6 Years After
description: Catching up with the winners of the 2007 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.

description: Bucolic Brooklyn, the borough of beehives, chicken coops, farm-to-table restaurants and rooftop vegetable gardens, is annexing another back-to-nature accouterment: the fire pit.

description: Openings

title: No Tie-Dye Required
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A few weeks ago, Mike North ambled up the steps of his home in the Lower Haight neighborhood here, feeling blissed out. Fresh from a 90-minute yoga class with live music and an instructor who had worn fishnet stockings and high heels, he was looking forward to a quiet, relaxing evening.

title: Europeans Pay Less for Mobile Use, but at a Cost
description: LONDON  Europeans are paying almost two-thirds less for their cellphone contracts than their counterparts in the United States, according to a report to be published Thursday by the British telecommunications regulator.

title: The Appalling Stance of Rand Paul
description: I dont put much past politicians. I stay prepared for the worst. But occasionally someone says something so insensitive that it catches me flat-footed.

title: English Hand Press Used by Designer William Morris Is Sold for $233,000
description: The 122-year-old English hand press that was used by the designer William Morris to produce The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, his ornate masterpiece of decorative printing, has been acquired by the Rochester Institute of Technology for its Cary Graphic Arts Collection.

title: The Mirror of Guantnamo
description: A decision last week by the federal appeals court in Washington, rejecting yet another Guantnamo detainees challenge to his continued confinement, left barely a ripple in the vast, still pond of Guantnamo litigation. Yet its very ordinariness makes the case of Ali v. Obama worth a few minutes consideration as another detention year, the 12th, draws to a close.

title: Development Blitz Provokes a Murmur of Dissent in Monaco
description: MONACO  As protests go, it was tiny: just a handful of people gathering quietly at a condemned building they thought should not be torn down. But in a place where dissent is rare, the demonstration counted as daring, even radical.

title: Paul Ryan Discusses Budget Deal
description: Representative Ryan and Senator Patty Murray agreed on a budget plan that could possibly prevent another government shutdown.

title: Intentional Communities
description: Communes, former politically idealistic (and cheap) ways for hippies to live, are springing up in large San Francisco Bay Area houses colonized by Silicon Valley 20-somethings.

title: Bipartisan Budget Deal Puts Ryan Under Fire From Fellow Conservatives
description: Representative Paul D. Ryans eight terms in Congress have produced much political celebrity and Republican respect but just two laws bearing the Ryan name  a renamed post office and a modified excise tax on arrows like the ones he uses for bow hunting.

title: Canada to Stop Delivering Mail to City Homes Over 5 Years
description: WATERLOO, Ontario  Canadas postal service said Wednesday that it would cease home delivery over the next five years, and substantially increase postal rates.

title: Fashion Logo Parodies, Strictly Tongue in Chic
description: Some people spend hundreds, even thousands of dollars to ensure that designers logos are prominently featured on their handbags, sneakers and jackets. But for $28, a different kind of fashion-insider cachet, knowing and impudent, can be bought. Thats the price of a T-shirt from Reason Clothing, whose apparel uses nearly identical fonts of high-fashion labels to turn Dior into Poor, Fendi into Trendi, or Balmain into Nawman.

title: Charlamagne Tha God: Keeping a Hot Seat Warm
description: Charlamagne Tha God, the shock-jock host of 105.1s morning show, The Breakfast Club, has a penchant for making his guests squirm.

title: The Turf Is Their Runway
description: Cam Newton, 24, the star quarterback of the Carolina Panthers, apparently isnt content with typical statistics like passing yards or completion percentage. Despite his teams recent eight-game win streak (which ended Sunday with a loss to the New Orleans Saints) and a definite shot at the playoffs, Mr. Newton has another form of gridiron expression in mind.

title: Waris Ahluwalia: A Ubiquitous Presence, However Unlikely
description: What better place to debut a jewelry collection by Waris Ahluwalia than the regal Explorers Club on the Upper East Side? With its wood paneling, stained-glass windows and imposing stuffed animals shot by ruling-class rifles, it seemed to be art-directed for someone who might be mistaken for European aristocracy or Indian royalty.

title: JPMorgan Plans to Unveil a Program for Job Skills
description: When Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago received a call earlier this year asking if he would support a new jobs initiative from JPMorgan Chase, he replied with his typical bluntness.

title: Nigella Lawson: Another Chef Lands in the Soup
description: Last week, the celebrity cook Nigella Lawson admitted in a London court that she had used cocaine and marijuana.

title: Autographs of the Formerly Famous
description: Keir Dullea, gone tomorrow, Nol Coward once quipped about the handsome actor, who is probably best known for playing the astronaut in 2001: A Space Odyssey.

title: Mourning Son Killed at 15, and Celebrating His Life
description: The living room of Sharon Cherrys third-floor apartment in Harlem looks out over a playground, yet feels like a shrine. Two walls are adorned with poster-size photographs of a fresh-faced teenage boy, staring straight at the camera; Ms. Cherry wears a T-shirt printed with an image of the same face. My son, she said, tears already starting to stream down her face, George White.

title: As Winter Nears, Chinese Capital Is Blanketed in Green
description: BEIJING  Sooty skies are not the only reliable indicator that winter has finally descended on the Chinese capital. Vendors selling roasted sweet potatoes occupy street corners with their repurposed oil-drum ovens. To ward off the sniffles, Beijing cabdrivers nibble on cloves of raw garlic, making taxi rides especially trying.

title: How to Truly Honor Mandela
description: World leaders, including President Obama, are jostling for the chance to celebrate Nelson Mandela this week, which would surely make Mandela smile. He had a mischievous sense of humor, and he knew better than anybody that the United States and other countries now embracing him had spurned him when he could have actually used the help.

title: Republicans Running in Reverse
description: Lets hear it for women in high places.

title: Former Quarterback Sues League Over Hits to the Head
description: The former star quarterback Craig Morton sued the N.F.L. in Federal District Court in Northern California on Tuesday, accusing the league of deliberately hiding information about the dangerous effects of head hits and concussions.

title: Should Democracies Have Monarchs?
Goodell Says Miami Case May Lead to New Workplace Rules
description: IRVING, Tex.  N.F.L. players should expect rule changes next year regarding behavior in locker rooms and with teammates in the wake of reports of bullying on the Miami Dolphins.

description: Recently I went shopping for candles and ended up spending nearly $900. I know what youre thinking: Outrageous, right? I thought the same thing.

title: Accused of Harming Bees, Bayer Researches a Different Culprit
description: MONHEIM, Germany  Bayer cares about the bees.

title: Pepsi Deal Underscores an Emphasis on Snacks
description: In an unusual deal that goes far beyond the soda wars, PepsiCo is to announce on Thursday that it is unseating Coca-Cola as the beverage supplier to one of the nations hottest restaurant chains, Buffalo Wild Wings.

title: The Play at the Plate: Safer
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Bruce Bochy spent his first career in baseball as a catcher, his second as a manager. He has absorbed the crush of oncoming base runners and felt the sickening despair of witnessing his own catchers injuries in collisions at the plate.

title: Ex-Officer Is Cleared in Hurricane Katrina Shooting
description: NEW ORLEANS  A former New Orleans police officer who was convicted three years ago in the shooting death of a civilian in the days after Hurricane Katrina, but was granted a retrial on appeal, was acquitted Wednesday on all counts.

title: Rivers Returns as Foe, but Not a Hated One
description: BOSTON  Doc Rivers spent nine years in Boston, a stretch that lasted longer than his playing career in Atlanta and any other stint in his life since his childhood on the South Side of Chicago. He presided over a team that lost a franchise-record 18 consecutive games in 2007 and a team that won an N.B.A. championship a year later.

title: Zeus Jones to Open San Francisco Office
description: ZEUS JONES, a consultancy that specializes in tasks for brands like digital, design, social media and content creation, is joining a parade of advertising agencies opening in San Francisco by hiring a well-known senior executive based in the Bay Area.

title: U.S. Colleges Finding Ideals Tested Abroad
description: WELLESLEY, Mass.  Members of the Wellesley College faculty reacted strongly when word spread that Peking University might fire Prof. Xia Yeliang, a critic of the Chinese government. Professor Xia, an economist, had visited Wellesley over the summer after the college signed a partnership agreement with Peking University.

title: Have We Met?
description: LONDON  Imagine entering the boardroom and meeting for the first time each of the companys 15 directors. These are important people in your life; youll be expected to recognize them when you next meet.

title: N.C.A.A. Change Is Coming, Maybe
description: Throughout Wednesday morning, some of the most important people in college sports settled into ballrooms on the seventh floor of the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan. There was talk and talk and more talk, forums and discussions and presentations. There were athletic directors and administrators and N.C.A.A. officials.

title: Montefiore Faces Neighborhood Opposition to Medical Complex in Bronx
description: A new medical center in the Bronx might seem like a welcome addition to a borough of 1.4 million residents facing a growing health crisis from obesity, diabetes, asthma and chronic diseases.

title: Hometown Remembers Madiba the Villager, Well Before Mandela the Icon
description: QUNU, South Africa  Nelson Mandela was on one of his early morning walks here in his rural home village when he spotted an old friend loosening up the soil on his land with a donkey-drawn plow. Mr. Mandela contemplated the sight, and though he was president at the time, he promptly and inexplicably took over.

title: The Toll From Three Deadly Diseases
description: International health agencies at the United Nations have documented enormous gains made over the past decade to curb three devastating diseases: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. Despite this great progress, there is still a big gap between whats been accomplished and what more could be done with sufficient financing.

title: Bargain-Basement Prices at a New York Hospital Prove Too Good to Be True
description: Knee joint replacements at one-tenth the next cheapest price statewide! Baby deliveries below what they cost the hospital! At such discounts, one could imagine New Yorkers trekking three hours from Times Square to a small upstate hospital to fix an aching joint or to give birth, considering that some Americans fly overseas for surgery to escape high costs.

title: Indias Reversal on Gay Rights
description: Indias Supreme Court issued a disgraceful ruling against human rights in reinstating a law that bans gay sex. On Wednesday, the court reversed a landmark 2009 decision by the Delhi High Court that decriminalized sex between consenting adults regardless of their gender.

title: The Minimalist Budget Deal
description: For most of this year, the brutal cuts to federal spending known as the sequester have wreaked havoc on important programs, cutting off hundreds of thousands from Head Start and low-income housing assistance, setting back scientific research and environmental protection, and costing more than a million jobs. Getting rid of the sequester for domestic programs was a high priority for Congressional Democrats, and they achieved much of what they wanted in a budget deal reached on Tuesday that in other important respects was disappointing.

title: Joe Bihari, Who Put Early R&B on Record, Dies at 88
description: Soon after the Bihari brothers started leasing jukeboxes in black neighborhoods of Los Angeles in the early 1940s, they realized they had a problem. While their business had a solid distribution network of stores, bars and restaurants, they could not find enough records to play in their machines.

title: Deal for Bronx Soccer Stadium in Works as Clock Ticks
description: The owners of New Yorks new professional soccer team and the Bloomberg administration are nearing a tentative agreement to build the citys first soccer-only venue: a $350 million, 28,000-seat stadium near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 12, 2013
description: He gave me my freedom. I can wait a little longer.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 11, 2013
A Final Farewell to Mandela
description: Onthatile Mokoena, 20, was born in South Africa with opportunities and freedoms that her parents were not afforded. She joined thousands at the Mandela memorial to give thanks and pay respects.

title: Police Break Up Luxury Car Theft Ring and Arrest 16
description: The car thieves plied their trade with a certain finesse. No windows were broken or doors pried. Rather, they focused on stealing the high-tech keys of prestigious brands like Bentley, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Porsche.

title: Bronx Courts Make Gains in Reducing Case Backlog
description: Judges and prosecutors in the Bronx have reduced a crippling backlog of felony cases by more than half in the last 11 months, but the boroughs courts still lag behind the rest of New York City in dispensing justice, court officials announced on Wednesday.

title: No Longer Robot, Smith Reprograms Outlook
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  David Lee, the Jets quarterbacks coach, spoke during minicamp about efforts by the rookie Geno Smith to learn a new playbook in a new system. This was before Smith was named the starter, when the staff was still evaluating him.

title: Corrections: December 12, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Dare to be Stupid
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I usually begin the blog posts for puzzles like this one by David Steinberg by saying something like No, youre not crazy. And youre not. In fact, if youre not sure what you should be doing with this theme, pull up a seat and join the club. I eventually figured it out, but it was rough going there for a while.

title: Criminal Action Is Expected for JPMorgan in Madoff Case
description: JPMorgan Chase and federal authorities are nearing settlements over the banks ties to Bernard L. Madoff, striking tentative deals that would involve roughly $2 billion in penalties and a rare criminal action. The government will use a sizable portion of the money to compensate Mr. Madoffs victims.

title: An Indispensable Player on Obamas Team Takes His Leave, at Last
description: WASHINGTON  Pete Rouse, President Obamas indispensable man with a low profile and big footprint, is the quirky insider who built the Obama organization, hired nearly everyone from the White House chief of staff on down, plotted strategy and regularly said he was about to leave.

title: New Film, Out of the Furnace, Accused of Stereotyping Ramapough Indians
description: MAHWAH, N.J.  The past week has been unsettling for the Ramapough Mountain Indians, who live on this northern stretch of the Appalachian Mountains that overlooks the Manhattan skyline and wealthy parts of Bergen County. The new movie Out of the Furnace, featuring a star-studded cast that includes Christian Bale and Woody Harrelson, also features numerous negative references to the Ramapoughs. They include a fight-ring subplot.

title: Madoff Trustees 2010 JPMorgan Suit
description: A series of internal JPMorgan emails suggesting that employees had concerns about the banks ties to Bernard L. Madoff. Some of the emails surfaced in a lawsuit filed by the trustee for Mr. Madoffs victims.

title: Slow Progress on Support for Womens Museum
description: WASHINGTON  A House committee hearing on Wednesday to consider a bill that could ultimately lead to the construction of a womens history museum here showed little sign that the initiative was gathering the momentum it needs to end a 10-year struggle for congressional approval.

title: Hagel Lifts Veil on Major Military Center in Qatar
description: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels visit to the advanced air operations center here this week was not just a stop at an important outpost of the United States military. It was also a major step forward for Pentagon transparency.

title: On Sturdier Ankles, Williams Bolsters Nets Offense
description: The sight of Deron Williams zooming around the court Tuesday night sent a jolt through the Nets.

title: Shares in Chinese Bad Bank Surge in Hong Kong Debut
description: HONG KONG  Shares in the state-run bad bank China Cinda Asset Management rose as much as 33 percent on their trading debut in Hong Kong on Thursday after the bank raised around $2.5 billion last week on huge demand for its initial public offering.

title: Giants Focus on Winning What They Can
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  General Manager Jerry Reese used the heady days of training camp in the summer to post a calendar on the Giants bulletin board that counted down the days to Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium on Feb. 2.

title: New Act Proposes National Paid Family Leave Policy
description: For years, the United States has been criticized for its status as an extreme world outlier in its support for families. After Australia passed its parental leave law in 2010, the United States became the only industrialized nation not to offer paid maternity leave. That failing has contributed to the United States being condemned for human rights violations by Human Rights Watch.  The United States also ranked last in breast-feeding support by Save the Children. The case for national paid family leave has been brought up by everyone from feminist academics to Fox News anchors  and me.

title: Rangers, Reeling at Home, Are Now Short-Handed, Too
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Winless three games into a record nine-game homestand, the Rangers can perhaps gain inspiration from familiar faces.

title: Texas Plan to Execute Mexican May Harm U.S. Ties Abroad, Kerry Says
description: HOUSTON  The scheduled execution next month of a Mexican national by the State of Texas threatens to damage relations between the United States and Mexico and complicate the ability of the United States to help Americans detained overseas, Secretary of State John F. Kerry has warned Texas officials.

title: House of Hard Knocks
description: Rescuing an old stone farmhouse in France required a dig through layers of junk and concrete.

title: An Archaeological Rehab
description: For 20 years, the old stone house on the hill stood empty, the forest surrounding it creeping ever closer. The houses elderly owner had died, leaving it to relatives who were in no hurry to sell and had priced it accordingly.

title: A Live-In Love Triangle Ends in a Beating Death
description: There were family outings at the beach, homemade pizza nights, a wintry day spent making a dreadlocked snowman  evidence of a secret life in Queens that seemed happy, if unconventional.

title: Queens Site May Be Added to Superfund List
description: The site of a defunct chemical company in Ridgewood, Queens, that was involved in atom-bomb research will very likely be added to the federal Superfund list, an Environmental Protection Agency official said on Wednesday.

title: Heres Looking Through You, Kid
description: An overnight stay in Philip Johnsons Glass House, where many have peeked but few have slept.

title: Bedtime Under Glass
description: New Canaan, Conn.  The weekend crowds blocking Ponus Ridge Road in December of 1948 were in a holiday mood, The New York Times reported. Hundreds from this conservative old community of early colonial homes turned out to watch workers put the finishing touches on a house few could have predicted would become a modernist classic.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 15 Matchup Breakdown
description: From a fantasy football perspective, fewer N.F.L. teams have been more unpredictable than the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Chargers (6-7) at Broncos (11-2)
description: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

title: Pass the Cassoulet ... And the Memories
description: Stamped with symbols representing life experiences (a mountain, a torn heart and a pizza slice, to name just a few), Grail, a cassoulet dish from the design firm Grain, is intended to inspire mealtime conversation. We used contemporary icons of things you would encounter in the city, traveling or online, but applied them to a more timeless piece, almost like Egyptian hieroglyphs, said James Minola, who founded the Bainbridge Island, Wash., company with his wife, Chelsea. We imagine people sitting around it at a table; maybe one of these icons speaks to you and reminds you of a story to share.

title: Rare Gems from Ettore Sottsass
description: Ettore Sottsass designed furniture, ceramics, dishware, jewelry, fashion boutiques, an apartment for Gianni Agnelli and, perhaps most famously, the red Valentine typewriter for Olivetti. This Austrian-born, Milan-based architect and designer also led a Zelig-like social life, founding the influential Memphis group and becoming friends with a diverse coterie that included Allen Ginsberg, Helmut Newton and Karl Lagerfeld.

title: Stopping by the Woods at Dusk (or Dawn)
description: The wallpaper company Troves latest pattern, called Trace, was inspired by a summer road trip through Yellowstone. There had been a fire, and as we drove through we saw many stages of the forest, in growth but also in death, said Jee Levin, a founder of Trove with Randall Buck. The couple, who were introducing their 7-year-old son, Sebastian, to the park, photographed trees that were rugged and imperfect. Back in New York, they designed what Ms. Levin called our own forest. The result is a romantic image of a silhouetted woods at dusk sitting above its hand-drawn mirror image. Flip the piece and it looks like a forest at dawn. Trace is one of three patterns in Troves winter collection, which will be formally released next month. It is 12 feet high with a 67-inch-wide repeat, and is $16 a square foot. Information: 212-268-2046 or troveline.com.

title: New York City Backs Off Moving Court to TriBeCa
description: After an uproar and a lawsuit by TriBeCa residents, New York City agreed in a settlement to withdraw plans to move a criminal summons court there, the plaintiffs announced Wednesday.

title: Fabrics Put Through the Wringer
description: Since 2000, Mary Bergtold Mulcahy has been designing block-printed organic cottons with Srinivas Pitchuka, a textile artisan in India. Working in a tradition called kalamkari, Mr. Pitchuka bleaches the textiles in the sun, washes them in the river, beats them against stones to make them soft and boils them. Then he prints them with vegetable dyes. Last month, Ms. Mulcahy opened Les Indiennes, a shop in Hudson, N.Y., that sells the fabric as quilts, pillow covers, tablecloths and yardage, along with miscellaneous home accessories. Most of the items cost up to 70 percent less than the same goods sold online or through other retailers. Eighteen-inch-square pillow covers are $25. Painted eggshell ornaments from the Czech Republic are $5 each. Les Indiennes is at 444 Warren Street, Hudson, N.Y. Information: 518-828-2811 or lesindiennes.com.

title: With a Whoosh and a Zoom: Cleaning Tools
description: To some, cleaning house means making a casual tour with the vacuum and taking a few jabs at the toilet with a soapy brush. Not Sabrina Fierman. As vice president of New Yorks Little Elves, a cleaning firm used by many designers and contractors, she takes the job to a level that would satisfy the most obsessive germaphobe.

title: Embracing Miamis Past and Future
description: Allan Shulman, the 51-year-old principal of the architectural firm Shulman & Associates in Miami, first became known for historic preservation. He rescued the 1915 Browns Hotel on lower Ocean Drive, which was built of pine. And he found a way to save much of the Art Deco Lincoln Theater on Lincoln Road, turning it into a stylish glass-walled H & M store. His new, 5,000-square-foot Miami Center for Architecture and Design (known as MCAD) opened last Friday in part of the 1912 main Miami Post Office, on Northeast First Avenue, in Downtown Miami. Over the years, the building had suffered much indignity, including a spell as an Office Depot. Now, as the new headquarters of the American Institute of Architects Miami chapter, it will be a place for free community events as well as professional gatherings. Speaking by phone from his office in the Miami Design District, Mr. Shulman, president of the Miami chapter, offered details about MCAD and opinions on the citys building scene. (The interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9:30 A.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In Woody Allens tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and 60s, a retired and overly psychoanalyzed music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to a lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile, in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and falls into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penlope Cruz) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) in shreds when her neurotic actress friend visits. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect  a ghost? a specter of the younger mans self?  who witnesses the ordeal. One of the most delightful things about To Rome With Love is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The movies limitations, as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights. Complaining, he added, would be as superfluous  though also, perhaps, as inevitable  as psychoanalysis.

Thats good news for anyone who loves the fast-paced restaurants that once epitomized glamour while offering good simple Gallic grub and first-rate people-watching, but in recent years have gained a reputation for mediocrity after many became part of restaurant chains more interested in the bottom line than good cooking.

They scrambled across the rocks and those of us in the audience followed  as much participants in the spectacle as viewers of it. title: Beatles American Albums to Be Released in a Boxed Set
description: As part of it celebration of the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of Beatlemania in America, Capitol Records is resurrecting a project it began in 2004, but quietly dropped before it was completed: the label announced on Thursday that it would release The Beatles: The U.S. Albums, a 13-CD set that includes the American versions of the albums the Beatles released in the 1960s, or at least, those with different track sequences (and, in some cases, different mixes) than the British versions that are now the standard discography. The boxed set is due on Jan. 21.

title: Zenyatta Extends Streak
description: Zenyatta notches her 17th consecutive victory.

title: Mexicos Pride, Oil, May Be Opened to Outsiders
description: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico  Every gas station in Mexico is stamped with the green-and-white logo of the state-owned oil monopoly, the economic lifeblood of the government. Oil Expropriation Day, commemorating the day Mexico seized control of the industry from foreign companies in 1938, is celebrated with speeches and even parades in some towns. An old song, The Oil Worker Hymn, credits oil with saving our fatherland.

title: Opening Day, 1938
description: Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., opened on June 10, 1938.

title: Health Plans Urged to Extend Enrollment
description: WASHINGTON  With many Americans still foiled in their efforts to buy insurance under the new health care law, the Obama administration moved Thursday to give them more time to sign up and pay premiums, and it extended a program for people with cancer, heart disease and other serious illnesses.

title: The Gun Report: December 12, 2013
description: BB guns are often thought of as a coming-of-age diversion, something young boys shoot in the woods. Theyare regulated in the same manner as air guns, which is to say, not much: They are not regulated federally, nor are they regulated by most state and local governments.But some states are beginning to recognize the destruction the weapons can cause.

title: Pincay Sets the Record
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. breaks Bill Shoemakers record for career victories by a jockey at Hollywood Park, and later retires from riding.

title: A Stay-at-Home Dads Dilemma, When the Marriage Ends
description: What happens to a marriage when a woman works and a husband stays home to raise children? On Sunday, The Times reported on how this plays out in the field of finance, where growing numbers of women say they are able to compete at new levels thanks to stay-at-home husbands. Readers from a variety of fields and economic backgrounds responded with an outpouring of experiences: the Connecticut stay-at-home father who tells white lies about his lack of employment (which career is it this week?); the wife who said the role reversal made her marriage more egalitarian and respectful.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: organic milk, nuts and farm animal drugs. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Alfonso Cuarn Gets a Nod But Could Use Another Perk
description: The filmmaker Alfonso Cuarn was boarding a plane in London to visit his family in Italy when he reflected on the nearly five-year effort to make and release Gravity, which received four Golden Globe nominations on Thursday, including best director, drama and actress (Sandra Bullock).

title: President of Middlebury College Says He Will Leave
description: Ronald D. Liebowitz, who has greatly expanded the reach of Middlebury College, will step down in 2015, after 11 years as president, he said Thursday. Under Dr. Liebowitz, Middlebury, a selective small college in rural Vermont, took over the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California, opened new schools overseas and expanded its summer language schools. Dr. Liebowitz said a major remaining concern is enrollment of minority and low-income students, where Middlebury trails most other elite colleges. Middlebury also announced a governance overhaul, giving each trustee broader oversight duties.

title: Its Hard to Summon Sympathy for Big Banks
description: Its no fun to be a banker these days.

title: Kochs Last Residence Is Named a Cultural Landmark
description: Edward I. Koch, some might argue, was a living landmark. Thursday, on what would have been his 89th birthday, his last residence, at 2 Fifth Avenue, was declared a New York cultural landmark.

title: Wall Street Trade Group Names New Leader
description: A financial industry trade group, theSecurities Industry and Financial Markets Association, has namedKenneth E. Bentsen, Jr., its president, as chief executive.

title: A Senior Getty Curator Is Stepping Down
description: Scott Schaefer, who has been senior curator of paintings at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles since 1999 is retiring as of Jan. 21, the institution announced on Thursday.

title: A Body of Work Gives the Mets Hope
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Sandy Aldersons verb of choice, in past off-seasons, has been punt. It said a lot about perception and reality. The Mets almost ignored the free-agent market and traded star players. Quite clearly, they were punting on the next season, no matter how their general manager spun it.

title: Ziggo Still Has Cards to Play in Liberty Global Talks
description: Ziggo has opened the door to Liberty Global, the media company controlled by John Malone. A few weeks after rebuffing an approach, the Dutch cable group has confirmed takeover talks with its larger rival. Any deal would be both big and logical, since Ziggo and a unit of Liberty, UPC, dominate the local market. And Liberty already owns a dominant stake in Ziggo. Now that Ziggo has conceded a willingness to sell to Liberty, the task is to get full value from a weak position.

title: Reports on Central African Republics Humanitarian Needs
description: Journalists and international humanitarian workers who have been extensively covering the conflict in Central African Republic have highlighted the desperate need for aid for the more than half a million people who have been displaced by the fighting.

title: One Way to Handle Smog: Lower the Standards
description: On seven of the first nine days of December, the air quality in Shanghai was so poor that the city warned children and the elderly to stay indoors. Flights and sporting events were canceled and stores sold out of face masks. Photographs of smog obscuring the Shanghai skyline circulated on the Internet. The pollution was even visible from space.

title: Photographer's Journal: Bryan Denton
description: After covering the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in Guiuan, Philippines, freelance photographer Bryon Denton reflects on his experience.

title: Big Hair, Bad Scams, Motormouths
description: Irving Rosenfeld, the con man running the great scam in American Hustle, isnt, his mistress admits, much to look at. He has a belly the size of a beer keg and a torturously complicated comb-over that he arranges with the fastidiousness of a Michelin-starred pastry chef. Appearances are not everything to Irving (Christian Bale), but rather just part of the swindle that is his lifes work, his passion and genius. The confidence game is his honey pot: Its what lines his pockets, lights his fire and cigars, and has transformed the mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), into his equal in theft and dissimulation, making her the Rosalind Russell to his Cary Grant in a romp thats pure Scorsese screwball.

title: Dialysis Takes a Toll
description: Dialysis is difficult for people of any age, but especially for frail older adults with multiple chronic conditions such as diabetes, heart disease and dementia  the patients least likely to have their lives extended significantly by this treatment.

title: Eating With the Apple Family
description: A meal at the family home of the Apples of Rhinebeck, N.Y., guarantees two things: food and conversation. Lots of it. In the four works in Richard Nelsons play cycle, now at the Public Theater, the fictional members of the family gather around the dinner table at the home of Barbara Apple, a schoolteacher, on days that commemorate recent events in American history: election days of 2010 (That Hopey Changey Thing) and 2012 (Sorry); the 10th anniversary of 9/11 (Sweet and Sad) and the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy (Regular Singing).

title: Investment From China May Be Near for Peugeot
description: GENEVA  PSA Peugeot Citron, the ailing French automaker, moved closer to grabbing a financial lifeline on Thursday, saying that it was in negotiations with Dongfeng Motor, a state-owned Chinese company with which it already has a joint venture, that could lead to a potential capital increase.

title: Hedge Fund Inflated Value of Coal Investment and Client Fees, S.E.C. Says
description: GLG Partners, a division of one of the worlds biggest hedge funds, has agreed to pay almost $9 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it overvalued its investment in Sibanthracite, a Siberian coal mining company, and in turn, inflated client fees.

title: Size Is of the Essence
description: Twenty years ago, New Zealand cuisine was what the locals call meat and three veg. But that is a distant ancestor to what is on the plate tonight at the Musket Room on Elizabeth Street: an archipelago of venison in a licorice jus sea, buffeted by roasted fennel, juniper meringues and celery-root pure.

title: Waiting for Ice, and a Winter Breeze
description: The mercury plummeted to below freezing on Thursday, and most people bundled up to avoid the cold. But for a certain branch of sailors, these temperatures are ideal. With the right conditions and a sustained cold snap, rivers and lakes freeze over, providing the perfect surface for ice yachting, a sport in which sailors navigate vessels across the ice.

description: Six finalists have been named for the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has announced. The $100,000 award, named for the German mens wear company that sponsors it, is given every two years to an artist making significant contributions in contemporary art. Besides cash, the winners work receives an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

description: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Department said on Thursday that it would consider banning the use of cellphones for voice calls aboard airplanes, a reaction to public outrage at a Federal Communications Commission proposal to lift a rule that has long forbidden the use of mobile phones during flight.

title: Comfort Food, Expanded
description: The Northend Bistro is a comfortable oasis that beckons from its tucked-in spot in, yes, the north end of Princeton. Bare wooden tables and paper napkins signal a casual experience; metal dining chairs reflect the light from an abundance of windows and from backlit glass panels.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Friday that Jang Song-thaek, the uncle and presumed mentor of its leader, Kim Jong-un, was executed for plotting a military coup.

title: Creative Ideas for the Holiday Gift List
description: Handblown glass bowls whose colors swirl like ribbon candy, whimsical felt fascinators and intricately adorned purses, ceramic cake stands as enticing as the desserts they were designed to hold  these are a few of the myriad offerings at seven gift-themed art exhibitions in galleries from Pelham to Cold Spring. The shows, though unrelated, share a common aim: to inspire visitors, as an announcement for one of them suggests, to celebrate the season of giving with the gift of anothers creativity.

title: Mandela Memorial Interpreter Speaks in His Own Defense
