description: BANGKOK  In a world now accustomed to democratic upheavals, including the Arab Spring and the Saffron and Orange Revolutions, the weeks of political upheaval in Thailand stand out for one main peculiarity. Protesters massing on the streets here are demanding less democracy, not more.

title: Monday Motorsports: Bernd Schneider Caps an Improbable Season
description: Bernd Schneider, a longtime driver for the Mercedes-Benz factory team, closed out a successful, but unexpected 2013 season with a victory in the Gulf 12 Hours touring car endurance race on Saturday at the Yas Marina Circuit in Abu Dhabi.

title: In N.F.L. Case, Help in Analyzing Deal
description: The judge overseeing the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and more than 6,000 players who sued the league for negligence and fraud has appointed a special master to help analyze the final agreement, which could be filed in days.

title: Breathe In, Breathe Out
description: Biologists have found that savannah monitor lizards extract oxygen from the air when inhaling and when exhaling  a characteristic, known as unidirectional breathing, that is most associated with birds. The discovery of this trait in lizards, reported in the journal Nature, raises questions about when and why it evolved. Either it developed in the 270-million-year-old common ancestor of lizards, birds and alligators (which were also recently found to practice unilateral breathing)  much longer ago than originally thought  or it developed independently in each evolutionary branch. As for why it evolved, the long-held theory that it aided flight in birds appears to need updating.

title: A Study in Forensics, Through a Favorite Sleuth
description: What would Sherlock Holmes make of How Sherlock Changed the World, a Tuesday night special on PBS?

title: Herbalife Shares Jump After Re-Audit of Books
description: Updated, 5:06 p.m. | Another day has brought more bad news for William A. Ackmans bet against Herbalife.

title: Sex and Intimacy After the Baby Arrives
description: Sex after childbirth? In the weeks after a newborns arrival, it may seem as far-fetched as nightclubbing.

title: Animal Humanity
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Climate Change Denial
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Lifelong Fight Against Trans Fats
description: In 1957, a fledgling nutrition scientist at the University of Illinois persuaded a hospital to give him samples of arteries from patients who had died of heart attacks.

title: A Simple Community Health Remedy in Mali
description: Deploying community health workers to treat sick children rapidly can make an enormous difference in how many live and how many die, according to a new study done in Mali.

title: Federal Judges Ruling on N.S.A. Lawsuit
description: A program to systematically keep records of all Americans phone calls most likely violates the Constitution, a judge ruled.

title: President Says a Coup Failed in South Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Soldiers loyal to the former vice president of South Sudan tried to overthrow the government, President Salva Kiir said Monday, continuing the political tension that has hung over the fledgling country for months.

title: Poaching Memories from Googles Wandering Eye
description: In this past weekends issue, Adam Fisher explained Googles ambitious plan to populate its maps with Street View images from all over the world  even the walls of the Grand Canyon, as seen from the rapids of the Colorado River. It called to mind a favorite Tumblr of mine, 9 Eyes, by the Canadian artist Jon Rafman. The blog, named for the nine cameras initially used to capture Street View images (Google has added six cameras since the project began), features enigmatic scenes taken from Rafmans travels throughout this growing virtual universe. What follows is an edited version of our conversation.

title: Egyptians Mock Ads Promoting New Constitution With Typos and Stock Images
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 12:37 p.m. | A campaign to win support for a draft of Egypts new constitution got off to a rocky start on Sunday, one month ahead of a referendum, when observers noticed that a banner promoting the document misspelled the word for Egyptians in Arabic and used stock images of foreigners to stand in for representative citizens.

title: Acura Recalls 7,400 RLX Sedans; N.H.T.S.A. Concludes Viper Investigation
description: Nearly 7,400 Acura RLX sedans from the 2014 model year will be recalled because of a rear suspension problem that can make the vehicle difficult to steer, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: The Read Around: Elizabeth Gilbert
description: In her return to fiction writing with The Signature of All Things, the author Elizabeth Gilbert found that the process can be familiar yet liberating from the constraints of nonfiction.

title: Conservative Wonks, Conservative Politicians, and Recessions
description: Josh Barro has a good but incomplete post about the conservative inability to deal in any meaningful way with the reality of recessions. As he says, GOP policy prescriptions  deregulate, cut spending (especially on the poor), and cut taxes (on the rich)  are the same when unemployment is above 9 percent as when it is below 5. How, he asks, can a political ideology have nothing to say about how to address recessions?

title: How to React to Diminishing Returns
description: The first piece of pumpkin pie is a real treat. The second piece might be good. But we may almost have to force ourselves to eat the third. Instead of enjoying it, were miserable. Why doesnt the last piece taste as good as the first?

title: In Mexico, Len Is on Top
description: The culmination of the Apertura (opening) season Sunday night did not quite rise to the suspense and drama of a Mexican telenovela, but it came pretty close.

title: The Read Around: Video of Elizabeth Gilbert
description: In The Read Around, a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, the author Elizabeth Gilbert, who has returned to fiction writing with The Signature of All Things, talks about how the process can be familiar yet liberating from the constraints of nonfiction.

title: Should We Toss Our Vitamin Pills?
description: One in two adults takes a daily vitamin pill, and Americans spend tens of billions of dollars each year on supplements. Now, a small coterie of physicians writing in a leading medical journal has offered this blunt advice: Stop wasting money.

title: Man Dies in Carjacking at Short Hills Mall; 2 Suspects Are Sought
description: For anyone who has ever felt a twinge of nervousness walking through a parking garage at night, the seemingly random act of violence was chilling: a carjacking at the Mall at Short Hills, a retail mecca for affluent suburbanites in Millburn, N.J.

title: Truths About Grades, and the Coldest Cold on Earth
description: Just in time for finals week, some sobering news about the nature of academic performance. Two new studies from Harvard University showed that early music education classes have no discernible effect on ones cognitive abilities, the Harvard Gazette reported.

title: Health Expenditure Is Really Really Big (A Clarifying Note)
description: OK, for some reason I didnt see that coming. But when I pointed out that insurers are getting ready to lay out around $500 million to promote policies via the Affordable Care Act  which I see as very good news  a fair number of readers were outraged. Insurers are spending all that money on advertising, when they should be spending it on health care!

title: After Hours | John Waters Has Lumps of Coal for All This Christmas
description: The cult filmmaker John Waters is like that lovably abrasive uncle you only see on holidays the one who tells the same offensive jokes year after year, a few of which are still funny enough to earn a belly laugh, or perhaps a wan smile. Thats a bit what A John Waters Christmas felt like Friday night at the very-far-west Stage 48, where the crowd looked like the adult version of the misfit teens who go to The Rocky Horror Picture Show every Friday at midnight.

title: In Performance: Kyle Riabko
description: Kyle Riabko plays his arrangement of Anyone Who Had a Heart, This Guys In Love With You and Alfie from Whats It All About? Bacharach Reimagined, at New York Theater Workshop.

title: Connecticut Schools Production of Rent Is Back On
description: After a petition drive and social media campaign by students at Trumbull High School in Trumbull, Conn., the principal said on Monday that he was reversing himself and allowing its production of the musical Rent to go forward in March as originally planned. The principal, Marc Guarino, said in an interview that he and the student Thespian Society had developed ideas that satisfied his concern that the production be accompanied by an educational component.

title: Should Gifted Students Get More Resources?
description: In a country that has always been a little uncomfortable with the idea of an educational elite, its tough to argue for more services for gifted students in public schools, particularly when so many districts are already starved for resources and high-quality programs. But thats what we did on Sunday in the third installment of our editorial series on fixing math and science education, and the touchy subject produced a particularly fervent response.

title: Volcker Rule Quickly Hits Utah Bank
description: The Volcker Rule was approved just a week ago, but its already forcing some banks to come clean about owning the kind of risky securities that the new regulation is intended to prevent banks from investing in.

title: Ignore the Snow. Its the Motorcycle Show in New York.
description: New models were in abundance when the New York stop of the Progressive International Motorcycle Show circuit opened last week.

title: A Stellar Farro Salad From Charlie Bird
description: Could farro salad be the new couscous salad? You certainly see it often enough on menus and at fancy takeout shops to make the case. But like with its cousin couscous, farro salad can be hit or miss. Sometimes its a deeply flavored, multi-textured delight. Sometimes its dull and bland.

title: The Big Squeeze
description: WASHINGTON  In a recurring comic bit, David Letterman used to place household items  a plate of jelly doughnuts, a six-pack of beer  in an 80-ton hydraulic press, gleefully watching as the items squirted, exploded and disintegrated.

title: No Plot, Just Poetry in a Gauzy Landscape
description: When the German choreographer Pina Bausch died in 2009, a wave of melancholy fell over the New York dance world: even though her company is based in Wuppertal, it was a fixture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Yet her ties to the city ran even deeper, since she had also studied at the Juilliard School.

title: Terrible Twos Who Stay Terrible
description: To understand the violent criminal, says Richard E. Tremblay, imagine a 2-year-old boy doing the things that make the terrible twos terrible  grabbing, kicking, pushing, punching, biting.

title: Bacons Triptych to Be Shown at Portland Art Museum
description: The Portland Art Museum in Oregon announced on Monday afternoon that the worlds most expensive painting ever sold at auction  Francis Bacons triptych Three Studies of Lucian Freud  which brought $142.4 million at Christies in November, will be on view there from Dec. 21 through March 30th.

title: Former Top Goldman Executive to Run Cushman & Wakefield
description: Edward C. Forst, a former co-head of Goldman Sachss investment management division who twice stepped down from top roles at the company, has agreed to join Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate giant, as its president and chief executive.

title: Amid Tortures Of the Flesh, A Nave Crush
description: Hallelujah! Who knew that the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl actually has a heart? You might not have guessed that if all you have seen of his work are his punishing examinations of bourgeois Austrian life, Dog Days (2001) and the first two parts of his Paradise trilogy, released this year.

title: No Finger-Pointing on Metro-North Crash at M.T.A. Meeting
description: Two weeks after a fatal Metro-North Railroad derailment in the Bronx, board members from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday gathered for their first public meeting since the crash, discussing safety features that had been missing from the railroad but refraining from any direct criticism of its leadership.

title: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photos from North Korea, Ukraine, Brazil and the Central African Republic.

title: Saving Kindle Notes Online, and Cleaning an LCD Screen
description: Saving Kindle Notes

title: Shock but No Awe in Homeland Seasons End
description: The hero of Homeland did not cheat death.

title: Buddhists With Issues and Hopes of Nirvana
description: In his unsettling new novel, Bruce Wagner exchanges his usual stomping ground of Hollywood for Big Sur and India, and at first glance this world of Buddhists, gurus and spiritual pilgrims might seem light-years removed from the Los Angeles of depravity, delusion and greed he depicted in his last book, Dead Stars (2012).

title: Times Minute | Watching North Korea
description: Also on the Minute, artifacts from closed churches find new life and discovering the color of pressure.

title: Times Minute | Watching North Korea
Todays Scuttlebot: Lego Stop-Motion of an Old Mac, and Twitters Male-Dominated Flub
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Two Saudi Prisoners Sent Home From Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  Two Saudi men held by the United States without trial for nearly 12 years at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, have been repatriated, the Pentagon said Monday.

title: Leaping In and Out of an Origami World
description: Some music is made for violin and unimaginable for trumpet. Other pieces are best on piano, worst on drums. Some video games are also like this, designed particularly for a particular instrument. An oddity called Tearaway, recently released by the British studio Media Molecule, is one such game. It enjoys the fortune and suffers the misfortune of being perfect for the unorthodox and not very popular hand-held PlayStation Vita.

title: A Struggle to Balance Wind Energy With Wildlife
description: DENVER  As the Obama administration seeks to clear a path for more renewable energy projects, it has increasingly found itself caught between two staunch allies: the wind energy industry and environmental organizations.

title: Artifacts | Its Marina Abramovics World, Willem Dafoes Just Living In It
description: The theater director Robert Wilson is best known for his stunning stage pictures, gorgeous lighting and lengthy evenings. The latest of his productions to hit New York is The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic, a biography of the performance artist that takes its narrator, played to the hilt by Willem Dafoe, a mere two hours and forty minutes to unpack.

title: After 45 Years, as Incendiary as Ever
description: Perhaps White Light/White Heat cant be the surprise it was when it arrived in 1968. The second album by the Velvet Underground, White Light/White Heat has been canonized, analyzed, annotated, emulated and contextualized as a cornerstone of punk and experimental rock. Generations of listeners have been aware of the insistent, relentless drone of its extended songs, the outbursts of scrabbling dissonance and earsplitting distortion from Lou Reeds lead guitar, the equally insistent presence of John Cales electric viola and keyboards, the deadpan tales of drugs and sex and death in Mr. Reeds lyrics and the pithy drive, amid the cacophony, of Sterling Morrisons rhythm guitar and Maureen Tuckers steadfast drums.

title: Flair, Intensity and Drama Circle Back a Quarter-Century Later
description: By her New York recital debut at Carnegie Hall in 1988, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, then 25, had evolved from teenage phenom to mature, adventurous artist. Earlier that year, she had demonstrated her burgeoning interest in contemporary music and her already formidable influence, requesting  and getting  from the eminent composer Witold Lutoslawski a version for violin and orchestra of his 1984 Partita for Violin and Piano.

title: Striking Miners, and Children Who Paid the Price
description: This has been a year of notable 50th anniversaries, but time didnt begin in 1963. A sorrowful PBS documentary on Tuesday night notes the 100th anniversary of an event forgotten by much of the country but not by the people of Michigans Upper Peninsula: a miners strike that led to a catastrophic stampede in which 73 people died, most of them children.

title: Customers Out in the Cold Balk at Uber Surge Pricing
description: On New Years Eve 2011, Uber, a company that connects passengers and drivers of luxury vehicles, had a bit of a falling-out with its customers.

title: A New Preamble Before the Big Show
description: WASHINGTON  Before we explore the problems with the permanent exhibition that opened this month at the National Archives here, it might help to recognize the challenges it faced. The exhibition, Records of Rights, is the first attraction you see after passing through the buildings new marble-clad entrance. It is meant to prepare a million visitors a year for what awaits them above, in the dimly lit Rotunda: original copies of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights  founding documents with such a sacral stature, they are viewed in near silence. What kind of exhibition could possibly serve as preamble?

title: New Era Passer and Old-School Coach
description: While some coaches who have recently moved up from the college ranks have excelled with athletic quarterbacks, Washington's Mike Shanahan has struggled with Robert Griffin III.

title: Video Sports of The Times: New Era Passer and Old-School Coach
Glaxo Says It Will Stop Paying Doctors to Promote Drugs
description: The British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline will no longer pay doctors to promote its products and will stop tying compensation of sales representatives to the number of prescriptions doctors write, its chief executive said Monday, effectively ending two common industry practices that critics have long assailed as troublesome conflicts of interest.

title: Study Links Autism and Somalis in Minneapolis
description: A long-awaited study has confirmed the fears of Somali residents in Minneapolis that their children suffer from higher rates of a disabling form of autism compared with other children there.

title: Dinosaurs and Statistics
description: A new paper highlights possible statistical problems in a series of papers on dinosaur growth rates.

title: A Hobbyist Challenges Papers on Growth of Dinosaurs
description: A dinosaur hobbyist who made his name as a Microsoft multimillionaire published a scientific paper on Monday alleging serious errors and irregularities in dinosaur research involving some of the worlds top paleontologists.

title: Time Is Up for High-Security Wine Cellar Hit by Hurricane, Judge Rules
description: The wealthy clients of a troubled high-security wine storage cellar in West Chelsea will not be getting back their 27,000 cases of valuable wine in time for the holidays.

title: Online Courses: High Hopes, Trimmed
Wellesley in China
K.K.R. to Buy Debt-Trading Affiliate for $2.6 Billion
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it planned to buy a publicly traded credit investment affiliate for about $2.6 billion as it seeks to simplify its corporate structure while expanding its balance sheet.

title: A U.S. Truth Commission
India: Ex-Official Released on Bail
description: Lalu Prasad, a once-powerful political leader from northern India, emerged from jail on Monday after spending more than two months behind bars on corruption charges. Mr. Prasad, a former chief minister of Bihar, was convicted in October of participating in a scheme in which false receipts were used to siphon more than $6 million in public funds from a program meant for animal husbandry. He was sentenced to five years in jail. But the Supreme Court granted him bail on Friday after noting that most of those convicted with Mr. Prasad in the case had already been freed while their appeals were considered. Such appeals often take many years to be decided. When he emerged from jail on Monday, Mr. Prasad pronounced it a fine place for politicians. Jail is the birthplace of Lord Krishna, Mr. Prasad said. I was never unhappy in jail.

title: Benefits Questioned in Tax Breaks for Nonprofit Hospitals
description: The billions of dollars in tax breaks granted to the nations nonprofit hospitals are being challenged by regulators and politicians as cities still reeling from the recession watch cash-rich medical centers expand.

title: When Sorry Means Never Having to Say ...
A Late Note, Improvised
description: To the Editor:

title: What About Bisexual Men?
description: To the Editor:

title: Redevelopment Plan Is Considered for Long Island College Hospital
description: Long Island College Hospital, which became a symbol of New York Citys struggling community hospitals during the mayoral race, is considering an offer to redevelop the property to include condominiums and an urgent care center.

title: Bad Move on Immigration
Russia: 4 Die in North Caucasus Raid
description: Members of Russias security services killed four men suspected of being militants on Monday when they stormed an apartment building after a tense overnight standoff in the North Caucasus region, where Russia is trying to stamp out an insurgency. In a statement, the governments National Antiterrorism Committee said that heavily armed troops supported by armored vehicles surrounded the building in the village of Bedyk in the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria on Sunday evening, acting on a tip that armed men were inside. A woman and a child left the house during the negotiations, but the men refused to surrender, officials said. Troops assaulted the building early Monday morning, killing all four men inside, including the groups leader, Arsen Khandokhov. The Federal Security Service said that Mr. Khandokhov and his group were behind more than 20 terrorist attacks, including the murder of two tourists in the region in 2010.

title: G.M. to Invest $1.3 Billion to Upgrade 5 Midwest Factories
description: DETROIT  After a year of big profits and surging sales in the United States, the American automakers are investing heavily in their domestic operations in anticipation of more good times to come.

title: Ray Price, Groundbreaking, Hit-Making Country Singer, Dies at 87
description: Ray Price, who was at the forefront of two revolutions in country music as one of its finest ballad singers and biggest hit makers, died on Monday at his home in Mount Pleasant, Tex. He was 87.

title: Apple Says Beyonc Set a Record on iTunes
description: Beyoncs surprise album release last week was celebrated by some commentators as a herald of things to come in the music industry, and dismissed by others as a mere stunt. But by sheer sales numbers, it was an unqualified success.

title: S.E.C. Calls for Stiff Penalties Against Tourre
description: Four months after being found liable for defrauding investors in a soured mortgage deal, Fabrice Tourre now faces a stiff financial penalty for his actions.

title: Travel to Far-Flung Places Spurs Private Jet Growth
description: The destinations read like the world map in the game Risk  Irkutsk, Mongolia, Madagascar.

title: Tom Laughlin, 82, Star of Billy Jack Movie Series, Dies
description: Tom Laughlin, the actor, writer, director and producer who created the Billy Jack movie series of the 1970s, a low-budget fusion of counterculture piety and martial-arts violence that struck a chord with audiences and became a prototype for independent filmmaking and distribution, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: A Transgender Volunteer for the Salvation Army
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  I GOT to the Waterville mall a few minutes early. My shift began at 11, and snow was falling from a pewter sky onto the parking lot. Id been having a hard time. This was about four Christmases ago, a few years after Id come out as transgender. In the aftermath of that unveiling, Id lost a couple of important friendships. Getting into the spirit of the season had been a struggle.

title: Getting Off to a Harmonious Start in Hong Kong
description: I GRADUATED from college on a Friday, started work that following Monday, and three weeks later my boss told me I was going to Europe on a business trip to sell tennis broadcast rights. I was 22 years old and I thought going on a business trip was great since I loved to travel. That was nearly 30 years ago.

title: After a Posting Deal, Questions on a Pitcher
description: The new posting agreement between Major League Baseball and Nippon Professional Baseball was completed Monday when the executive committees of both leagues ratified the deal, perhaps paving the way for the right-handed pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, the most prized Japanese player since Yu Darvish two years ago, to finally be posted.

title: Upon This Burger
description: LOS ANGELES  Just five years ago, Adam Fleischman was in a two-bedroom rental with his wife and their year-old son, fumbling around for a career that might stick. Screenwriting hadnt worked out. Same for finance. He was 38 and, he told me, It was do or die.

title: The Thought Leader
description: Little boys and girls in ancient Athens grew up wanting to be philosophers. In Renaissance Florence they dreamed of becoming Humanists. But now a new phrase and a new intellectual paragon has emerged to command our admiration: The Thought Leader.

title: USEC, Enricher of Uranium for U.S., Seeks Bankruptcy
description: WASHINGTON  USEC, the sole American company in the uranium enrichment business, said Monday that it would file for bankruptcy early next year, although it hopes to keep operating.

title: Muirhead and Britain Are Pushing for an Olympic Medal in Sochi
description: STIRLING, Scotland  It is a sight as arresting as any in winter sports: Eve Muirhead gliding metronomically across the curling sheet, up to  and beyond  the moment when she releases the stone toward its target 150 feet away.

title: Big Bonuses, but a Shift in Who Gets the Biggest
description: Wall Streets senior executives have been holed up in conference rooms across Manhattan the last couple of weeks, locked in tense all-day sessions. The special project: dividing up this years spoils as bonus season approaches.

title: Aid Challenge in Syria Mounts for U.N. Official
description: UNITED NATIONS  Valerie Amos, the top United Nations official responsible for easing the Syrian conflicts humanitarian crisis, has made five visits to the country since early 2012 and has developed a cordial working relationship with Syrian relief officials.

title: What Is Good Teaching?
description: In 2006, an idealistic New York public schoolteacher named Kevin Greer joined the faculty of an idealistic new high school, Brooklyn Community Arts and Media. Greer had previously taught English to 12th grade honors students at Dewitt Clinton, a huge high school in the Bronx. At B.C.A.M., which hoped to inspire students with an arts-driven curriculum, he would be teaching ninth graders. Most of the students had not chosen B.C.A.M., but had simply been assigned to the school. They werent nearly as self-motivated as Greers former students. Many if not most of them read below grade level.

title: Secrets and Contradictions
description: I know a compelling character when I encounter her on the page. Her simplicity betrays an enigmatic complexity, and her known qualities suggest unknown ones. She possesses the one thing I want most from a character: the power to make me want to know more about her.

title: Brooklyns Next Prosecutor Protests $286,000 Payment to Hynes Deputy
description: Brushing aside the objections of the man who made him an electoral lame duck, Charles J. Hynes, the departing Brooklyn district attorney, announced on Monday that he would pay his retiring top deputy almost $286,000 in unused vacation pay, or almost $100,000 more than what a typical city employee could be entitled to.

title: One White House Shift Is Delayed for a Month
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will soon name a new overseer to complete repairs of the governments health insurance website, but the current manager, Jeffrey D. Zients, is delaying his move to become chief White House economic adviser for about a month, administration officials said Monday.

title: Seinfelds Deliberately Inept Web Campaign for Acura
description: IN Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee, a web series introduced in 2012, Jerry Seinfeld borrows a vintage car like a Lamborghini or Jaguar and picks up fellow comics for a drive to a diner or coffee shop, with in-car and roving cameras capturing their conversations about stand-up comedy and show business. But for a new season that begins Jan. 2, its not just cars that Mr. Seinfeld is steering  he also wrote a series of commercials for the shows sole sponsor, Acura.

title: Many Detect End of Line for Stimulus by the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  The beginning of the end probably will not come on Wednesday, but it is coming soon. The Federal Reserve has made clear that its bond-buying campaign will not continue at the present pace for much longer.

title: E.U. Pledges Aid for Mideast Peace
description: The European Union will provide an unprecedented package of European political, economic and security support to the Israelis and Palestinians if they reach a permanent peace deal, the union said in a statement on Monday after a foreign affairs council meeting in Brussels. The package will offer Israel and the future Palestinian state a special privileged partnership, including increased access to the European markets, closer cultural and scientific links, facilitation of trade and investments as well as promotion of business-to-business relations, the statement added. The European Union also condemned continued Israeli settlement construction and expressed concern over incitement and episodes of violence, actions it said undermined peace negotiations. Secretary of State John Kerry brokered a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian talks in July after years of stagnation.

title: Playing With Abandon May Have Exacted Toll
description: A special Mass at a Roman Catholic church on Sunday in Jacksonville, Fla., was planned as a remembrance for Ryan Freel, a former major leaguer who committed suicide nearly one year ago at 36. It became more than that, however, after Freels family had learned four days earlier of a factor that might have precipitated his death on Dec. 22, 2012.

title: A Powerful Rebuke of Mass Surveillance
description: For the first time since the revelation of the National Security Agencys vast dragnet of all Americans telephone records, a federal court has ruled that such surveillance is significantly likely to be unconstitutional.

title: The Next Chapter for Derivatives Regulation
description: Under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a five-member panel of three Democrats and two Republicans, has an all-important role in regulating the multitrillion-dollar market in derivatives.

title: Insider Trading Trial of Former SAC Manager Goes to the Jury
description: The fate of a former top trader for the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors will soon hinge on whether or not jurors believe the governments star witness, a technology analyst who has pleaded guilty to insider trading.

title: Intersection: San Franciscos Mission
description: In the Mission District, Jai Carrillo, a hairstylist, said his personal style was kind of like if the Golden Girls ran into Vivienne Westwood.

title: Discrimination in Sochi
description: While Vladimir Putin turns Russia into an increasingly dangerous place for gays and lesbians, the Winter Olympics in the Russian resort city of Sochi will soon begin drawing athletes and fans from around the world. There will certainly be gay athletes. And there will be thousands of spectators who come from countries where it is not a crime to love someone of the same sex.

title: Cornered by Accusations, Christie Parries With Jokes and Stonewalls With Snarls
description: Gov. Chris Christie is a wonderfully primal New Jersey politician who embraces three truths: Transparency is for squares, bluster is your friend and fingerprints are a pain.

title: Study Raises Questions About Antibleeding Drug
description: Horses treated with the race-day antibleeding medication furosemide bled at a greater rate than horses that did not receive the drug, a study released by the Breeders Cup on Monday found.

title: Pope Replaces Conservative U.S. Cardinal on Influential Vatican Committee
description: ROME  Pope Francis moved on Monday against a conservative American cardinal who has been an outspoken critic of abortion and same-sex marriage, by replacing him on a powerful Vatican committee with another American who is less identified with the culture wars within the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Prison for Rhode Island Lawyer in Tale of Insurance and Death
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Joseph Caramadre contends he was a philanthropist and a clever lawyer, offering $2,000 payments to people who were dying. The United States attorney contends that he was a scam artist, preying on the very ill and getting rich by defrauding insurance companies.

title: Bloomberg Focuses on His Legacy in Farewell Tour Across the City
description: With 15 days left in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is focused on his legacy.

title: Finding Classroom Rigor in a Global Curriculum
U.S.-Germany Intelligence Partnership Falters Over Spying
description: BERLIN  Nearly two months after President Obama assured Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany that the United States would never again target her cellphone, a broader effort to build a new intelligence relationship with Germany is floundering, with each side increasingly reluctant to make major changes in how it deals with the other.

title: Knicks Smith and Shumpert Become Question Marks
description: The Knicks were undefeated when Coach Mike Woodson declared an open competition between Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith for a spot in the starting lineup. Optimism was running high. Neither player had missed a shot.

title: Federal Consumer Agency Sues Over Online Loans
description: It sounds like something from a movie: A $10,000 loan with an annual interest rate of nearly 90 percent, that costs more than $60,000 to repay.

title: Bolivian Jail, an Actors Help and Now a Return to New York
description: A Brooklyn flooring contractor and father of five, who was jailed in Bolivia for 18 months until the intervention of the actor Sean Penn lessened his punishment to confinement under house arrest, has been spirited out of the country and is in the New York area, according to Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn.

title: Judge Has Record of Wrestling With Thorny Issues, and the U.S. Government
description: WASHINGTON  Judge Richard J. Leon, who shook up Washington on Monday by declaring a National Security Agency data collection program almost Orwellian, is a conservative and a vivid writer who does not shrink from criticizing the federal government on matters as varied as pornography, death penalty drugs and terrorism suspects at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: New York Archdiocese Wins Ruling on Contraception

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 11:30 A.M. (MoreMax) ANNA KARENINA (2012) Keira Knightley (above) stars as Anna, the bored wife of a virtuous government official (Jude Law) in mid-19th-century Imperial Russia, who travels from St. Petersburg to Moscow to calm a marital storm in the household of her philandering brother (Matthew Macfadyen) in Joe Wrights stagy adaptation of this Tolstoy novel. Aaron Taylor-Johnson plays the man who captures her heart: Count Vronsky, a young military officer with the eyes of a poet and a domineering mother (Olivia Williams). And Alicia Vikander is Kitty, a lovely young woman adored by Levin, the gloomy rural landowner (Domhnall Gleeson) widely understood to be Tolstoys alter ego, whose idea of love  an ennobling union of souls  is a rebuke to the amorality festering in cities. I assume you know that it ends badly, but Mr. Wrights real interest, like Tolstoys, is in everything that happens in between Annas first meeting with Vronsky and her final encounter with the wheels of a train, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And while Mr. Wrights screen versions of Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice and Ian McEwans Atonement remain trapped in literariness, he added, Mr. Wrights Anna Karenina is different. It is risky and ambitious enough to count as an act of artistic hubris, and confident enough to triumph on its own slightly  wonderfully  crazy terms. Pious Tolstoyans may knit their brows about the stylistic liberties Mr. Wright and the screenwriter, Tom Stoppard, have taken, but surely Tolstoy can withstand (and may indeed benefit from) their playful, passionate rendering of his masterpiece. Jacqueline Durran won an Oscar for costume design.

He has been ubiquitous, hawking Dodge Durango trucks, accepting a tribute from a journalism school and matching wits with members of the profession he exists to lampoon. That television news has so eagerly embraced Ron Burgundy may be evidence that the Anchorman movies dont go far enough, satirically speaking. The man may be a vain, ethically obtuse, generally clueless buffoon, but it would not occur to him to allow a fictional character on his air to sell a product. Hes no George Stephanopoulos.

title: Like a Home Renovation, but With Vermeers

That hiatus, during which some of the finest Rembrandts, Vermeers and other masterpieces of Dutch art vanished from public view, would most likely be forgotten if not for The New Rijksmuseum, Oeke Hoogendijks eye-opening, patience-testing new documentary. The film dwells on the logistical and bureaucratic details of the process, and if it does not exactly write a fresh chapter in the history of art, it stands as an exemplary study in the sociology of art administration.

For Theodore Twombly (Joaquin Phoenix), the poetically melancholic hero in Her, Spike Jonzes exquisite new movie, that voice (Scarlett Johansson) is a lifeline to the world, which he has loosened his hold on since separating from his wife. The voice brightly greets him in the morning and, with a sexy huskiness, bids him good night in the evening. The voice organizes his files, gets him out of the house and, unlike some multitasking females, doesnt complain about juggling her many roles as his assistant, comfort, turn-on, helpmate and savior  which makes her an ideal companion even if shes also just software.

title: Q. & A. With Arthur Levine

In 2006, he wrote a report describing extremely low standards for admission and graduation from teaching programs. Teacher education right now is the Dodge City of education, unruly and chaotic, he said at the time. Now, as the president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation, which supports scholarship and public service in a variety of fields, he remains focused on improving the achievement gap in education among races and incomes. The foundation has given stipends to nearly 1,000 teaching fellows who have gone on to teach in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and math) in high-needs public schools. The gathering was held to commemorate the second anniversary of the death of Mr. Kims father, the longtime dictator Kim Jong-il, but analysts said Mr. Kim also used the event to show that he was firmly in control after the execution of his uncle last week. The meeting was the first major national event that Mr. Kim presided over since the execution of Jang Song-thaek, who had long been considered the No. 2 leader. title: Doctor, Teacher, Soldier, Spy
description: In December 1863, a Union cavalry company escorted the disinterred remains of Dr. Rufus Gillpatrick through the streets of Lawrence, Kan., to Oread Cemetery, where they were reburied. Still marked with desolation from William Quantrills violent raid in August, the city remained an abolitionist stronghold and was a fitting final resting place for Dr. Gillpatrick. Although he had been, at times, a surgeon, politician, teacher, military adviser, reporter, farmer, soldier and spy, Gillpatrick was perhaps best known to contemporaries for the ardent opposition to slavery that ultimately cost him his life. His curious career and violent death illustrates the porous line between civilian and soldier on the frontier.

title: Social Conservatives and Social Science

Noting that academic economists range from liberal to libertarian,he asks: What can we learn from conservative economics failure to launch?One possibility, he allows, is that social conservatism simply doesnt have any solid economic arguments behind it, but that has an obvious problem:Rationalizing social conservatism using Econ 101 is childs play. Just close your eyes, tap your heels three times, and say Negative externalities.' (From risky sex, drug and alcohol use, family breakdown, etc.) And yet, Caplan says, almost no social conservative bothers to make [economic] arguments. Why dont they?

title: Q. & A. With Liping Ma
description: Liping Ma, a former teacher and principal in China, has written extensively about the differences between how the United States and China teach math to elementary school students. After earning a doctorate in curriculum and teacher education from Stanford University, she worked as a senior scholar at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. In 1999, she published Knowing and Teaching Elementary Mathematics, an influential book that argues elementary school teachers need a better grounding in arithmetic and math in order to teach them effectively to their students. She currently works as an independent researcher. Dr. Ma spoke recently with Vikas Bajaj of The New York Times editorial board about her research and why Chinese and other Asian students score well above their American counterparts on international math tests.

title: 36 Hours in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

Jackson Hole and its slopes are more accessible than ever, with direct flights from Newark, Denver, Houston, Dallas/Fort Worth, Minneapolis, Chicago, Atlanta, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Salt Lake City, and a recent overhaul of Jackson Hole Mountain Resorts lift system. But there is also plenty on the valley floor to grab your attention, including vast wilderness reserves where deer and the buffalo roam. Add to that Jackson, an old-school cowboy town with lots of new panache, the bohemian log cabin village of Wilson and the luxurious modern facilities of Teton Village, and youve got a weekend where true-West sensibilities and wilderness adventures are balanced by comfort and style.

He was advised to make them younger and to add more sex and violence, but his strengths are humor and Holmesian cogitation, and he stuck with them. He was right. One book in the series won an award for the funniest mystery novel of 2008.

Theyve got nothing on Delores Nunn, who is 59 and lives in Yorktown, Va. Ms. Nunn recently finished decorating 15 artificial trees for the house she shares with her husband, James, a retired Army colonel. Each tree is trimmed according to a theme, including nuns, travel, sock monkeys, the beach, wine and nature. A small dog-themed tree sits near the food bowl of Mazie, the couples springer spaniel-poodle mix. title: Caribbean Travelers Warned About Mosquito-Borne Illness
description: Travelers to the Caribbean island of St. Martin are being warned that, for the first time, a mosquito-borne illness called chikungunya has been detected there. Chikungunya causes fever, headache and severe joint pains that last about a week, and sometimes longer. There is no vaccine, so the only prevention is to avoid mosquito bites, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday. So far, 10 cases have been confirmed in St. Martin, and health officials believe the virus is present in the islands mosquito populations  the first time that it appears to have established itself anywhere in the Western Hemisphere. Previous outbreaks have occurred in Africa, Asia and parts of Europe.

In November, it reopened as the King Cole Bar and Salon. Mr. Delucie brought his night life cachet, a war chest of regulars and a younger crowd that buzzes later than before. title: Turkey Jailing the Most Journalists

Turkey was followed by Iran and China; the three countries account for more than half of the 211 journalists jailed worldwide as of Dec. 1. The number of journalists killed and imprisoned fell in 2013, but the year was the second worst for the number of imprisoned since record keeping began in 1990; the worst was last year, when 232 were held. The report said 52 journalists were killed so far this year. The largest number, 21, were killed in Syrias civil war. The second largest number of fatalities was in Egypt, with six dead.

title: Sex and Drugs and I.P.O.s
description: If you want to know the truth, the Wolf of Wall Street  the person, that is, not the Martin Scorsese-Leonardo DiCaprio movie that opens on Christmas Day  spent only a fleeting few months on the actual Wall Street. In 1987, Jordan Belfort  a.k.a. the wolf himself  took a job at L. F. Rothschild, an old white-shoe firm. It was his first job in the business, and he was given the assignment of cold-calling prospects that he would then turn over to a broker. In his memoir  upon which the movie is based  Mr. Belfort claims, among other things, that a successful Rothschild broker (played by Matthew McConaughey on screen) took him to lunch on his first day and told him to masturbate often if he hoped to be a good broker himself. Given Rothschilds stodgy reputation, I tend to think this story is an exaggeration, an act of salesmanship intended to lure in Hollywood. No matter. Not long after Mr. Belfort began working for L. F. Rothschild, the crash of 1987 wiped out the firm and took his job with it.

title: Dwight Garners 10 Favorite Books of 2013

title: Janet Maslins 10 Favorite Books of 2013
description: LAWRENCE IN ARABIA: WAR, DECEIT, IMPERIAL FOLLY AND THE MAKING OF THE MODERN MIDDLE EAST by Scott Anderson (Doubleday). This superbly fine-tuned account of the Middle East during World War I is no hagiographic T. E. Lawrence biography. Lawrences strategic talents, not least his peculiar skill at polite belligerence, are seen within the full context of wartime espionage by other players. Mr. Anderson does a fine job of piecing together the many conflicting Middle East interests that are ordinary eclipsed by the alluring Lawrence story. An original, illuminating history that requires and rewards close attention.

title: Michiko Kakutanis 10 Favorite Books of 2013
description: THE GOLDFINCH by Donna Tartt (Little, Brown & Company). In this astonishing Dickensian novel, Ms. Tartt uses her myriad talents  her tactile prose, her knowledge of her characters inner lives, her instinct for suspense  to immerse us in a fully imagined fictional world that reminds us of the wonderful stay-up-all-night pleasures of reading. The novel is at once a thriller involving the theft of a famous Dutch painting; a panoramic portrait of New York (and America) in the post-9/11 era; and an old-fashioned coming-of-age story about an orphan named Theo who, with his best friend Boris, one of the great recent fictional creations, will enter the pantheon of classic buddy acts alongside Laurel and Hardy, Vladimir and Estragon, and Pynchons Mason and Dixon.

For another, weve listed books that we liked as much as we admired. Thats where the quirks come in.

title: Protecting Citizens, and Their Privacy
description: THE United States and its allies face major national security threats, particularly from international terrorism, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and cyberwarfare and espionage. Effective surveillance by the National Security Agency and other agencies within the intelligence community has helped to keep Americans safe from such threats. The nation will continue to need such protection in the future.

description: The growing basketball collaboration between Dennis Rodman and Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, can be traced back to an Irish online betting company and the pope.

description: Some Christmas songs are meant to be cheerful but depress you because theyre so awful. These tend to play on an endless loop and brutally de-jollify public spaces this time of year.

title: Baby Makes 3 or 4, but Not 5
description: My husband and I had our first baby this year. Were thrilled. And even though my parents got divorced last year, I want both of them to celebrate Christmas with us. So far, theyve refused to be in the same room together. (It was a messy split.) I told them how important it is for me and my son to celebrate his first Christmas as a family. But they still said no. How can I get them to see how important this is to us?

title: Government Requests to Remove Online Material Increase at Google
description: Governments, led by the United States, are increasingly demanding that Google remove information from the Web.

title: New Mexico Becomes 17th State to Allow Gay Marriage
description: The New Mexico Supreme Court unanimously affirmed on Thursday the right of same-sex partners to marry in the state, reasoning that the protections and responsibilities that result from the marital relationship shall apply equally to them and to opposite-sex couples.

description: Images from local media surfaced last week on Facebook and in other social media showing what were described as the graphic consequences of a drone-fired missile strike on a convoy that was part of a wedding party in a remote area of Yemen.

description: The New Jersey Legislature approved legislation on Thursday that would allow students without legal immigration status to pay in-state college tuition. Gov. Chris Christie planned to sign it on Friday, a spokesman said.

description: A six-bedroom Scarsdale Colonial with a heated greenhouse and a five-bedroom Stamford Colonial with a rambling floor plan.

title: Garlic Fails to Curb Yeast Infections
description: Oral garlic supplements are a popular remedy for vaginal yeast infections, but a randomized trial has found them ineffective.

title: Starting Over in a Familiar Spot
description: Of all the kinds of restaurants in suburban New Jersey that a chef might hitch his dreams to, a traditional French bistro must rank among the most tempting and the most treacherous. Tempting because the pleasures are many, especially for those who have encountered the real thing; treacherous because that special Gallic alchemy of bustle and warmth, of forthright and deeply satisfying cooking, is confoundingly hard to pull off.

title: Your First Dance Songs
description: For many couples, a first-dance song has the power to evoke memories of their steadfast relationship. As part of our occasional series, Wedding Album, we invited New York Times readers to share the name of the song they selected for their first dance and why it is meaningful to them. We received dozens of stories that represented the tribulations of long distance relationships, the enduring love of high school sweethearts, and the satisfaction of finding love at an older age.

description: CLASSICAL music is finally embracing the download. Classical music devotees have traditionally been more, well, traditional in their attachment to actual physical recordings.

title: Congress Is Warned Anew Not to Breach Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON  With its new budget deal, Congress has avoided one threat of another government shutdown. But unless Congress acts, the threat of a breach of the debt ceiling looms early next year, the Treasury Department warned in a letter to congressional leaders on Thursday.

title: Bryant and Lakers Plans Break Down
description: LOS ANGELES  When the Lakers awarded Kobe Bryant an eye-popping two-year, $48.5 million contract extension last month, it seemed like an inordinate amount of faith  and cap space  to place on their aging star, who at 35 had not yet come back from a torn left Achilles tendon.

title: Young Souls Portray the Wit of Hamlet, With Brevity
description: Let it not be said that Shakespeare means nothing to young people.

title: Payouts to N.F.L. Retirees With Mild Dementia Are Being Clarified
description: A persistent criticism of the $765 million settlement the N.F.L. agreed to in August is that only retired players in the worst health will receive payouts.

description: Katie, the syndicated talk show starring Katie Couric, which began with enormous fanfare in September 2012, will cease production at the end of the current season.

description: When Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire financier, visited his father-in-law at the emergency room of a hospital in Manhattan after Hurricane Sandy last year, he was horrified by what he saw.

title: Verizon to Release First Transparency Report
description: Following in the footsteps of companies like Google and Facebook, Verizon Communications is going to reveal more about what customer information it shares with the government.

title: Hazelnuts Complement Oregon Pinot Noirs
description: Oregon pinot noirs have started to express terroir. At this point in their history they have yet to exhibit the velvet lushness of fine red Burgundies, but they are on their way. And when it comes to terroir, a few iconic ingredients that suggest Oregon beg for these wines. Im thinking mushrooms, black truffles and hazelnuts.

title: New Look for Verdis Corpulent Clown
description: A bully and a tease, buffoonish and brilliant: Falstaff is many things. But above all, the hero of Verdis comic opera is defined by his girth. Se Falstaff sassottiglia, non  pi lui, Sir John sings early on in the first scene: If Falstaff grows thin, he is no longer himself.

title: Mans Best Friend Takes on a New Meaning
description: She has floppy ears, eyes of exquisite sadness and an operatic tendency toward ecstasy, anguish and other big emotions. Leave her alone in a thunderstorm, and she may fall into despair.

title: In a Variety of Music, Seeing Is Hearing
description: Images of strange and startling beauty percolate through Squonk Operas Mayhem and Majesty, a small spectacle of a show occupying that hard-to-classify intersection where live music meets visual art.

title: Study Documents 2012 Downturn in Chinese Art Market
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas art auction market suffered a sharp downturn in 2012, amid a global slump in demand for Chinese art, fueled in part by concern about the many fakes that are offered for sale.

title: Economists: Less Scrooge-Like Than You Thought
description: A few years ago Joel Waldfogel wrote Scroogeonomics: Why You Shouldnt Buy Presents for the Holidays, an economic manifesto about the wastefulness of gift-giving. The Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicagos Booth School of Business recently queried its panel of 46 economic experts on the subject, and the responses were surprisingly less Grinch-like.

title: Making Music Outdoors
description: Perhaps its somewhat perverse, given the season, for the Miser to recommend joining a series of outdoor musical parades across the city this weekend. But looking over the lineup for this years Make Music Winter festival on Saturday, you might conclude that coat weather never sounded so good.

title: Does the A.A.P. Logo Belong on Formula Gift Bags?
description: If you walked out of a hospital with a new baby and an Enfamil-sponsored gift bag of formula during the past year, you might be wondering why it sported the American Academy of Pediatrics logo on its tag, just a little over a year after the same group released a lengthy policy statement reaffirming its recommendation that babies be exclusively breast-fed for the first six months, and up to one year with complementary foods. The logo appears on a safety tag attached to a bag containing gifts of formula as well as a booklet published by the American Academy of Pediatrics, New Mothers Breastfeeding Essentials, with, according to Crystal Lewis of Womens eNews, Mead Johnsons name prominently displayed on the inside of the cover page.

title: The Animation of the Imagination
description: One way to look at An Animated World, a retrospective of films distributed by the New York-based company Gkids, is in terms of dollars. Of the 18 films in this festival, which begins Friday at the IFC Center in Manhattan, those that have already been released commercially in American theaters have made a total of about $2.8 million. Thats 1  percent of what Disneys Frozen has earned in less than a month.

title: Ambassador for the New
description: A look at a new exhibition at MoMA that highlights the career of the gallery owner and art collector Ileana Sonnabend.

title: The American West in Bronze, 1850-1925
description: A look at works in a new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Why Oregon Will Fondly Remember 2011
description: How important is vintage in discussing fine wines? Id say we overrate it, or at least over-generalize about it. Focusing on vintage characteristics may be a helpful shorthand approach for wine writers, but usually it is too simplistic, leading to reflex decisions rather than more-considered ones.

title: Backward to Somewhere
description: The modest, run-down home at the center of The Past is filled with rooms that  much like the characters who are busily, sometimes leisurely passing through them  somehow feel cut off from one another. Set in a characterless Paris suburb thats as physically and psychically distant from the City of Light as the moon, the movie is both a family melodrama and a relationship story, which perhaps inevitably means its about love and loyalty, secrets and lies, and how the past, never being dead, just hovers around waiting to smack us upside the head. All this also makes it something of a haunted house movie, except that its characters are plagued by ghosts of their own design.

title: After Hours | A Goofy Display of Acrobatics, Juggling and Hula Hooping
description: Cline Dion, Cirque du Soleil, poutine. Lets face it: We expect a highly virtuosic level of cheesiness from the Quebecois, and we revel in it. So it goes at N.Y.U.s Skirball Center, where Cirkopolis, the latest body-twisting delight from the Montreal neo-circus troupe Cirque Eloize, is in residency through Jan. 5. The show begins with a single man, a beaten-down bureaucrat in business drab, stamping papers at a desk before giant projections of rotating industrial cogs,  la Metropolis. It sounds like the scene is being set for some Weimar-tinged exploration of the alienation of the human worker. Not quite. Those Bauhaus facades are a mere backdrop for a dazzling display of human bodily levitation, contortion and gyration. The acrobats defy gravity in jaw-dropping performances on giant wheel-like contraptions, atop one anothers bodies, suspended from trapezes and ropes, and, astoundingly, up and down a 100-foot pole at frenetic speeds. Its hard not to deliver an ovation when a pretty young woman in a fluttery red dress whirls inside a massive hula hoop, like a human dreidel.

title: Ceiling at Theater in London Collapses on Audience
description: Updated, 6:32 p.m. Dozens of people were injured, including at least seven of them seriously, when part of the ceiling of the Apollo Theater in Londons West End collapsed onto the audience during a performance Thursday night, police and fire officials said.

title: Manifest Destiny, at the Point of a Gun
description: Around 1905, the city fathers of Denver decided that a monument to honor their pioneering predecessors was in order. The commission went to Frederick William MacMonnies, an American sculptor trained in the Beaux-Arts who lived in France. MacMonnies proposed a multitiered fountain topped by the figure of an Indian chief, but local citizens objected to celebrating a recently feared and despised enemy. So MacMonnies offered instead a sculpture of the all-around frontiersman Kit Carson (1809-68), who, to this day, appears in bronze riding a rearing horse at the summit of the Pioneer Monument in downtown Denver.

title: A Legendary Dealers Eagle Eye
description: If you think that all art exhibitions result from the natural meeting of laudable subjects and curatorial passion, consider Ileana Sonnabend: Ambassador for the New, which opens on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the subject is a worthy one  Sonnabend was among the most foresighted art dealers of the late 20th century  the show is a byproduct of legal hassles and diplomatic campaigns surrounding her billion-dollar estate, which may be one reason it feels, as a tribute, cool and impersonal, a portrait-in-art that is only a sketch.

title: The Obsessions of a Straight American Guy
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Jason Rhoades died unexpectedly in 2006, at the age of 41, he left behind a vast and bewildering body of work: rambling, porous, performative installations that were as deliriously grandiose as anything by Dieter Roth, Paul McCarthy, Matthew Barney or Thomas Hirschhorn. Curators are still sorting it all out, to judge from Jason Rhoades: Four Roads, at the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

title: Desperate Years: To Be Young, British and Lacking
description: For todays socially conscious British filmmakers, northern England is more or less what southern Italy was to the postwar neorealists: a landscape of social misery, both picturesque and harsh. Instead of a disenfranchised peasantry clinging to tradition in the face of modernity, contemporary British cinema finds a demoralized postindustrial underclass fighting for dignity at the margins of the global economy.

title: Art as Currency in a Tragic Time
description: A personal art collection can be displayed as a trophy room or as a diary. The Ileana Sonnabend exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is cast in greatest-hits mode; MoMAs the right place for it. Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart: Collected by Julie Ault at the nonprofit gallery Artists Space is an intimate document, scrappy, annotated, apartment size. The whole thing, 200 pieces stretched over two locations, could probably fit in a decent-size studio, if you stored some behind furniture and under the bed.

description: New Mexicos Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that excluding same-sex couples from the freedom to marry violates the states constitution. That makes New Mexico the first marriage equality state in the Southwest.

title: Not So Fast on Volcker Rule, Regulators Tell Smaller Banks
description: It didnt take long for the financial industry to get bank regulators to make an exception to the Volcker Rule when it comes to limiting risk-taking by smaller banks.

title: An Aging Actress Faces the Mirror
description: The cosmic and the microscopic are casually  and delicately  juxtaposed in All the Light in the Sky, an evocative, slightly melancholic movie directed and photographed by the prolific mumblecore auteur Joe Swanberg. This portrait of a middle-aged actress in Los Angeles who makes a decent living as a Hollywood bit player but worries about the future, is bolstered by the astoundingly natural performance of Jane Adams (Happiness, Hung). Her chipper, articulate character, Marie, is 45 and acutely aware of her professional shelf life. She lives in a comfortable Malibu home on stilts that hugs the Pacific Coast.

description: MOSCOW  A regional court in Kazan, Russia, convicted a gay-rights advocate on Thursday for violating the countrys much-criticized law against gay propaganda.

title: Other Countries, Other Shores
description: We love poets for the things their poems lead us to imagine; but equally, we love them for how we imagine their lives to be. Confusing poets lives with their work is an illusion as old as the tradition of confusing words with objects. But in fact it is for the sake of this illusion that we feel such a strong need for poetry, for novels, for literature. There are some poets whose work we read with their lives in mind, and what we know of those lives ensures that their poetry leaves a more enduring impression. C. P. Cavafy is, for me, just such a poet. Like Edgar Allan Poe, like Franz Kafka, Cavafy makes no explicit reference to himself in his best and most stirring work; and yet, with every poem we read, we cannot help thinking of him.

title: A Cockeyed Optimist
description: Economic nostalgia can have a strong appeal, especially following more than five years of a financial crisis and its aftermath. In the United States, people talk longingly of the mid-20th century, when the middle class was growing and upward mobility was the norm. In Europe and Japan, many hark back to the 1980s, before the euro was born and the Japanese bubble burst. Even in China and India, two of the worlds more dynamic economies, some like to celebrate a time when life did not revolve around breakneck growth.

title: Norman Rockwell, the Storyteller
description: Dear fragile Norman Rockwell. He grew up in a series of cramped apartments and shabby boardinghouses in Upper Manhattan, skinny, weak-chinned, squinty, an abysmal student, inept at math, probably dyslexic, neglected by his parents, overshadowed by a handsome, athletic older brother, and for the rest of his life was uncertain of himself and modest to a fault. He enrolled in art school to become an illustrator in the footsteps of Howard Pyle and N. C. Wyeth, just as the Armory Show of 1913 was about to usher in the avant-garde and relegate illustration  art as storytelling  to the back pages. He was a loner, did not feel close to his parents or brother, was not a devoted father to his three sons. He was married to his work; his three wives, Irene OConnor, Mary Barstow and Molly Punderson, learned to accommodate. His biographer reports that his love life was stark: Nothing that can be described as a love letter survives among his papers. It seems unlikely that he ever wrote one.

title: Like Simba, Only Hes a Plucky Pachyrhinosaurus
description: The Lion King goes prehistoric in Walking With Dinosaurs, a good-looking extension of the franchise that began as a BBC television series.

title: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 20-26
description: A Christmas Carol

title: A Dream Factory for a Benighted China
description: What you dont dare imagine, we dare to do is the motto of the dream team known as Personal Tailor, a fantasy fabrication service (led by Ge You and Bai Baihe) that provides wealthy clients with a taste of the lives they have always wanted. No request is too outlandish (the Custom Martyrdom Package will furnish you with a simulated Nazi interrogation, hunger strike optional) or too elaborate, even if the outcomes are not always as planned.

title: Spare Times for Dec. 20-26
description: Christmas at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Jan. 6) The museums annual Nativity display, featuring a crche within a Christmas tree, made its debut in 1957. It was the idea of Loretta Hines Howard, an artist and collector who donated over 200 18th-century Neapolitan crche figures to the museum. After her death in 1982, her family continued the tradition. Visitors circling the tree and this years display can see more than 20 cherubs and 50 angels positioned among the branches.

title: Enter Playwright, Trailed by Filmmakers
description: Tracy Letts knows his play August: Osage County is a winner. A scathingly funny tale of a broken Oklahoma family, August won the Tony Award, the Pulitzer and almost every other accolade for best play after it opened on Broadway in 2007.

title: From Simple Chords, Trance-Inducing Effects
description: Its not hard to concoct a list of likely inspirations for Stars of the Lid, the persuasive ambient-music duo formed in 1993 by Brian McBride and Adam Wiltzie. Seminal tape-loop meditations by Robert Fripp and Brian Eno, the haunting tidal wash of Gavin Bryarss most influential handful of works, the infinite sadness of Goreckis Third Symphony, the unsettling disquiet of Angelo Badalamentis Twin Peaks music: All this and more resonates in the duos work.

title: A Whirl of Bodies Spinning Illusions
description: reMIX, the Momix program that opened Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater for a three-week run, is a greatest-hits show. There are 13 pieces, one going back to 1982, one new to New York, but most familiar from previous reMIX samplers. However shuffled, the product formula remains the same: fit performers doing gymnastic exercises that are fitfully impressive, theatrical illusions that intermittently please or fool the eye, lots of props.

title: It Aint Over When the Hallelujah Is Sung
description: May I just ask: Were you one of the two dozen or so audience members who stampeded out of Tuesday nights New York Philharmonic performance of Handels Messiah right after the Hallelujah? Because if so, I feel it incumbent upon me to tell you: You missed the best bits.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Price of a Stolen Credit Card, and #NSAMovieTitles
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Hiking in a Winter Wonderland
description: JUST because temperatures have dropped doesnt mean outdoor efforts to elevate your heart rate should take a nose dive, too. New York City offers many walking trails and paths through scenic, wooded parks and along breathtaking waterways.

title: Jones Group to Be Bought Out by Private Equity Firm
description: The Jones Group said on Thursday that it had accepted a buyout offer of $15 per share from private equity firm Sycamore Partners, bringing the long rumored deal to fruition.

title: Fred Benjamin, Exacting and Inventive Teacher of Jazz Dance, Dies at 69
description: Fred Benjamin, an internationally known teacher of jazz dance who was also part of the creative wave of young black modern-dance choreographers who came to prominence in the 1970s, died on Dec. 14 in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Where the Ghosts Smoke Cigars
description: One of the newest landmarks to be designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission is the 1929 Tammany Hall, on the east side of Union Square at 17th Street. Although it was built during a high point of Tammany fortunes, when Al Smith, Robert F. Wagner and Gentleman Jimmy Walker were regulars, its really not much to look at: a mild, inoffensive essay in the Georgian style.

title: In the Shadow of Rising Towers, Laments of Lost Sunlight in New York
description: Having to live in someone elses shadow is one of the risks of being a New Yorker. Yet for untold thousands, this vexing state of affairs is literally true. In a city forever sprouting new buildings, the quest to reach higher often comes at the cost of stealing somebody elses light.

title: The Top 10 Photo Books of 2013
description: Stacks of books lined the countertops of the photo department in precarious, even Seuss-ian formations. They made for a daunting task, possibly a workplace hazard. There were formidable publications from the likes of Philip Lorca DiCorcia, Gregory Crewdson and Joel Meyerowitz. Books by artists like Taryn Simon and Edward Burtynsky, whose works had appeared in the magazine. We even had entries with titles like Quotations from Chairman Mao Tsetong and Holy Bible. There are too many good books this year, lamented one exhausted photo editor when the judging was finished.

description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

description: LUBBOCK

description: This animated Op-Doc explores the life of Nadezhda Popova, known as Nadia, who became a World War II hero as part of a Soviet all-female bombing regiment.

title: The Night Witch
description: This is one of five films commissioned in conjunction with The Times Magazines The Lives They Lived issue, which commemorates people who died this year.

description: A sudden  or not so sudden  move is an instant hit with everybody concerned.

title: The Poetry of Downsizing
description: Last spring, when the novelist Jean Hanff Korelitz and her husband, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Irish poet Paul Muldoon, decided to move to New York City from Princeton, N.J., they figured the hard part would be finding an apartment they liked. Really, that was the easy part. They found lots of apartments they liked.

title: Chinese, Without the Fusion
description: The Orient in Bethpage is the real deal: a Chinese restaurant with no sushi bar, no fusion dishes and no apologies. Twenty years ago, there were many restaurants like this, though most were not nearly as good. Today there are far fewer, and the Orient gets my vote as the best Chinese restaurant on Long Island.

title: Hunter Chic With Some Tongue in Cheek
description: Nick Di Bona, who worked for almost a decade at Peter Pratts Inn, in Yorktown, has opened his own place, Madison Kitchen, on the west side of the tracks in Larchmont, near a sports club and auto body shops. Mr. Di Bona, who is not yet 30, has turned a former red-sauce Italian joint into a glittering ode to the midcentury cocktail lounge. Its not a big space, but after a long renovation, it looks like a million bucks.

title: Judges Party Switch Gives Democrats Something to Build On
description: When Lawrence E. Meyers won a seat on the statewide Court of Criminal Appeals in 1992, he was the first Republican elected to the states highest criminal court.

title: Hagel Criticizes Chinese Navy, Citing Near Miss
description: WASHINGTON  The Chinese Navy has been irresponsible, and its actions risk escalating tensions with the United States, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said Thursday in the highest-level rebuke of Beijing since a Chinese warship came dangerously close to an American guided missile cruiser this month.

title: A White-Glove State of Mind
description: As New York Citys luxury buildings wage battle over who can deliver the most outsize amenities to residents, some are expanding their focus to include the doormen who quietly usher in residents, handle the packages and hail the cabs.

description: Amid a persistent drought, a growing population and a dwindling supply of surface water, much of Texas is  searching  for underground water resources.

title: For Targets Shoppers, a New Holiday To-Do List
description: Target confirmed on Thursday that hackers gained access to credit card and debit card information for 40 million of its customers during the crush of the holiday shopping season. The company encouraged everyone who shopped in its United States stores from Nov. 27 through Dec. 15 to be vigilant about monitoring their accounts and their credit. Here are some tips on how to do so.

title: Group Seeks Special Label for Food: Natural
description: The trade organization representing the nations largest food and beverage companies wants permission to label as natural products that contain genetically engineered ingredients like corn, soy, canola and sugar, according to a letter sent to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Is It Really a Bistro? Who Cares?
description: It is a welcoming sight on a cold winters eve  a country house, brightly lit, on a country corner. This is 2hopewell Bistro and Bar. Inside you find a cozy basement tavern, and above it dining rooms with ax-hewn posts, flickering candlelight, white walls and wide pine floorboards. Potted palms and Rothko-like prints by the artist Anne Hebebrand, illuminated on the walls, add an apt touch of color. The restaurant is intimate and quiet, with expert service timed perfectly to deliver a luxurious evening. Theres no hurry here.

title: Same View, Less Money
description: As new luxury high-rises like One57 garner stratospheric prices for their unobstructed Central Park views, some developers are focusing on the potential of the parks northern frontier. At a development on West 110th Street, developers hope to draw buyers farther north with the promise of Central Park views at a more modest price.
