title: City Opera Ticket Holders Have to Get in Line With Other Creditors
description: When the New York City Opera filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 3 it asked the court if it could refund $323,000 worth of ticket income to subscribers who had faith in the increasingly shaky company. At the same time, it mailed a letter to those ticket buyers, expressing confidence that the court would grant that request but suggesting that patrons could also waive their right to a refund and donate the money to the failed company instead. Enough ticket buyers agreed to reduce the debt by about $30,000.

title: Dream Leads Hindu Priest to Flushing Store With Temple
description: Kumar Natarajanaidu flipped the cassette in his old tape player and resumed his trance, kneeling on a folded New York Jets blanket and rapidly chanting prayers in Tamil, leaping up each time a customer entered seeking DVDs or flowers.

title: Wells Fargo Poised for Wall Street Run
description: Wells Fargo will start knocking more loudly on the bulge brackets door. The California lender is already one of the top 10 global investment banks by fees, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Much of that comes courtesy of middle-market clients. But if the bank run by John Stumpf starts going after bigger fish, it could put Wall Streets bigwigs on the defensive.

title: Land Leases Are Deferred to de Blasio
description: The Bloomberg administration will not make any decision about a plan to lease some open spaces on public housing land to private developers and will instead leave it to the new mayor  who has objected to the initiative.

title: Beyoncs Surprise Attack
description: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss what Beyoncs self-titled new record represents in her career, and in pop right now.

title: How Lucrative Thy Branches
description: Chris Botek, a tree grower in Lehighton, Pa., is used to people being shocked by how much his Christmas trees cost.

title: For a Hedge Fund Pioneer, a Tiger Fund Burning Bright
description: Julian Robertson, the billionaire investor and an early pioneer of the hedge fund industry, is again proving to be a top picker of new talent.

title: If You Need a New Addiction, Try QuizUp
description: Two years ago, Alec Baldwin was removed from a plane when he refused to turn off his phone because he was engaged in a game of Words With Friends. Some may have judged Mr. Baldwin for what seemed like a bad decision. But to Words With Friends devotees, his anger would have felt entirely familiar: The best smartphone games are downright addictive.

title: Fashion at a Very High Price
description: From cheerful red handbags to festive green belts, colored accessories are often mandatory for the style-conscious during the holiday season. But what many fashionistas dont know is that many of these products may be tainted with high levels of lead  and the brighter and shinier they are, the greater the risk.

title: Popcast: Beyoncs Surprise Attack
description: Last week Beyonc announced, minutes before Friday morning, the release of her new self-titled album; it all appeared on iTunes, as well as a separate video for each song. The album sold, according to iTunes, a million copies in five days. No HealthCare.gov-like problems were reported.

title: Highlights From Obamas News Conference
description: President Obama held a news conference on Friday before departing with his family for a two-week vacation in Hawaii, and Times reporters provided updates and analysis during the event.

title: Playing With Your Christmas Gift? Scheduled for Thursday
description: Im putting fun on the calendar.

title: Have You Been Through a School Lockdown? Tell Us About Your Experience
description: This month, when an 18-year-old student walked into Arapahoe High School in Colorado with a pump-action shotgun and began shooting, teachers and students and administrators knew almost immediately how to respond. Classroom doors slammed shut. Students huddled in the corners and stayed quiet. A resource officer inside the school sprang to action. Nearby, other schools locked down until they knew whether they, too, faced any threat.

title: U.S. Soccer Releases All-Time Best National Teams
description: To end its centennial year, U.S. Soccer this week released its all-time Best XI for the mens and womens national teams.

title: News Corp. Buys a Media Start-Up for $25 Million
description: In a move highlighting the increasing role that user-generated content plays in the news business, News Corporation, owner of The Wall Street Journal, announced on Friday that it had bought Storyful, a company that calls itself a social news agency.

title: A Day of Music, and Movement Therapy, for a Conductor
description: Was it really just two years ago that Trinity Wall Street church scaled back its music program in what an article in this newspaper later called a seeming brush with death? The churchs music and arts director, Julian Wachner, 44, is now rushing to erase such memories. Austerity is out. In its place: a four-month festival of Benjamin Brittens music, Bach cantatas every Monday and a series celebrating the 12 nights of Christmas, which runs from Dec. 26 to Jan. 6. Thats between Mr. Wachners side gigs conducting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music or the Juilliard Opera Theater and as music director of the Washington Chorus, all while he recovers from a summer shoulder injury that temporarily stilled his baton. Mr. Wachner lives in TriBeCa with his wife, the Rev. Emily Wachner, the churchs priest for welcome, liturgy, hospitality and pilgrimage, and the couples American bulldog, Sophie, and cat, Rowan.

title: What Stronger Health Spending Growth Means for Obama
description: Gross domestic product growth was much faster than previously estimated in the third quarter, partly because health care spending was revised sharply upward. Consumer spending on health care services grew at an annual pace of 2.7 percent last quarter, instead of 0.9 percent, as the Commerce Department had previously reported.

title: Pajama Boy Vs. Duck Dynasty
description: Senator John Cornyns longshot challenger in the 2014 Texas Republican primary, Rep. Steve Stockman, is milking the Phil Robertson controversy for all its worth.

title: South Bend, Ind., to Recall Studebakers 1963 Departure
description: Fireworks shows are usually for celebrating a notable anniversary or achievement. But on Friday night in South Bend, Ind., the fireworks will recall a low point: fifty years since Studebaker left its factory there and moved to Canada to fade into oblivion.

title: Statement From Khodorkovsky in Berlin Answers Some Questions, but Not All
description: Last Updated, 7:20 p.m. | Hours after his sudden release from prison on Friday, the Russian dissident Mikhail Khodorkovsky released a statement from Berlin, along with an image of himself being greeted at the airport by Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a former German foreign minister who helped arrange his travel, as my colleagues Steven Lee Myers and David Herszenhorn report.

title: Czars Rule: Romanovs Prove Popular in Todays Russia
description: A replica of Russias grand imperial crown, made of nearly 11,500 diamonds, will be on display in Moscow until early January at the State Historical Museum near Red Square, the latest of dozens of exhibitions across Russia devoted to the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Romanov dynasty.

title: Review: 2014 Mazda CX-9
description: Introduced in 2007, the Mazda CX-9 has been around the block. After all these years (and two face-lifts), corners remain this nimble three-row crossovers natural habit.

title: A Valedictory Radio Chat for Bloomberg and for His Host
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg leaves office at the end of the month. It so happens that his regular on-air interlocutor, the radio dynast John R. Gambling, is retiring, too.

title: Contracting Overhaul Is Promised for Navy
description: WASHINGTON  Navy Secretary Ray Mabus on Friday acknowledged gaps in the Navys oversight of the companies that provide supplies for the nations warships across the world and announced wide-ranging plans to revamp contracting practices that experts say have made it far too easy for businesses to defraud the service out of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Living With a Business Below
description: Every New York apartment has a catch, and so when Ashley Falcon, a gregarious fashion stylist, considered the built-in closets, roomy kitchen and plentiful windows in a particular Greenwich Village rental while apartment-hunting two years ago, she decided that she could stomach the downside: living above a funeral home.

title: Spanish Tortilla With Tomato Salad
description: Spanish tortillas are an adaptable dish that can be served at brunch or a cocktail party.

title: With Friends Like These
description: After shepherding West Virginia into legal existence with its own government and representatives in Washington, Francis H. Pierpont made a surprising decision. Instead of remaining with his friends, family and new duties in the state capital, Wheeling, in late 1863 he headed east toward Alexandria, Va., to take up a much more challenging task: governor of the Restored State of Virginia  in effect, the government in exile.

title: Bingeing on Beyonc: The Ripple Effect
description: Early in the morning of Dec. 13, Beyonc turned the Internet upside down with the surprise release of a new music and video album, announced with a simple Instagram post.

title: Harry Potter Headed Onstage in London
description: LONDON  There have been seven books, selling over 450 million copies, and eight films. Now Harry Potter will apparate into the West End in 2015, in a new play about the early years of J. K. Rowlings boy wizard, before his years at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Ms. Rowling will collaborate on the play with an as-yet unnamed playwright; she will also be a co-producer, she told The Daily Mail on Thursday.

title: Conspicuous Combustion
description: The Lamborghini Aventador LP 700-4 Roadster, an exotic sports car with a $488,175 sticker, brings out ones inner exhibitionist.

title: A Potatos Postcard From Spain
description: Before I had ever tasted a tortilla Espaola, the traditional Spanish potato omelet, I couldnt imagine what the fuss was about. What could be so special about a dish made from only eggs, potatoes and onion?

title: Carriage Driver Is Charged With Animal Cruelty
description: A carriage horse driver with a checkered history was charged on Friday with animal cruelty after a police officer observed him working a horse that was visibly injured, according to court documents.

title: Engaging Shenanigans, Big Surprises
description: The question was written in the sand. It was asked under the big top and with bells on. There was a bended knee followed by a Will you marry me? on an elevator ride, and a proposal made on a hotel rooftop to a soundtrack of whirling propellers. There are many other memorable and creative ways to ask that age-old question. So, since that query is often posed during the holiday season, now may be a good time to review some of the most interesting proposals submitted this year to the Vows pages of The Times.

title: Art and Entertainment That Makes Us Feel Old Before Our Time
description: For much of the 20th century, scientists believed that the slower ones metabolism, the longer ones life. This is called the rate of living theory, and although it is not actually true for humans, it feels increasingly accurate of our machines. The faster our computers get, the faster they seem to break, burn out or become obsolete. The average life span of an American cellphone is 18 months. No wonder the members of my superconnected demographic  young, urban, educated, creative, often described as millennials  are all afraid were shooting to obscurity.

title: How to Make Noise about Antibiotics
description: Some of you have asked me how best to make your opinions heard about routine use of antibiotics in animals, the subject of my column this week. You could:

title: London Theaters Checked After Ceiling Collapse
description: LONDON  The authorities were carrying out inspections of Londons West End theaters on Friday, intent on avoiding any further collapses like the one at the Apollo Theater, where a falling ceiling injured more than 80 people watching a play in the packed house.

title: Ally in $98 Million Settlement on Bias in Auto Loans
description: Ally Financial agreed on Friday to pay $98 million to settle accusations that it discriminated against minority borrowers who were charged more than white customers for auto loans by car dealers.

title: Nigella Lawson Assistants Found Not Guilty of Fraud
description: LONDON  Two Italians sisters who spent more than a million dollars on the celebrity chef Nigella Lawsons credit cards were acquitted of fraud charges Friday by a London jury.

title: Dancing Our Way to a Holiday Break
description: The Academy has started the promotional reel for its March 2 telecast in a major way, with the host Ellen DeGeneres dancing down the street, trailed by a crowd of men and women clad in tuxedos. The trailer, released on Thursday and scheduled to play in theaters next month, was conceived and directed by Paul Feig, the Bridesmaids and Heat filmmaker, and set to new music by Fitz and the Tantrums. The dancer and choreographer Stephen (tWitch) Boss, a judge on the TV show So You Think You Can Dance, was responsible for the moves in the video.

title: Studios Unfazed by Colossal Wrecks
description: For Hollywood film studios, 2013 is shaping up as the year of the flop, as the public radio host Brian Lehrer described it on the air in August.

title: Robots Strut (Or Trot) Their Stuff In Florida Competition
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  My hotel clerk asked me if I was part of the robot thing.

title: Tardy Taper Thoughts
description: Not dead yet, in case youre wondering  just busy with preparations for family travel, and then with travel itself; this post was written during a layover.

title: Special News Quiz | Farewell, 2013
description: The Year in Rap, from Flocabulary.

title: Jazz Deal for Gentium Shows Benefits of Inversions
description: In 2011, Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a California-based drug maker, acquired Azur Pharma, a small rival based in Ireland.

title: Their Chart-Toppers Are Each Other
description: In August 2011, Meghan Milewski was sitting in a bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, when she got a text from Sameer Naseem, one of her best friends. He said, We have to meet up  I have a present for you, she said.

title: 3 More Indicted in Silk Road Online Black Market Case
description: Updated, 6:38 p.m. | New reporting about the Silk Road defendants has been added.

title: Its Early to Bed as Knicks Battle a Matinee Curse
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Noon games on weekends are a rarity for the Knicks. This season, they have also been a disaster. When the Knicks played the San Antonio Spurs on Nov. 10 at that early starting time, they lost by 31 points. When they tried again a month later against the Boston Celtics, they lost by 41.

title: Daughter Seeks Freedom for Jailed Ukraine Leader
description: KIEV, Ukraine  As Russias best-known political prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, arrived in Germany on Friday at the end of a whirlwind 24-hour passage to freedom, the daughter of Ukraines most prominent political prisoner urged the president here to follow in the footsteps of the Russian president and set her mother free.

title: The Gun Report: December 20, 2013
description: Two decades ago, Kenzo Dix, 15, a high school freshman in Northern California, was at the house of a friend, who was showing off his fathers semi-automatic Beretta pistol. The child, who had been shooting with his father, unloaded the full magazine, inserted an empty magazine and pulled the trigger, not knowing there was still a bullet in the chamber. The bullet went through Kenzos shoulder and into his heart. The young basketball player and graffiti artist was killed.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Spain; British Columbia; Utah
description: Canary Islands International Music Festival, Spain

title: Microfoundations and the Parting of the Waters
description: The blogospheric debate about microfoundations, saltwater/freshwater and all that has, I think, been illuminating. Among other things its serving almost as an oral history of What Really Happened  minus the oral part, but not mediated by the usual slowness and overthinking of formal publication.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Behind the Music
description: This week, Alan Light and David Leonhardt.

title: Man With a Thorn in His Side
description: Readers predisposed to dislike Morrissey could respond to his Autobiography with the same barb Vladimir slings at Estragon in Waiting for Godot: No one ever suffers but you.

title: Book Review Podcast: Behind the Music
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Alan Light reviews four new memoirs by famous musicians, including Simple Dreams, by Linda Ronstadt. Mr. Light writes:

title: Wheelies: The Vezel View Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Missing From Podiums: Women
description: Dinosaur, go back to your cave! the British conductor Sian Edwards said over the phone with a laugh, her eyes audibly rolling.

title: Friday Night Music: London Grammar
description: Yes, I know its only afternoon  but this layover is my only chance to post today. Also, Im behind the curve on this group  theyre already pretty big. And while Im apologizing, maybe I should feature one of their fine original songs instead of a cover. But I fall in love with groups via an entry performance, and this was the one for this band.

title: A Sugar Plum Fairy Tale
description: This time of year, a Sugar Plum Fairy needs to take care of her toes. Do you mind if I sew my point shoes?

title: Obama Discusses N.S.A. Surveillance
description: At a news conference at the White House, the president talked about changes to the National Security Agencys surveillance capabilities.

title: Something About It Says Party!
description: TESTED 2014 Ford Fiesta ST

title: What I Discovered on My Flash Drive
description: The first thing I did with my 2013 Lamborghini Aventador LP 700-4 Roadster, the half-million-dollar beast of a sports car I was recently allowed to possess for five days, was drive it to pick up my daughter from detention. Shed been busted for talking in Biology.

title: Target Customer Information Shows Up on the Black Market
description: The nightmare before Christmas continues for Target.

title: Enduring Virtues Onstage in London
description: Between 1949 and 1976, the Royal Ballet of London was the most frequent foreign ballet company to visit the United States. Beloved for both theatricality and purity of style, it made annual or biennial visits to New York and other American cities. Two of its coast-to-coast tours lasted five months each. New York became its second home; one of its seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House was eight weeks long. Its stars included Margot Fonteyn, Moira Shearer, Beryl Grey, Svetlana Beriosova, Nadia Nerina, Antoinette Sibley, Lynn Seymour, Merle Park and Anthony Dowell, with Rudolf Nureyev its most celebrated guest artist. For many Americans, it was the yardstick by which to judge all other kinds of ballet classicism.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Stumbling, Strategic Steps to Manhood
description: Of all the videos Justin Bieber has been featured in this year, none is likely to leave as deep an impact as the one that surfaced last month of him sleeping comfortably  vulnerably  on a couch in Brazil. That video was filmed by a woman, described in news reports variously as a porn star, a prostitute or a mere party guest, who blows him a kiss at the end of the clip and who went on to tell the press that she and Mr. Bieber had shared a night of sex.

title: A Virtual Alternative to the Hot Pursuit
description: If StarChase, a maker of GPS-tagging systems for police departments, has its way, cable TV stations will soon be looking for new material to fill slow news days. Thats because the Virginia Beach company has developed a device meant to eliminate the high-risk car chases that draw viewers and seem, inevitably, to end in tears.

title: Video: The Mazda CX-9 Has Aged Well
description: Introduced in 2007, the Mazda CX-9 crossover has been refreshed twice, and Ive now reviewed it three times. Some vehicles seem dated after just a few years on the market, but with its most recent Kodo design face-lift, the CX-9 retains a youthful appearance. We should all be so lucky.

title: Afterlife for an X Prize Contender
description: With a background in chemical engineering and his job as an air quality regulator for the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, Kevin Smith might seem an unlikely sort to be spending his free time building a car in a backyard garage. But Mr. Smiths education and experience no doubt contributed to his home-built cars being refined far beyond a typical shade tree effort.

title: A Car Monitor That Also Talks to Facebook
description: Even cars that have reached their teenage years can now enjoy the benefits of social networking. Their ability to stay connected comes with the introduction of Zubie, a plug-in device and service that not only monitors a vehicles condition and location but also lets owners share that information with family and friends.

title: Amid Skepticism, Support for Parts of Health Law
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that while many Americans expressed concern or outright disapproval with how the health care law might affect their family, specific components of the law had strong support.

title: Tricky Business: Defining Authenticity
description: When the Guggenheim Museum sold pieces by Kandinsky, Chagall and Modigliani in the early 1990s to help it buy one of the worlds most important collections of Minimalist and Conceptual art, it knew it was paying not only for hundreds of seminal works but also for a mares nest of problems.

title: Weekend Reading: Skipping the Wall St. Wolf
description: Martin Scorseses film about Jordan Belfort is set join a long list of Wall Street movies that are focused more on frat-boy antics than financial wizardry.

title: Big Ticket | A Place for Everything for $10.16 Million
description: A serene Classic 7 condominium at the Mayfair at 610 Park Avenue that brims with light, thanks to generous northern, southern and eastern exposures, sold for $10.165 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Even When This Music Rocks, It Stays Mindful of Its Roots
description: Viento de Agua OPUS IV

title: Music and Success
description: DOES music make you smarter?

title: Levine and Mahler, Laredo and Mozart
description: During Christmas week, Carnegie Hall is surprisingly active, starting on Sunday afternoon at 3, when the Met Orchestra performs an all-Mahler program conducted by James Levine. The compelling baritone Peter Mattei will be the soloist in Song of a Wayfarer. Then Mr. Levine will lead the teeming, episodic yet inexorable Seventh Symphony, an 80-minute workout for a maestro and orchestra. Then the conductor Jaime Laredo presents two programs with the New York String Orchestra, a group of select young musicians in training. On Tuesday, Christmas Eve, at 7 p.m., he leads Mozarts Overture to Le Nozze di Figaro and Paris Symphony, as well as Mendelssohns Violin Concerto with Bella Hristova as soloist. On Saturday at 8 p.m., the esteemed pianist Leon Fleisher will be heard in Prokofievs Concerto No. 4 for left hand and orchestra, on a program that opens with Elgars Introduction and Allegro and ends with Tchaikovskys Pathtique Symphony. (212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

title: An Indie Rapper, Loud and Proud
description: The indie rapper Le1f (born Khalif Diouf) is an oddball and an empire builder: an openly gay (or as one of his songs puts it, gayngsta) rapper with a degree in dance who also runs a label, Camp & Street. He produced the Das Racist track Combination Pizza Bell and Taco Hut before starting his own busy, prolific career, including two generous free mixtapes. He has a low voice, a startling wardrobe and an ear for sparse but insistent tracks.

title: The Land of Sweets Sheds Its Tutus
description: A dancegoers options are fairly limited this week: Theres The Nutcracker, and then theres The Nutcracker. But two of the seasons most popular renditions couldnt be more different. At Lincoln Center, New York City Ballet soldiers on in its six-week run of George Balanchines classic version, with its pristine dancing and reverence for childhood fantasy. A darker sort of fantasy is playing out at the Minetta Lane Theater, home to Company XIVs burlesque twist on this E. T. A. Hoffmann tale.

title: Cash for Cab Drivers
description: New Yorks incoming mayor, Bill de Blasio has enjoyed strong support from taxicab fleet owners, while the current Taxi Commissioner, David Yassky, has been a strong advocate for taxicab drivers. Perhaps not surprisingly, Mr. de Blasio has made it clear that Mr. Yassky, will be one of the first people out the door comeJanuary 1.

title: A Cappella Contest Makes a Comeback
description: The Voice has paid a lot of bills for NBC, but another good singing competition, The Sing-Off, never became a ratings juggernaut and was apparently dead at the end of its third season in 2011. Then the network had a change of heart. It decided to bring The Sing-Off back this month for a two-week, seven-episode Season 4 and gave its premiere The Voice as a lead-in.

title: Star of the Show? The Art Dealer
description: Trace the history of the finest pieces of postwar art, and many of them lead back to Ileana Sonnabend, the gallery owner and collector, who died in 2007. Andy Warhols Liz #1 (Early Colored Liz), which sold at Sothebys for $18 million last month? Sonnabend. Robert Rauschenbergs 20th-century mixed-media collage Canyon, which the Museum of Modern Art won over the Metropolitan Museum last year? Sonnabend.

title: Loverly Memories of a Director
description: Spend Christmas Day at the Walter Reade Theater revisiting three of the most memorable films directed by George Cukor, whose work is being surveyed through Jan. 7 by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in its series called The Discreet Charm of George Cukor.

title: Obamas Year-End News Conference
description: Before taking questions from reporters, the president delivered an opening statement, saying he firmly believed 2014 could be a breakthrough year for America.

title: Best Marriage Proposals of the Year
description: A look back at the most interesting marriage proposals submitted to the Weddings/Celebrations section of The New York Times in 2013.

title: Obama on Health Care
description: The Timess Jackie Calmes asked the president about his statement that if you like your plan, you can keep it being called the Lie of the Year by PolitiFact.

title: Analyzing the American Express Surcharge Settlement
description: In August 2012, lawyers for merchants won a settlement from MasterCard and Visa, an agreement that on close inspection struck many merchant advocates as not much of a victory.

title: Calculating the Number of Windows in Buildings in Manhattan
description: Q. Like many first-year M.B.A. students, I am preparing to interview for summer internship positions. A typical interviewer may ask a question such as How many windows are there in all the buildings in Manhattan? to test your critical reasoning skills. There are ways to estimate, but Id love to know for sure: Just how many buildings are there on the island of Manhattan, and how many windows do they contain?

title: Trudging Somberly to Their Deaths, as a Lone Soul Mourns
description: At the heart of Megan Kendziors dance Witness is a question: How can we observe atrocities and look away? The production, an exploration of indifference and trauma, was inspired by her research into the Holocaust and her visit to the Auschwitz death camp. Her tools are bodies  15 dancers, to be exact  the plaintive sound of the accordion and many pairs of shoes, which refer to the horrifying room of victims shoes at Auschwitz.

title: Ballads Punctuated by Frenzy
description: The guitarist Mike Stern reached peak combustion at an unlikely point in his first set at the Iridium on Thursday night, while cutting a path from one guileless ballad to the next. He enlisted only his tough-minded drummer, Dennis Chambers, for this excursion, issuing no directive beyond a tempo. In no time they achieved a blues-rock bliss state, goading each other toward notions of strenuous metaphysical abandon.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Nepal.

title: Boasting a Power That Pep Le Pew Would Admire
description: Mr. Stink is a charming holiday fable with an added draw for Downton Abbey fans: the sight of Hugh Bonneville, the distinguished Earl of Grantham in that series, reduced to an almost unrecognizable state of vagrancy in playing the title character.

title: No Space Too Small, No Lease Too Short
description: When Kanye West brought his Yeezus tour to New York last month, he needed somewhere to sell his merchandise. Instead of a concert booth, he opened a pop-up shop at 355 Bowery and sold $35 snapback hats and $20 tote bags.

title: Maria Bello: Partnerships, Love and Conversations, to Be Continued
description: Why now?

title: The World at Her Fingertips
description: When Natalie Massenet ascended the stairs of the Carnegie Hall stage a month ago to accept a Woman of the Year trophy from Glamour magazine, she outdid Jennifer Lawrence at the 2013 Oscars ceremony, nearly tripping on her Alessandra Rich white lace gown (soon available for upward of $3,000 at Net-a-Porter, the online luxury retailer she founded)before impaling the hem with her high-heeled sandals.

title: The High Priest of Horology
description: Jay Z asked him to pick out a watch for his two Carnegie Hall concerts last year (he wore a Jaeger-LeCoultre Reverso).

title: Climate Scientists, Then and Now, Espousing Responsible Advocacy
description: Ive long appreciated Gavin A. Schmidts approach to doing and communicating climate science. Schmidt, deputy director of NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies, has endured many slings and arrows, not to mention hacks and legal tangles, in building RealClimate.org into what Ive called a vital online touchstone for anyone trying to understand research on the human influence on the planets thermostat.

title: Ho, Ho, Ho? Oh, No, No, No!
description: We skitter, we dodge. My boyfriend and I will be flying to India on Christmas Day. Jetting off on Santas Judgment Day is not unusual for me; Im among that tiny percentage of the population who hears Santas helpers and thinks skycaps. Part of my seasonal wanderlust lies in the belief that a Christmas celebrated by two adults and no children can be eerily quiet, a Beckett play performed in a canyon on the moon. But the larger part lies in my conviction that the most beautiful and tinselly bauble to be found on Dec. 25 is reduced airfare.

title: Federal Judge Rules That Same-Sex Marriage Is Legal in Utah
description: Salt Lake County began issuing marriage licenses to jubilant same-sex couples on Friday, hours after a federal judge ruled that Utahs amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the United States Constitution.

title: Who Will Keep Financial Reform Going?
description: In late November, nine Democratic senators sent President Obama a letter about a vacancy on the five-member Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency charged under the Dodd-Frank law with regulating most of the multi-trillion dollar market in derivatives.

title: For Millennials, a Generational Divide
description: You know them when you see them. They are tapping on their smartphones, strolling into work late and amassing Instagram followers faster than a twerking cat. They complain. They disrupt stuff. They simultaneously (and somewhat improbably) like both Kanye West and Kenny Chesney.

title: Mr. Obamas Disappointing Response
description: By the time President Obama gave his news conference on Friday, there was really only one course to take on surveillance policy from an ethical, moral, constitutional and even political point of view. And that was to embrace the recommendations of his handpicked panel on government spying  and bills pending in Congress  to end the obvious excesses. He could have started by suspending the constitutionally questionable (and evidently pointless) collection of data on every phone call and email that Americans make.

title: Uh-Oh: George Clooney Is Drooling Again
description: When Heather Allard, an entrepreneur from Pawtucket, R.I., saw the dog with the red bow tie on the Internet, she had to have him. It was partly the mixed boxers commanding jaw and the steadiness of his eyes, but it was mostly his name: James Earl Jones.

title: One Mushroom Ragot, Five Meals
description: I have never been a gravy fan, but I am a fan of what I call Mushroom Ragot Gravy, which is not a gravy at all but a mushroom ragot, or stew. I always make too much. I double the recipe if we are going to be a dozen people, which we usually are during holiday gatherings, even though I know that nobody will have enough room on their plates for more than a spoonful.

title: Many Arms and Many Splendors
description: The pace at Octopus Garden, a Brooklyn store, turns frenzied before Christmas Eve when Italian-Americans celebrating the Feast of Seven Fishes crave octopus, cuttlefish and calamari.

title: A Treasure House of Shifting Aspirations
description: SAN MARINO, Calif.  What does a 15th-century illuminated manuscript of The Canterbury Tales have in common with an Old Mission Brand label from a crate of oranges? What is the connection between the novelist Thackerays 1853 drawing of a black girl in South Carolina and plantings meant to echo the famed Chinese gardens of Suzhou? What could possibly connect 19th-century light bulbs and Gainsboroughs much-loved painting Blue Boy?

title: Red Carpet Watch: Judi Denchs Style
description: Ms. Dench favors caftan style looks on the red carpet.

title: Weighing Health Plans: The Devilish Details
description: On the way home from a bar in the wee hours of the morning, Branden Eastwood, 29, managed to break his ankle stepping into a cab. He wasnt insured, so it became an expensive night out: He received $42,000 in medical bills from a Georgetown hospital.

title: Octopus Garden Prepares for Feast of Seven Fishes
description: Most times of the year, no one can be seen in Octopus Garden save the workers in the back trimming squid beaks or keeping an eye on the octopus-washing machines. Vincent Cutrone, the owner of the store (hidden off Avenue U in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and marked with a sign made of stick-on letters from the hardware store), often is not at the counter. When the rare walk-in customer appears, his staff just hollers to him in the office.

title: Agustin Madala Wins the Goren Trophy
description: The Goren Trophy is awarded to the player who wins the most masterpoints during the Fall North American Championships. This years winner was Agustin Madala, who hails from Argentina but represents Italy. He amassed 402.22 points, 83.32 more than Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.

title: Survival Goes to Extremes
description: A former Navy SEAL, Jake Zweig got his start on reality TV as a small-minded loudmouth on the third season of Top Shot, the underappreciated marksmanship competition show on the History Channel. He was a talented shooter, but also petty and sulky and disruptive; his elimination came as a relief.

title: Telecom Italia Shareholders Reject Bid to Remove Board
description: Shareholders in Telecom Italia on Friday voted against a proposal to remove its board in a battle over the companys future. But a sizable percentage of votes supported the dissidents plan.

title: Google Bus Vandalized During Protest
description: Activists blocked three buses carrying Bay Area tech workers to their Silicon Valley jobs on Friday, breaking a window of one of the vehicles. It was the second demonstration this month targeting the buses, which are rapidly becoming a symbol of the surging animosity between the tech world and everyone else in the Bay Area.

title: Putting on the Blintz
description: The fabulously feline chanteuse Eartha Kitt inspired these blintzes. In an otherwise insipid song called Mink, Schmink, recorded in the 1950s, she sings about how wealth and riches dont mean a thing if you havent got love, rhyming princes, schminces with caviar and chicken blintzes.

title: Yemen Deaths Test Claims of New Drone Policy

title: New Center, but Woes at Historic Site
description: The Weeksville Heritage Center in Crown Heights in Brooklyn started out operating from a cluster of small wood-frame houses, the remnants of a free black community established in 1838. The organization has preserved those three houses, along with documents and artifacts. Now, a new 23,000-square-foot, $34 million building just yards from the houses presents a chance for Weeksville to create a national showcase for black history and culture.

title: NASA Solves Helmet Leak With Makeshift Snorkels
description: NASA, in preparation for a spacewalk on Saturday, has devised makeshift snorkels that would allow an astronaut in a spacesuit to continue breathing even if a sudden water leak should fill the helmet, as happened to an Italian astronaut who almost drowned in July.

title: Bill Cunningham | Red and White All Over

Private homes and spectacular store windows at stalwarts like Lord & Taylor, Bergdorf Goodman, Tiffanys and Bloomingdales turned often-harsh streets into a winter wonderland.

description: Apparently these are cropping up all over the place. This one is near Washington, D.C.s Union Station. Email your own to bittmanstuff@gmail.com.

description: The Olympic torch has begun its journey from Moscow to Sochi, and its been anything but a smooth one. Along the record-breaking 40,389-mile route, the torch has had its fair share of mishaps.

description: A major banking regulator moved on Friday to curb a type of financial maneuver that banks can exploit to make themselves look stronger than they actually are.

title: A Favor Economy in Which Kind Acts Come With Expected Reciprocity
description: Some years ago, I had a friend who moved to New York with various aspirations, and until they were fulfilled he supported himself working at a restaurant. The place was cultish and bohemian  artists had started it  and interesting people worked there. Eventually my friend got to know the daughter of a famous actor there. On various occasions, he ate out with this woman and her father, noticing that when they did, the bill rarely arrived. This led my friend to one of his most astute and enduring observations about New York: Only rich people eat for free.

description: Over the past year, the Obama administration has made a series of major changes to the health care law, many in response to the troubled rollout of Healthcare.gov.

It was broken and burned-looking, a little piece of garbage, but it was also like a postcard from the 1980s that had gotten lost.

title: For a Mayor on His Way Out, a Subway Station on Its Way In
description: For years, Michael R. Bloomberg has been a subway rider of singular distinction: a mayor who often took the train to work, as common New Yorkers do, albeit after a chauffeured drive from his townhouse to an express stop a mile away.

title: Israel: Palestinian Killed Near Border
description: Israeli forces on Friday fatally shot a Palestinian man who approached the border fence separating Gaza from Israel and wounded five others at several points along the fence, Palestinian medical officials said. The Israeli military said that Palestinians had thrown rocks at soldiers near the fence and fired a mortar shell into Israel. Ouda Hamad, 22, was the third Palestinian to be killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers this week. On Wednesday and Thursday, Israeli forces in the West Bank killed two Palestinians, one during arrest raids in the Jenin refugee camp and one in Qalqilya. The military said the man killed in Qalqilya had fired on the soldiers. A spokesman for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, condemned the West Bank killings as a dangerous Israeli escalation meant to undermine peace negotiations.

title: China: Tibetan Sets Himself on Fire
description: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China died after setting fire to himself on Thursday afternoon, according to two Tibet advocacy groups based outside China. The monk, Tsultrim Gyatso, was the 125th person inside a Tibetan area of China to commit self-immolation as an act of protest since 2009, according to Kate Saunders, a spokeswoman for the International Campaign for Tibet. Another group, Free Tibet, put the total at 123, with 27 this year. The latest protest took place in a town that Tibetans call Amchok, in the Chinese province of Gansu.

title: Murray Hill Churchs Neighbors Would Prefer to Look at the Clock
description: The Christmas season, with its silver bells, silent nights and packed pews, might not be the most opportune time to take issue with your local Catholic church. But a group of neighbors of the Church of Our Saviour in Midtown Manhattan are doing just that, complaining that  of all things  the incessant ringing of church bells has produced a heavy helping of bad cheer.

title: Youkilis Joins Star Pitchers Team in Japan
description: Whether the Japanese star Masahiro Tanaka stays with the Rakuten Golden Eagles for the 2014 season or pitches in the United States remains unclear. But one established major leaguer has decided to leave the majors and join Rakuten, no matter where Tanaka ends up.

title: Radio Stations Find Ratings Rocket Fuel in Switch to Christmas Format
description: Thanksgiving is over  the in-laws are gone  and Christmas is not yet here. Its a cold weekend day, not much happening, and you head to the strip mall. Flat-screens beckon, Chromebooks too, and assorted pads, pods and tablets. You turn on the radio, find your trusty Lite-FM station, and settle in for some Elton, Celine, Shania and Mariah.

title: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Followed by a Firing and an Apology
description: Updated, 12 p.m. A message about race and AIDS in Africa posted on the Twitter account of a Manhattan public relations executive at an Internet media giant on Friday caused a global outcry on Twitter and around the web. The executive apologized on Sunday after she was fired on Saturday.

title: Chocolate Prices Soar as Appetites Get Bigger
description: GENEVA  Chocolaterie Pascot, a small laboratoire, or factory, in the Carouge district here, was a hive of activity on a recent morning. The team was scrambling to fill the last orders for Christmas.

title: Senate Wraps Up Briskly After a Tumultuous Year
description: WASHINGTON  The final day of the Senates 2013 session ended on an anticlimactic note on Friday as senators pressed the pause button on the bickering that had kept the chamber nearly paralyzed this year.

title: In Apology, and a Sale, Target Tries to Appease
description: Scrambling to tamp down consumer outrage over the theft of credit and debit card data from more than 40 million of its customers, Target announced on Friday that it would offer a 10 percent discount on purchases inside its stores on Saturday and Sunday  the final shopping weekend of the holiday season.

title: Having a Servant Is Not a Right
description: AT the heart of the fracas surrounding the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York who promised to pay her housekeeper $9.75 per hour, in compliance with United States labor rules, but instead paid her $3.31 per hour, is Indias dirty secret: One segment of the Indian population routinely exploits another, and the countrys labor laws allow gross mistreatment of domestic workers.

description: The beige buildings collectively known as Industry City form narrow cobblestone canyons perpendicular to the Sunset Park waterfront. The loud roar of vehicles speeding down the nearby Gowanus Expressway gives way toward the west to the slow rumble of trucks creeping across the uneven streets.

title: Libya Militias Fleeing Cities, Leaving Chaos
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  For the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011, the independent militias that dominated Libyas biggest cities and sometimes cowed the central government have fled from the streets, chased away by a combination of civilian protesters and armed groups.

title: Revitalizing Our Forests
description: THIS Christmas season, I am roasting chestnuts by the fire. American chestnuts, to be exact. These nuts, once widespread, were almost wiped out by a fungal blight. For a century, most of the chestnuts we eat, like the sweet Castanea sativa variety, have been imported from Europe and Asia.

description: Three former aides to an upstate New York assemblyman have accused him of sexual harassment, saying he repeatedly made sexually explicit comments in their presence and offered invitations to share a hotel room with him.

description: A 16-year-old girl was killed and two women were critically injured in a fire that engulfed the two upper floors of their three-story home in Brooklyn early Friday morning, officials said.

title: John Bell Hoods Leg
description: It happened so fast. As Maj. Gen. John Bell Hood of the Confederacy led his soldiers into action at the battle of Chickamauga on Sept. 20, 1863, a Mini ball struck his right leg; later that day his leg was amputated four inches below the hip. Although such operations resulted in an 80 percent casualty rate throughout the Civil War, Hood survived, and traveled with his damaged appendage to the residence of the Little family, 15 miles away from the battlefield.

title: Tom Cruise Settles Defamation Lawsuit Against Publisher
description: LOS ANGELES  Tom Cruise has settled his prominent lawsuit against the publisher of In Touch and Life & Style magazines, his lawyer said.

description: WASHINGTON  With his appointment of a seasoned Senate free-trader as his new ambassador to Beijing, President Obama has chosen an emissary who faithfully reflects his priorities with China, which have tended to emphasize jobs and other economic issues.

description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  The robot gently grabbed the door handle and pulled it open. But before it could shuffle through the frame, it lost its grip and the spring-loaded door slammed shut.

description: At Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, the pop singer Ruslana Lyzhychko keeps demonstrators upbeat and energized in freezing temperatures every night.

description: The budget deal that Congress approved and sent to President Obama on Wednesday may bring some relief to agencies burdened by sequester cuts all year, but it does nothing to bring the two political parties closer together. Republicans immediately reverted to their obstructionist agenda, making it clear that the budget compromise with Democrats was a brief aberration.

title: One-Handed Basketball Player Gets a Shot With Florida
description: MILTON, Ga.  A referees whistle halted play during a recent game at Milton High, a school situated among horse farms in an affluent area north of Atlanta. A foul had been called, leaving the culprits coach mystified.

title: Ned Vizzini, 32, Dies; Wrote Teenage Novels
description: Ned Vizzini, a precocious and highly praised writer of popular young-adult novels that often dealt with themes of teenage anxiety and depression  and still made readers laugh  died on Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 32.

title: Bangladeshi Workers Long Wait
description: It has been nearly eight months since the collapse of a building in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment factory workers and left many others with grave injuries. But most of those victims and their families have yet to receive adequate financial help or medical care.

title: S.N.L. Stops Joking About Casting Problems
description: After coming under intense criticism for its lack of onstage diversity, Saturday Night Live is poised to hire its first black female cast member since Maya Rudolph left the show in 2007. Lorne Michaels, the executive producer, told The New York Times that S.N.L. recently held special auditions and that one or two black women would most likely join the cast in January  a good thing for notions of balance, of course, but also for the shows relevance.

title: Britain: Judge Rejects Libyans Rendition Case
description: A Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, cannot pursue in a British court his well founded claim that he was unlawfully abducted in 2004 in a joint MI6-C.I.A. operation, and later tortured, because the case involved other countries and could damage Britains relations with the United States, a British high court judge ruled Friday. The judge, Peregrine Simon, ruled, with hesitation, that Mr. Belhaj could not sue MI6, the foreign intelligence service, and a former foreign secretary, Jack Straw, even though parliamentary oversight and police investigations were not adequate substitutes for a decision by a court. He dismissed the case, he said, because American, as well as British, officials were involved in the rendition of Mr. Belhaj and his pregnant wife to Libya in 2004 and agreed with the British government that a case in open court would harm its relations with Washington. Mr. Belhaj will appeal.

title: Law Will Tighten Oversight of Special Education Providers
description: Responding to reports of fraud and abuse, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo this week signed into law a bill to strengthen oversight of New York States preschool programs for disabled children.

description: Theyre frustrated. Everybody was thinking that Obamacare was going to come in with more affordable rates. Well, theyre not more affordable.

title: Plan Sought to Protect Food Supply From Terrorism
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a ruleon Fridayto require major food producers to develop a plan to prevent intentional attempts to contaminate the food supply. The agency said it favored the rule, not because such a criminal act is likely, but as an extra precaution. Under the rule, open to public comment until the end of March, companies would need plans to address vulnerabilities in production processes, particularly to acts of terrorism. They would have one to three years to comply.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: The beginning of the end for the Federal Reserves stimulus program, a big investment by General Motors and the theft of credit card data by hackers.

title: Beltran Is Back in New York, With Nothing to Prove
description: A second chance for what? Carlos Beltran said on Friday, and on paper he sounds irritated. But in person, with a small group of writers in a club at Yankee Stadium, he did not seem that way. Beltran was in a fine mood, actually, having just formalized his three-year, $45 million contract with the Yankees.

title: Janet D. Rowley, Who Discovered Cancer Can Be Genetic, Dies at 88
description: Dr. Janet D. Rowley, a physician who four decades ago became the first person to show a conclusive link between certain genetic abnormalities and certain cancers, died on Tuesday at her home in Chicago. She was 88.

title: U.S.C. Coach May Have Brought Some Baggage With Him
description: LOS ANGELES  The University of Southern California football team has spent its recent days being greeted by Elvis, entertained by acrobatic dancers and preparing for Saturdays Las Vegas Bowl against Fresno State. But Steve Sarkisian, the teams newly hired coach, has a more pressing concern: hoping that what happens in Seattle stays in Seattle.

title: In Newark, a Final Meeting, Perhaps, for Two Ageless Stars
description: NEWARK  The Finnish Flash rolled through New Jersey one last time on Friday, and as with all the stops on Teemu Selannes N.H.L. farewell tour, it was a special occasion. The game between the Anaheim Ducks and the Devils was the last regular-season appearance for Selanne, 43, in the metropolitan area and, almost certainly, the last time he would play in the N.H.L. against Jaromir Jagr, 41, the leagues other ageless wonder.

title: Sudden Stop in Momentum as Rangers Woes Continue
description: The Rangers, eagerly seeking a burst of home ice energy after encouraging efforts in their previous two games, lost a befuddling contest to the Islanders, 5-3, on Friday at Madison Square Garden.

title: More Stones Crop Up on Nets Rocky Road
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Nets entered the season talking up their collective size as one of their greatest strengths. But as the season continues, the team keeps shrinking in the face of even the smallest challenges.

title: Early Bowl Games to Watch
description: Who says all the good bowl games are in January? Bowl season has already started, and while the AdvoCare V100 Bowl on Dec. 31 may not have the cachet of the Rose Bowl, it will feature two of the best running backs in the nation. And that is just one of the intriguing matchups to watch before the end of 2013. This may be your last chance to see quarterbacks Teddy Bridgewater, Johnny Manziel and Jordan Lynch before they start playing on Sundays.

title: EuroVision Star Becomes Voice of Protest
description: When Ukrainian security forces stormed Kievs central square on Dec. 11, the pop singer Ruslana was on stage and attempting to defuse the situation. I kept a quiet confidence in myself, and I believe that my voice kept them calm, she said recently. Ruslana, the 2004 winner of the EuroVision Song Contest, has been a constant presence at Independence Square, also known as Maidan, since demonstrators gathered there in late November to protest the governments decision to postpone an economic agreement with the European Union. She is on stage every night from midnight until sunrise, keeping thousands of demonstrators upbeat and energized in freezing temperatures. Many protesters consider her to be one of the leaders of the movement, but she vehemently disagrees. We said that one cannot lead Maidan, one can only join Maidan, she said.

title: Kelly Clark, Lawyer Who Won Boy Scouts Abuse Case, Dies at 56
description: Kelly Clark, a lawyer whose successful child molestation lawsuit against the Boy Scouts of America in Oregon led to the release of a trove of documents containing thousands of accusations of sexual abuse, died on Tuesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 56.

Mr. Heffner helped create what became Thirteen WNET, New York Citys public station, and was its first general manager.

title: Easy Holiday Entertaining
description: For holiday entertaining this close to Christmas, it is wise to keep things easy in order to remain festive and in good cheer. Greeting guests at the front door with a glass of wine in hand both sets the tone for a casual event and is more enjoyable than running yourself ragged in the kitchen. This year, my husband and I are entertaining a dozen friends and family on Christmas Eve in our small Welsh hillside cottage, where there is no electricity. Its not quite as heathen as it sounds, and what could be more Christmassy than a dwelling lit by candles and warmed by open fires?

Rana doesnt blay football, he wrote on a whiteboard, looking down at his notebook before slowly composing each letter, but he riding story.

My roommate waitressed at a restaurant where she made huge tips, but I didnt have the bone structure or hair texture to be hired somewhere like that. Instead, I waited outside the Village Voice offices. It was the late 90s, and every Wednesday when the paper came out, a line of people stretched down the sidewalk to get a first look at the classified ads. Thats how different things were before the Internet. Back then, people would unbend their legs and assume a vertical position, known as standing.

There was Fred Abrahams, 77, a skier who had surgery on both ankles for arthritis  one in New York for more than $200,000 and one in New Hampshire for less than $40,000. There was Matthew Landman, 41, billed more than $100,000 for antivenin administered in an E.R. after a small rattlesnake bite. But the news I received from my husband as I walked through the door was devastating. The girls had been exploring in the attic  a space Id thought was the perfect hiding place for Santas gifts. title: Reflections on the Killing of Chico Mendes 25 Years Ago
description: Its hard for me to believe that its been 25 years since a cattle rancher ordered his son to shoot Chico Mendes, a rubber tapper and unionist who had become an effective international campaigner for sustainable use of the Amazon rain forest. I spent the year following Mendess assassination piecing together The Burning Season, my book on his life, death and influence. But I havent been back to that corner of the Amazon since the trial of his murderers in 1990. The Guardian has published an excellent article assessing his legacy. Linda Rabben, an anthropologist and activist focused on human rights and the environment, is the lead organizer of a conference on Mendes and grassroots environmentalism next spring. She sent this short Your Dot contribution on Mendes:

title: In Blow to Leadership of 11 Revolt, Egypt Activists Are Given 3 Years in Prison
description: CAIRO  Three activists who played central roles in the uprising against former President Hosni Mubarak were convicted on Sunday of participating in recent protests and sentenced to three years in prison, raising fears that the new government was seeking revenge against opponents of Egypts old order.

title: Vienna Philharmonic Revokes Nazi Honors
description: The Vienna Philharmonic has revoked honors it bestowed on six notable Nazi officials during Hitlers reign in Austria and Germany. The action was taken at the annual meeting of members of the orchestra, which is self-governing, on Oct. 23.

title: For Liverpool Fans, There Is Plenty to Cheer
description: LONDON  England upholds some mighty odd soccer traditions around Christmas.

title: Hobbit Edges Out Anchorman 2 at Box Office
description: A scorched-earth ad campaign delivered solid ticket sales for Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues over the weekend, while two Oscar hopefuls had mixed results in wider release, computer-generated dinosaurs flopped and a Bollywood import arrived in Imax and broke records. But no newcomer was strong enough to overtake The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (Warner Brothers), which repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America by selling about $31.5 million in tickets at 3,928 locations, for a two-week domestic total of $127.5 million.

title: State Official Appointed by de Blasio as Leader of Child Welfare Agency
description: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio on Sunday named a top state social services official to serve as his child welfare commissioner, installing an experienced leader atop an agency with a history of failing the children it serves and bedeviling mayors who try to reform it.

title: A Woodstock for Robots
description: At the Robotics Challenge 2013 Trials in Homestead, Fla., teams that built rescue robots competed for a chance at a $2 million prize.

title: A Gift That Keeps on Giving  to Strumming Musicians
description: Heres an unsolicited, last-minute, pre-Christmas plug for the Pick Punch, a device my 15-year-old son gave me for my last birthday that turns old credit cards or other plastic sheet  in this case a stray hotel key  into stringed instrument picks.

title: Man Threw Son, 3, From High-Rise Before Jumping to His Death, Police Say
description: A Brooklyn man who had recently separated from his wife and was sharing custody of their 3-year-old son threw the boy from the roof of a 52-story Manhattan high-rise on Sunday afternoon before jumping to his death moments later, the police said.

title: Combating Criminals With Flash
description: The hero of Dhoom 3 isnt Indias top cop, Jai Dixit, whos summoned to Chicago from Mumbai to catch a thief. Jai (Abhishek Bachchan) may be the seriess franchise player, but in each Dhoom film, a heroic guest villain has eclipsed him.

title: Bangladeshi Factory Owners Charged in Fire That Killed 112
description: NEW DELHI  The police in Bangladesh charged the owners of a garment factory and 11 of their employees with culpable homicide in the deaths of 112 workers in a fire last year that came to symbolize the appalling working conditions in the countrys dominant textile industry.

title: Debating the N.S.A.s Data Collection, and a Panels Findings
description: Washington  A member of President Obamas advisory committee on signals intelligence, the panel that recommended major restrictions on the National Security Agencys data collection, on Sunday countered the notion that the panel had found no value in the agencys activities.

title: In Our Pages: December 23
description: 1938: Firemen Battle To Save Invalides Monument Roof

title: A Nureyev Ballet, With a Hint of Ambivalence, Takes Its Time
description: PARIS  Rudolf Nureyevs The Sleeping Beauty, currently being performed by the Paris Opera Ballet, is ornate, ceremonious and very, very long. It also hints at Nureyevs ambivalence toward the Russia he left behind when he defected to the West in 1961 at 23 while on tour with the Kirov Ballet.

title: After the Deluge, the Restoration
description: More than most Renaissance artists, Giorgio Vasari knew the perilous existence of human creations. In The Lives of the Artists, the chronicle of the great quattrocento painters and sculptors for which he is best known, he describes how a stone bench, hurled off a parapet by an anti-Medici mob in Florence in 1527, chanced, as Fortune would have it, to land on Michelangelos David, breaking one of its arms into three pieces.

title: Haunted by Holiday Shows Past
description: The spurious war on Christmas bemoaned on Fox News notwithstanding, a war really has been going on in recent years at the holidays: a war between traditional television Christmas specials and that aggressive musical interloper, the singing-competition finale. Its a mismatch. With December now dominated by singing competitions  The X Factor and The Voice wrapped up last week; The Sing-Off ends Monday night  the old-fashioned variety-show-style Christmas special feels as if it could go extinct any year now.

title: You Cant Save Them All
description: You dont play video games, but youre curious about them. How should you get started? Thats a question that Steve Gaynor, the writer and director of the independent game Gone Home, has taken to asking guests on his podcast (Tone Control: Conversations with Video Game Developers): What would they recommend to someone who is entirely new to the medium?

title: Strategy Remains Elusive for Ukraine Opposition
description: KIEV, Ukraine  One of the most effective, and affecting, sights on Maidan, the independence square that antigovernment protesters have made theirs for the past month, is a simple wall of wooden blocks. There are hundreds, in jagged formation, each with the name of a village, town or city etched in black.

title: Jets Ride Ryans Power of Persuasion to Victory Over Browns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rex Ryan stamped. He shouted. He cursed and snarled and appealed, releasing a reservoir of fury on a man who was in position to make a very important decision. When he had finished pleading, Ryan had what he wanted.

title: Book Theft in Italy, With a Hint of Politics
description: MILAN  For years, the books kept coming. A precious edition by Thomas More. Leather-bound volumes from the Italian Renaissance. Some stolen from the Baroque-era Girolamini Library in Naples, given as gifts to an influential longtime consigliere to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Make Music Winter
description: The celebration in Prospect Park was marked by a participatory performance and unseasonably warm weather.

title: A Romp, Meant to Ring in the Cold, Feels Like Spring
description: Last year, Make Music Winter, the annual solstice celebration of participatory performance, took place with an emphasis on its final word. I joined in Winterize, the baritone Christopher Dylan Herberts peripatetic outdoor version of Schuberts Winterreise, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on a raw, gray afternoon as chilly as the melancholy score.

title: Reaching for Souls High Ground
description: Classic soul singing is, among countless other things, the art of the interjection. Whoo! Mmmmm. Ohhhhhh. HahahaHA! Owww. Yeah, yeah! Am I lying? Can I take my time? Listen to me! Do you feel it? Used right, those interjections can be percussion, comedy, respiration, tension, release and more. Bobby Womack, 69, used them all at City Winery on Friday night, wearing a red leather suit, a red hat and red sunglasses as he started a three-night stand.

title: Q. and A.: U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker on China Trade Talks
description: Since a key Communist Party conference issued a plan in November to advance market reforms, a series of foreign envoys have rolled through China seeking to capitalize on some of its more business-friendly initiatives. Top American trade officials took the same tack during talks in Beijing last week, but made clear afterward that it would take time for United States businesses to reap dividends from the conference, known as the Third Plenum.

title: China Deal Gives Apple Big Market to Court
description: Just about any way you slice it, 763 million customers is a huge potential pie.

title: An Affection for Books, Dogs, One Tough Nun and, Yes, a Husband
description: The best advertisement for Ann Patchetts new collection of nonfiction is anything else Ms. Patchett has written. Her novels (Bel Canto remains the most exquisite), memoir about a friend (Truth & Beauty) and assorted speeches and essays all share unusual frankness and drawing power. Ms. Patchetts style is not overly confessional, but it is beguiling in ways that make her sound like someone youd want to know. Her new book, This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage, reinforces the impression of an uncommonly kind person who is not above self-interest but loves books, her grandmother, the toughest nun who taught her in grade school, her husband and her darling dog.

title: Enough Anxiety to Fill Two Books
description: WASHINGTON  There are countless American families braving the usual anxieties of the holiday season: frantic shopping, exasperating travel and tedious relatives.

title: Monaco Triumphs at Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
description: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the premier event at the Fall North American Championships last month in Phoenix, was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.; and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

title: Passengers on Bus Near Tel Aviv Flee Just Before a Bomb Explodes
description: JERUSALEM  A bomb exploded on a bus in Bat Yam near Tel Aviv on Sunday minutes after the passengers were asked to get off, preventing casualties. The police said that initial evidence pointed to an attempted terrorist attack, presumably by Palestinian militants, the first of this kind in just over a year.

title: Don't Get in Bed With Assad
description: Beirut  One might think that Americas policy toward Syria couldnt get any worse, but the rise of extremists there is generating dangerous thinking in Western capitals. High-level advisers and former officials have recently started to talk about Bashar al-Assad as a lesser evil than whatever comes next; some even see him as a potential partner in fighting jihadi terrorists.

title: The Weight of the Past
description: This column is about Edward Snowden. And the National Football League. And, I suspect, most of the rest of us.

title: Japans Proactive Pacifism
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has approved a plan to strengthen the nations military.

title: Nets, Built to Win Now, May Need to Cut Losses
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It may be futile when one is chased by a shark in deep water to question the decision to have gone swimming in the first place. But regret is a common human experience, and so it is fair to wonder if Billy King is feeling any as his master plan for winning an N.B.A. championship appears to have fractured like the fifth metatarsal in Brook Lopezs right foot.

title: Obama Says Further Action Possible in South Sudan
description: HONOLULU  After an attack on three United States aircraft attempting to evacuate American citizens from South Sudan, President Obama sent a letter Sunday to top congressional leaders in which he said he might take further action to support United States citizens and interests in the contested region.

title: Believe You Me
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  There is nothing better for my solving ego than a Monday Andrea Carla Michaels puzzle, and its not just because its Monday. Its because she, along with her collaborator, Michael Blake, fills her puzzles with wonderful things that they and Will Shortz clue in such a way that my pencil never stops moving until the entire grid is filled. And when its done, I might not remember filling in all of the entries because it was just that smooth, but I know that Ive had a good time. You really cant ask for more than that on a Monday.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 23
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Monday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 23
description: INCOME AND SPENDING On Monday, the Commerce Department will announce the data on personal income and spending in November. Economists on Wall Street are looking for an increase of 0.5 percent for both figures, according to Bloomberg, but a stronger reading would allay fears of weak overall economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2013. Growth is expected to slow substantially from the robust 4.1 percent annual pace recorded in the third quarter, but recent data has been a bit more positive so experts will be watching to see if that continued in November with personal income and spending.

description: CINCINNATI  It has been a long time since a streetcar was just a streetcar here.
