title: Mission Schools Opened World to Africans, but Left an Ambiguous Legacy
description: Of the hundreds of pages in Nelson Mandelas autobiography, Long Walk to Freedom, barely a dozen recount his college education at the University of Fort Hare, established by white Christian missionaries. He spent less than two of his 95 years there. Most obituaries made only a brief mention of that period.Mandela left Fort Hare partway through his studies during a conflict with its leader, a Scottish evangelist named Alexander Kerr, about a student boycott of college elections. At that moment, I saw Dr. Kerr less as a benefactor than as a not-altogether-benign dictator, Mandela wrote in his memoirs. As for himself, a 22-year-old at that point in late 1940, I was in an unpleasant state of limbo.

title: Adding Citrus to Salads and Desserts
description: I always stuff an orange or a tangerine into the toe of my sons Christmas stocking. He is more interested in the chocolate in his stocking and I usually end up eating his orange, but Ill never forego this European tradition that dates from a time when citrus was a rare treat. We in the United States take our oranges and grapefruit for granted year round, but citrus really does have a season  winter  and it is welcome at this time of year, when we need all the vitamin C we can get.

title: Targets Nightmare Goes On: Encrypted PIN Data Stolen
description: After hackers stole credit and debit card records for 40 million Target store customers, the retailer said customers personal identification numbers, or PINs, had not been breached.

title: Where Celebrity Assistants Go When Theyre Losing Their Minds
description: In this past weekends Lives column, Jessica Berger Gross, who worked as Bella Abzugs personal assistant in the late 90s, wrote about finding emotional support in a confidential gathering held by the Association of Celebrity Personal Assistants. Intrigued, we got in touch with one of the associations founders, Rita Tateel, to find out more about the group.

title: Charities That Inspire Kids: The Ronald McDonald House
description: Earlier this month, I asked readers to share stories of charities that had touched and inspired their families and sparked an urge to give in their children. As we head through whats often a week of charitable giving for many and into 2014, well post some of those stories here.The Ronald McDonald House

title: At Long Island Restaurants, Fondue Is Melted Comfort
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, several groups of diners who had come in from the cold could be seen huddling around bubbling pots of cheese fondue at the Village Cheese Shop in Mattituck. Nostalgic and interactive and warming is how the owner of the 13-year-old-shop, Rosemary Dougherty Batcheller, 54, described the appeal of fondue. You linger over it, and it has a festive feeling.

title: Children Need To Take Risks, and Parents Need to Let Them
description: Im haunted by a 3-year-old French girl in a buttercup-yellow dress. Shes a vague remnant from an article I read sometime in the last two to three years about the supreme competence of French children. While her mother chatted with a reporter in the living room, the girl very ably made cupcakes in the kitchen. In the years since I read the article, she periodically appears in my life as a rebuke against too much caution.

title: Tinkering by Beijing
description: The Peoples Bank of China has allowed extremely sharp movements in interbank lending rates, discouraging banks from relying too heavily on short-term borrowing.

title: Markets on Edge as China Moves to Curb Risky Lending
description: HONG KONG  Chinas financial system is in danger of becoming too big to bail out.

title: A Reluctant Bride Conquers Her Fears
description: When Marvin Coote kissed Rachel Skiffer not long after they met at a dance at Harvard, it was just her fourth real kiss  and one of the previous three had come during a game of Truth or Dare.

title: Art Matters | Korakrit Arunanondchai, the Rapping, Body-Painting Free Spirit of the Art World
description: This summer while I was in Thailand, I made a fake road movie with my twin, Korakrit Arunanondchai says. He plays me and I play him; I play a Manchester United fan and he plays, like, a denim painter. We go on a soul-searching journey together.

title: Last Words From a Beirut Bombing Victim
description: Video and social media images of a bomb blast in downtown Beirut were widely shared online, highlighting the first such attack in several years to hit the capitals business district as well as some of the final public remarks and writings of a prominent Lebanese politician who was among the six people killed.

description: Eagles (9-6) at Cowboys (8-7)

title: The Farm-to-Centerpiece Movement
description: Not long ago, Jessica Gigot might have had a hard time designing a seasonal bouquet for her February wedding, even in the coastal Pacific Northwest with a relatively mild climate and long growing season.

title: Serving Comfort Food and Beyond
description: Twofiftytwo Restaurant in Bedminster occupies an Arts and Crafts-style bungalow painted a beautiful deep red and featuring a wide and welcoming front porch. Such innocence hardly prepares you for the elegance of its interior, a room of pale grays and creams with wood veneer tables and foam-green leather banquettes. Only expensive spas project this kind of serenity.

title: What I Love | Jonathan and Faye Kellerman
description: When in New York, the writers Jonathan Kellerman and Faye Kellerman retreat to a pied--terre near the park.

title: Change Would Be Criminal
description: It used to be that when the Los Angeles-based novelist Jonathan Kellerman came to the city that never sleeps, he never slept either. I was here all the time for book tours, for business with my publisher, said Mr. Kellerman, 64, who is married to a fellow best-selling crime writer, Faye Kellerman. I stayed at the best hotels, but they were always noisy and I never got a nights rest.

title: Customizing Trips With a Computer Assist
description: Guidebooks and crowdsourced travel websites compete with advice on where to go. But the new site Trekkel attempts to automate a trip designers job by asking users to rate their interests and itemizing a custom list of recommendations in return.

title: Through the Winter on a Locally Sourced Menu
description: Although chefs at farm-to-table restaurants in Connecticut build their menus around locally sourced ingredients, few match the commitment of Kim Dziubinski, the owner of Seagrass Grill in the Indian Neck neighborhood of Branford. She is making her way through its first winter  it opened in April  with the goal of using only fruits, vegetables, dairy products, meats and poultry that are locally produced and, whenever possible, organic.

title: On Twitter, Documenting an Antarctic Journey and a Countdown to a Rescue
description: A Chinese vessel is battling severe weather and ice jams as it tries to make its way toward a research ship wedged in Antarctic ice, and the ordeal has been documented in social media postings by a professor on the ship, Chris Turney.

title: Book Review Podcast: Writers and the Bottle
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Lawrence Osborne reviews Olivia Laings The Trip to Echo Spring, which chronicles the alcoholism of six American writers: John Cheever, Tennessee Williams, John Berryman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. Mr. Osborne writes:

title: Beyonc Stays on Top
description: Beyoncs new album, released by surprise on iTunes, has held at No. 1 for a second week and has now sold almost a million copies in the United States, even as some retailers refuse to stock it.

title: Lawrence Ulrichs Top 12 of 2013
description: In 2013, the best new models included many stellar sports cars, perhaps signaling that good times are about to roll.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: James G. Cobbs Top 12 of 2013
description: It was a good year for car buyers, as postrecession investments paid off, bringing interesting models to showrooms.

title: When Love Grows Steamy, Dont Use the Ironing Board
description: The phrase saved the worst for last comes to mind.

title: A Condo for Art Collectors
description: Supporters of the High Line, the wildly popular elevated park, are quick to point out that it has catalyzed the redevelopment of West Chelsea. What may get lost in the enthusiasm is the fact that art galleries, too, have provided a major spark, going back to the 1990s, when they first began appearing amid factories in this longtime industrial area.

title: Critics Picks: Recovery Is Paying Off
description: It was the year when Fisker fizzled and Coda collapsed, along with the dreams of several other would-be automakers. Tesla provided endless drama as its chief executive, Elon Musk, swatted at naysayers, state dealer associations and federal regulators, even as the Model S became a trophy car for the affluent and tech-savvy.

title: Tune In, and Turn On the Reading Light
description: Mark Lewisohn never intended to become a Beatles biographer. His interest was mainly in pure research, and his first books were compilations of facts: an annotated listing of all the Beatles concerts (The Beatles Live, 1986); a descriptive catalog of the music, released and unreleased, in EMI archives (The Beatles Recording Sessions: The Official Abbey Road Studio Sessions Notes, 1962-1970, 1988); and a record of the groups radio and television appearances (The Complete Beatles Chronicle, 1992). Around the time his recording sessions book was published, he described the market for Beatles biographies as oversaturated.

title: Ales Not Just for Drinking
description: Gastro pubs have been popping up across Westchester for several years, bringing hundreds of craft beers to diners attention, from light lagers to imperial stouts. Along with interesting food, these gastro pubs will offer 10, sometimes 20 different drafts at a time and dozens of bottled choices, including those from Captain Lawrence, the eight-year-old Elmsford brewery that makes about 15 different brews, and Yonkers Brewing Co., founded in 2010. Peekskill Brewery, an ambitious restaurant in that Hudson River town, even makes its own beer.

title: Distributor Apologizes for Movie Posters Ignoring Chiwetel Ejiofor
description: BIM Distribuzione, the film distribution company that is marketing 12 Years a Slave in Italy, has formally apologized for distributing posters and publicity materials that played down Chiwetel Ejiofor, the black actor who is the films protagonist, while prominently featuring two white supporting actors: Michael Fassbender, who plays a sadistic slave owner, and Brad Pitt, who has a small role as a laborer.

title: Dream Boats
description: The most noteworthy design studies of 2013.

title: India Finds New Methods to Punish U.S. Diplomats
description: NEW DELHI  Indias diplomatic corps, still seething over the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York, continued its tit-for-tat campaign against American diplomats this week, revoking privileges, beginning tax investigations and issuing new consular identity cards that say the card holder can be arrested for serious offenses.

title: Movie Review: 'The Wolf of Wall Street'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Wolf of Wall Street."

title: Movie Review: 'August: Osage County'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "August: Osage County."

title: 'The Secret Life of Walter Mitty'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty."

title: Final Report on Sandy Hook Killings Sheds New Light on Gunmans Isolation
description: Authorities in Connecticut released a final report on Friday outlining the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown on Dec. 14, 2012, providing the most complete account to date for one of the nations most wrenching massacres.

title: At Lloyds, a Bank and Its Boss on the Rebound
description: Antnio Horta-Osrio was eight months into his new job as chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group in 2011, wrestling with a plan to refocus the British lender, when he stopped sleeping.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Westchester five-bedroom home on six acres, a sprawling Fort Lee waterfront condo; and a Nassau contemporary with an artsy two-sided fireplace.

title: Arrest Warrant for Hdiard Owner Is Revoked
description: MOSCOW  A court in Moscow on Friday withdrew an arrest warrant for the Russian banker Sergei Pugachev, the owner of the French luxury food chain Hdiard, a day after the warrants issuance had been prominently reported in the Russian business newspaper Kommersant.

title: A Refusal Stands Strong, 32 Years Later
description: It has been 32 years since Jennifer Holliday unleashed on the world her version of And I Am Telling You Im Not Going, in the original Broadway production of Dreamgirls, and pop-gospel belting hasnt been the same since. Like the sound of thunder rolling off a mountain, its echoes cascading for miles, Ms. Hollidays voice resounded with a power that combined the range of Sarah Vaughan with the fervor of Aretha Franklin. And at Thursdays sensational opening-night show of her debut at 54 Below, Ms. Holliday infused that howl of refusal with the same defiant, fearsome intensity she displayed onstage three decades earlier.

title: Aiming to Reinvent Itself, Panasonic Moves Beyond the Living Room
description: FUJISAWA, Japan  Panasonic used to make televisions, refrigerators and computer monitors in this suburb of Tokyo. Now, six years after closing its factories in Fujisawa, the company is building homes on the site, which is sandwiched between Mount Fuji and the Pacific.

title: A Year of Teasing at Shapes to Come (and Sometimes Just Teasing)
description: As in most years, the international auto salons of 2013 showcased scores of futuristic design studies and fanciful concept cars among their attractions. Some of the vehicles were merely exercises in styling fantasy; others hinted at exciting, mold-breaking production cars to come.

title: Plug In, Turn On, Pass Gas Station
description: When the final figures for 2013 are tabulated, sales of battery-electric and plug-in vehicles in the United States are expected to nearly double 2012s totals, according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association, a trade group based in Washington. Even so, that is fewer than 100,000 vehicles, in a year when the industry is on track to comfortably top 15 million sales.

title: Of Hovercraft, Heroes and Hens
description: We writers enjoy bemoaning that there are no more surprises in the automotive world, but the last 12 months was full of them, from an exhaust note that caused constant double-takes to a Rolls with unexpected avian appeal. And then, of course, there was the hovercraft.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side Co-op with two-bedrooms and a working fireplace; and a Park Slope three-bedroom with an open living and dining room.

title: Sharing a Jazzy Working Holiday
description: The close of the year is a time for many things: cozy reunions, warm nostalgia, extravagant splurges. If youre Wynton Marsalis, artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, its also a time to set up shop in a smallish room and get back to work, as if you had ever stopped.

title: Spain Orders Smaller Price Increase for Electricity
description: MADRID  The Spanish government decreed on Friday that the countrys utilities could charge consumers only 2.3 percent more for their electricity next month after accusing utilities of manipulating a recent auction to win a price increase of 11 percent.

title: Out of the Comfort Zone
description: A disturbing image or a discordant style, or both, might have qualified a work to be included in Rabble-Rousers: Art, Dissent, and Social Commentary at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

title: The Independent Journal Esopus, Still Going Strong After a Decade of Publishing
description: It takes chutzpah to start a print publication these days, and a loose grip on reality to imagine that it could last a decade. But the biannual journal Esopus defied the odds last month when it published its 20th issue, Special Collections, which features work by Matthew Weiner, the creator of Mad Men. Tod Lippy, the magazines affable founder and editor, is a one-man masthead, conceiving and executing every issue with assistance only from interns who get paid in lifetime subscriptions.

title: Spiritual and Prolific, in an Era of Upheaval
description: You can generally depend on Italian Renaissance art for tasteful, traditional Christmas imagery, and Francesco Vanni: Art in Late Renaissance Siena at Yale University Art Gallery delivers plenty of Madonnas, angels and adorable infants. But it also offers a view of European art at a moment of upheaval and of an artist working in the centers of religious power and responding to these changes.

title: A Move Done, Barnes Leader Makes Another
description: PHILADELPHIA  The conflict was often ugly, the lawsuits vicious, the risks fairly pronounced.

title: What the Tipsy Peasant Knew
description: For those who imbibe with abandon on New Years Eve and need soothing relief the day after, soup may be the answer. Some swear by a big bowlful of menudo: spicy Mexican tripe soup topped with chopped raw onion, chiles and a squeeze of lime. Theres Korean hae jang gook, a heady concoction of ox blood, meaty bones, bean sprouts and dried cabbage. The list of possibilities is long. Every nation seems to have a surefire hangover cure to recommend.

title: When Your Life Needs a Do-Over
description: Mastering the Art of Quitting: Why It Matters in Life, Love, and Work, by Peg Streep and Alan Bernstein. Da Capo Lifelong Books, $24.99, 272 pp.

title: Exploring the Science in Football
description: Joshua Padilla dropped back to pass and let the football fly.

title: Robert W. Wilson, Frugal Philanthropist, Dies at 87
description: Robert W. Wilson, a retired hedge-fund founder who became a major philanthropist, donating about $600 million to causes that included environmental conservation, the American Civil Liberties Union and Roman Catholic education (though he was an openly gay atheist), died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: A Spot to Start, or End, the Day
description: Hectors Cafe & Diner has remained relatively unchanged since it opened in 1949.

title: The Year in Fashion
description: No one really talks about fabulous, must-have clothes anymore. Have you noticed? Instead, in 2013, the conversation focused on business deals (which luxury brand would go public next, the further designs of Amazon) and how celebrities faced their baby fat. Still, the year had its ironic moments and left-field surprises, plus a few artists who refused to be complacent.

title: The Year in Fashion
description: Names that stood out: John, Raf, Baz and Marc.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Lebanon, Egypt, Central African Republic and Afghanistan.

title: Melancholy Danes
description: Im going to be visiting Scandinavia next month, so Im doing preliminary homework  and for someone who hasnt been following the region closely, there are surprising developments. Heres real GDP, with the US to give some sense of comparison:

title: Friday Night Music: London Grammar, Hey Now
description: Some readers last week asked for a performance of one of their originals; KEXP delivers a stunner:

title: Flaming Baba au Rhum
description: A baba is traditionally baked with raisins, but Melissa Clark makes hers with chocolate.

title: Flaming Baba au Rhum Earns the Oohs and Aahs
description: Of all the desserts that you could set on fire, you may never have considered the baba au rhum.

title: A Diner Where Worlds Collide
description: Beginning most days at 3 a.m. on a tiny stretch of Washington Street, men in bloodstained aprons muscle open the gates of their meatpacking storefronts and unload dripping carcasses onto waiting trucks. The routine is much the same as it has been for generations, although the meatpackers are now surrounded by designer boutiques and chic lounges.

title: Bridge Deals Online to Learn From and Discuss
description: The Internet has had a profound effect on our lives, primarily for the better.

title: Forecasting the Year Ahead, and Preparing to Be Wrong
description: THIS is the time of year when investment analysts predict what they believe will happen over the next 12 months. That they are invariably wrong about something is a given. Or, to be more charitable, it is a given that events that no one could have foreseen will have caused their deeply researched predictions to be incorrect.

title: A Winter Bouquet, Locally Grown
description: The florist Jennie Love digs through the snow at her urban flower farm in Philadelphia to create a seasonal, organically grown bridal bouquet out of unusual materials.

title: Leaders Say South Sudan May Be Closer to Peace Pact
description: JUBA, South Sudan  Regional leaders in East Africa announced Friday that they had made progress on a peace deal to help end the crisis in South Sudan, but there was no indication that either side in the conflict was abiding by a cease-fire.

title: Documentaries: Where Sundance Goes, Oscars Follow
description: LOS ANGELES  The winner of this years Oscar for best documentary, Searching for Sugar Man, was first seen at the Sundance Film Festival. Ten of the 15 documentaries on the 2014 Oscar shortlist made their debut in the Sundance snow.

title: Indian Family Sees Its History in a Shirt
description: Ten years ago, lost to drugs and alcohol, Karen Little Thunder moved back to the Rosebud Indian Reservation in South Dakota, where, she said, she saved her own life by reconnecting to her Lakota heritage, particularly the legacy of her great-great grandfather. He was Little Thunder, a Lakota leader and a contemporary of Crazy Horse, whose life spanned several decades central to the history of the tribe  from the battles it fought across the Great Plains to its resettlement on reservations.

title: Regulators Reviewing Volcker Rule Provision
description: Federal regulators on Friday once again tried to quiet the controversy about the potential impact of a provision of the Volcker Rule on hundreds of community banks.

title: Times Minute | Legal Victory for N.S.A.
description: Also on the Minute, Justin Bieber's new movie and looking back at drones in 2013.

title: Times Minute | Legal Victory for N.S.A.
description: In the Video

title: Monk Parrots Find Freedom
description: Staring at a parrot flying through the biting cold of Queens, it is easy to imagine its escape from the warmth of someones home, and just as easy to picture its brief future. But looks can be deceiving.

title: Her Term Is Up as Well
description: Greeting a visitor to her office at Wolfensohn Fund Management earlier this month, Diana Taylor betrayed a touch of jitters. Would you like something to drink, she asked twice in quick succession, before catching herself, and murmuring distractedly, Oh, I asked you that.

title: Trendsetter of 2013? Goodwill
description: It was an unexpected goofball hit that caught music industry pundits dozing in their rocking chairs. It was an exuberant success celebrating the sartorial joys of pajama bottoms worn as daywear, Grandpas plaid cardigans and moth-bitten leopard-print mink.

title: The Year in Style
description: Names that stood out: Miley, Macklemore, Marc and Tommy.

title: Muslim Brotherhood Supporters Defy Egyptian Crackdown
description: CAIRO  Defying the widening crackdown against them, supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood marched in cities across Egypt on Friday, protesting the governments decision to declare the group a terrorist organization and clashing with security forces in several places.

title: A Tow-Truck Driver Who Races to the Wreckage
description: New cars, full coverage, is what Joey Cali said he was looking for as he cruised the streets of East New York.

title: Medicare to Cover More Mental Health Costs
description: For decades, older adults with depression, anxiety and other psychological conditions have received unequal treatment under Medicare. The program paid a smaller share of the bill for therapy from psychiatrists, psychologists or clinical social workers than it did for medical services. And Medicare imposed strict lifetime limits on stays in psychiatric hospitals, although no such limits applied to medical care received in inpatient facilities.

title: Urban Melodrama
description: The saga of Gov. William Sulzers impeachment a century ago cannot be told often enough, both as an object lesson and as urban melodrama. Jack ODonnells Bitten by the Tiger (Chapel Hill Press) is a welcome addition to the growing genre.

title: Turkish Game Show Pulled After Hinting at Corruption Scandal
description: Last Updated, 7:43 p.m. | A popular Turkish game show disappeared from the airwaves this week after its host appeared to make a veiled reference to a widening corruption scandal by asking a contestant to name a slang term for a person who takes bribes.

title: He Makes Madames Toast
description: The pastry chef Franois Payard, 47, honed his craft first in France and later at Le Bernardin and Daniel; with the entrepreneur Marlon Abela he now has a dozen patisseries and bakeries in New York, Las Vegas, Japan and South Korea. On Sundays he tries to dial it back, so he can unwind with his wife, Fernanda Capobianco, 32, owner of the bakery Vegan Divas; prepare and share good food with friends in the couples Turtle Bay apartment; and take his mind off business for a day.

title: Protesters Clash With Police in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands of protesters calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey over a corruption scandal clashed with the police on Friday night as they tried to reach Taksim Square in central Istanbul, suggesting that the growing political crisis could converge with street unrest.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. While I (as a good Samaritan) was helping two groups of tourists at my local No. 1 subway station, the employee at the token booth refused to give me more than one subway map. How many maps does each booth get? Who is responsible for keeping each booth supplied? And, most important, what is M.T.A. policy about giving out subway maps to tourists?

title: Bill Cunningham | Start the Countdown
description: New Years Eve is a time for extravagant dresses, decorative headdresses and oversize necklaces. Shown here: designs worn at some of the best parties over the last 12 months  a preview of sorts for the Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibition of Charles Jamess spectacular ball gowns, opening in May. Museum parties included the one at the Frick Collection, with Champagne and caviar, and the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, with Champagne and doughnuts. (The Gardner opened, by the way, on New Years Day 1903.) In Times Square, it will be just Champagne (and lots of it).

title: Bill Cunningham | Start the Countdown
description: The night before the new year is a time for extravagant dresses, decorative headdresses and oversize necklaces.

title: Turkey Legs Conquer Land of Mouse Ears
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It made its humble debut at a single stand in the late 1980s next to Big Als Coonskin Caps in Frontierland. Slowly it spread  dripping, always dripping  beyond Walt Disney World here to Disneyland in California.

title: Ready, Set, Hike! A Trial Trek to MetLife Stadium
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The officials planning Super Bowl XLVIII want it to be the Super Bowl of public transportation. They are not just discouraging fans from walking to MetLife Stadium on game day in February  they are forbidding it. The only way in will be through a security perimeter, and there will be nowhere to enter the security perimeter on foot.

title: New Energy Struggles on Its Way to Markets
description: WASHINGTON  To stave off climate change, sources of electricity that do not emit carbon will have to replace the ones that do. But at the moment, two of those largest sources, nuclear and wind power, are trying to kill each other off.

title: Spirits of New York: Local Distilleries
description: An easing of laws regulating the production and sale of liquor in New York state has helped spur the establishment of micro-distilleries across the five boroughs.

title: A Taste of the Social Webs Turkey Legs
description: The web is studded with a perhaps surprising number of examples of Disney customers indulging in the massive drumsticks known as the jumbo turkey leg  from otherwise mild-mannered seemingly nuclear families to all-female groups of carnivores to whole collections of Instagrams that depict man versus meat.

title: Recipes With Local Liquor
description: King County Manhattan

title: Projects Under Scrutiny Displace Istanbuls Poor
description: ISTANBUL  On the narrow streets that slope from one of Istanbuls hills toward the shoreline of the Golden Horn waterway, old wooden houses where military officers of the Ottoman Empire lived are being painstakingly refurbished to their original design. Before the officers arrived, the area, which includes the citys biggest mosque, was for centuries a center of Islamic scholarship.

title: 90 Proof New York
description: Steven DeAngelo was bored on Wall Street. Colin Spoelman never found a job he wanted to do. Brad Estabrooke was laid off from one he would never miss. Dave Kyrejko was a former art school student working with fish tanks and aquariums.

title: Holocaust History, as Told by a Survivor
description: EMSDETTEN, Germany  LASZLO SCHWARTZ never had a proper adolescence. The Nazis made sure of that.

title: A New Years Wish List for New York City
description: The year we are putting behind us was dominated in New York by some of the liveliest politics in memory  or rather, some of the liveliest mayoral politics outside Toronto. We elected Bill de Blasio as the 109th mayor of the city and embraced his tale of two cities, but not until we milked the tale of two Anthony Weiners, one of them the story of a volatile and ineffectual former congressman, and the other the story of a prolific composer of lurid texts generated under the ingeniously conceived alias Carlos Danger.

title: Loyal Subscribers Keep Hobby Magazines Afloat
description: Lance Prucnals family, like others in the digital age, has canceled most of its newspaper and magazine subscriptions.

title: Bowing to Pressure, A&E Revokes Suspension of Duck Dynasty Star
description: The indefinite suspension of Phil Robertson, the patriarch of the family at the center of the A&E Networks huge ratings hit Duck Dynasty, became definite Friday  at zero episodes. The network announced he would not be suspended after all.

title: Bloomberg and Kelly Share Valedictory Moment
description: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, it has become something of an annual tradition: proclaiming yet another year of reduced crime and fewer murders.

title: First Attempts Fail to Free Ship Stranded by Heavy Ice
description: Icebreakers sent to free a stranded Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, off Antarctica were stopped by heavy ice within sight of the ship, officials said early Saturday. A Chinese icebreaker in the area, the Xue Long, or Snow Dragon, was asked to divert toward the Shokalskiy, which is carrying members of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition and became stuck in the ice on Tuesday about 1,700 miles south of Tasmania. A spokeswoman for the Australian Maritime Safety Authority said the Xue Long was about seven miles from the Shokalskiy when the ice became too thick to cut through. A French icebreaker also could not clear a path to the ship, said an expedition spokesman. The ships will await the arrival of an Australian icebreaker, which has a greater icebreaking capacity, he said.

title: The Faces Behind the Counter
description: When we eat at a McDonalds or a Burger King, we rarely pay attention to the people behind the counter. Our eyes are often focused upward on the brightly lighted menus, or perhaps downward on our smartphones or watches. But according to employment statistics, more than 55,000 people work in fast-food restaurants in New York City, and the number is rapidly increasing. Many of them earn the minimum wage: $7.25 an hour, increasing on Jan. 1 to $8. Forty percent are 25 or older. More than a quarter are parents raising children.

title: New Home Offers Hope After Years of Devastation
description: Kenneth Silver had little to lose by 2012. His way of life was already severely diminished, and when Hurricane Sandy swept through Coney Island, its waves washed away what little he had left.

description: WASHINGTON  An emergency federal program that acts as a lifeline for 1.3 million jobless workers will end on Saturday, drastically curtailing government support for the long-term unemployed and setting the stage for a major political fight in the new year.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Freedmen of Wisconsin
description: In the summer of 1862, a 31-year-old slave named Samuel Mathews and his family freed themselves by escaping from their plantation in Franklin County, Ala. With the army of Union Gen. William Rosecrans nearby, local Confederates had been talking of impressing Mathews into service as a cook. Unwilling to serve the rebel army, Samuel, his 25-year-old wife, Sarah, their 8-year-old son, Richard, and their 7-year-old daughter, Ellen, snuck away to a Union Army camp in nearby Tuscumbia, in the northwest corner of the state. But it was only the first step in their journey to freedom, which would last eight months and finish 700 miles north in the unlikely locale of rural Dodge County, Wis.

title: Chief Will Step Down After Five Years at Hyundais U.S. Unit
description: The chief executive of Hyundais American unit, who for five years navigated the company through the recession to huge growth, will step down next week, the company said in an abrupt announcement.

title: Different Paths, and Endings, for Two Derby Hopefuls
description: Horse racing is a game of chance. Seasoned horsemen and horseplayers know that if a Kentucky Derby favorite makes it to the starting gate, he is still anything but a sure bet.

title: Libya Holds Four American Military Personnel for Hours
description: WASHINGTON  Four American military personnel assigned to the United States Embassy in Tripoli, Libya, were detained Friday and then released after being held for hours by the countrys Interior Ministry, American officials said.

title: Academics Who Defend Wall St. Reap Reward
description: Signs of the energy business are inescapable in and around Houston  the pipelines, refineries and tankers that crowd the harbor, and the gleaming office towers where oil companies and energy traders have transformed the skyline.

title: Louis Scarcellas Ex-Partner Is Coming Under Scrutiny in Brooklyn Cases
description: Behind his back, Stephen W. Chmil was called Robin  the quiet sidekick to his more handsome, daring and celebrated partner.

title: Follow Me, Follow My Mom
description: I JUST dont like you sharing personal information with strangers, my mother said.

title: Hey, Stars, Be Nice to the Stagehands. You Might Need a Loan.
description: They create the technical razzle-dazzle when the Rockettes take the stage for the Radio City Christmas Spectacular. They raise the 45-foot-high Christmas tree for George Balanchines The Nutcracker. And on New Years Eve, they will make the opulent ballroom set spin for the Metropolitan Operas new Die Fledermaus.

title: Asada, After a Struggle, Is Soaring Over the Ice Again
description: DETROIT  Figure skatings kiss-and-cry area is designed for sequined emotion. But when Mao Asada of Japan received her composite score at the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, her expression remained as flat and neutral as the ice.

title: Greeting the New Year
description: This is the season of lists: roundups and recaps, forecasts and resolutions.

title: Finessing Typewriters for Nearly 40 Years, and Now Turning Over the Keys
description: Bino Gan has never seen any of Woody Allens movies, but in his own way he has helped in the writing of them. Mr. Gan has made sure that the famous Olympia typewriter Mr. Allen uses to write his screenplays is always in good pecking order.

title: In Miracle Season, Auburn Breaks a Machine
description: The Auburn football program has a thing for slogans. All In was the rallying cry a couple of years ago. Together showed up on shirts this season, a Season of Miracles in which Destiny was big, alongside the perennial catchphrase Family  the kind of stuff you hear on corporate retreats or in Hallmark specials.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 27, 2013
Police Salaries and Pensions Push California City to Brink
description: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif.  Emerging from Los Angeless vast eastern sprawl, the freeway glides over a narrow pass and slips gently into the scrubby, palm-flecked Coachella Valley.

title: Despair at Guantnamo
description: In April, when a hunger strike by detainees at the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, was in its third month, Pentagon officials agreed with defense lawyers that the underlying cause was a growing despair among prisoners who have been in detention for a decade with no hope of getting out. The protest, which at its height involved 106 of the 166 prisoners there this summer, served to put the Guantnamo issue back on the radar in Washington.

title: Singapores Angry Migrant Workers
description: Frustration among Singapores unappreciated and underpaid migrant workers has been building in recent years as their numbers have grown faster than the country can accommodate them. Tensions boiled over earlier this month, after a 33-year-old Indian migrant worker was killed by a bus in the Little India neighborhood. A crowd of fellow workers from South Asia gathered at the scene. Their anger quickly escalated, with some 400 people pelting stones, attacking emergency responders and setting fire to vehicles. It was the worst riot to hit Singapore, one of the worlds most orderly countries, since 1969.

title: This Week, Mass Surveillance Wins
description: Has the National Security Agencys mass collection of Americans phone records actually helped to prevent terrorist attacks?

title: Summer Camp That Makes a Difference
description: Yancy Riveras son Brian, 11, is autistic and painfully shy. Summers used to be the worst time, with Brian out of school and spending his days watching TV. But it was not the 1990s anymore, he told them; the days of bandit capitalism in Russia were over. I decided its what I wanted, and that was that, he said.

It is his steadfast belief that they have an enviable foundation, especially on defense, and a young core that will expand through free agency and the draft.

title: A Civil Servant in Mexico Tests U.S. on Asylum
description: LA RUANA, Mexico  Jittery families cram into his tiny office here, daily. Hundreds more have appeared at the San Diego border 1,500 miles away, clutching an official-looking letter bearing his name, gambling that its description of the violence in this blistering stretch of central Mexico will help them gain asylum in the United States.

title: No Cheer for the Jobless
description: The House Republicans who refused to renew expiring federal jobless benefits before leaving Washington for an extended Christmas break have shown no inclination to revisit the issue when they return to work in January. This is unconscionable. In each of the previous seven major recessions, dating back to 1958, Congress has never let federal benefits expire when the need has been as great as it is today. And for good reason. Prematurely ending benefits inflicts needless harm on families  the average benefit is about $270 a week  as well as avoidable damage on the economy by denting essential spending.

title: 12 Years of Mayor Bloomberg
description: When he walked into the mayors office 12 years ago, businessman and billionaire Michael Bloomberg took charge of a damaged city. The World Trade Center was a windblown construction site, barely cleared after the attacks on Sept. 11. Tourists were afraid to come to the city; residents were afraid to stay. The budget was a disaster, $3 billion to $5 billion in the red. In a modest speech at an intentionally modest inauguration, Mr. Bloomberg nevertheless pledged to rebuild and renew New York and to keep it the capital of the free world.

title: Words for the Dumpster
description: WITH the last tick of 2013, lets throw out the most annoying, overused and abused words of the year. A few of these terms, twerking or stay classy, die a natural death when someone like John McCain starts using them  the aural equivalent of a comb-over. Others need a push.

title: When Demons Are Real
description: SOME months ago, on a warm Friday evening in Accra, Ghana, I found myself in an all-night prayer session with a charismatic evangelical church. All-night prayer has become wildly popular in the city, somewhat to the distress of those who object to the late-night noise, which rivals that of an American frat party.

title: Confessions of a Columnist
description: IN ancient Sanskrit, the word pundit meant wise man or religious sage. In modern English, it means often wrong, rarely accountable. There are ways that those of us who scribble about politics can avoid living down to that reputation  by keeping our predictions vague (it worked for Nostradamus), by sticking to sure things (I told you Herman Cain wouldnt be elected president), or by deploying weasel words like its possible that ... at every opportunity. But time, chance and fallibility eventually make false prophets of us all.

title: When the Mentally Ill Own Guns
description: Lawmakers who refuse to support effective gun safety measures often prefer to talk about better screening of the mentally ill to identify deranged would-be perpetrators before they can carry out mass shootings. This is, of course, a political dodge. Even in the handful of states where law enforcement agencies are trying to confiscate the guns of unstable individuals, state and federal laws too often enable the mentally ill to reclaim their guns as a right under the Second Amendment.

title: Bitcoin Is Evil
description: Its always important, and always hard, to distinguish positive economics  how things work  from normative economics  how things should be. Indeed, on many of the macro issues Ive written about it has been obvious that large numbers of economists cant bring themselves to make that distinction; they dislike activist government on political grounds, and this leads them to make really bad arguments about why fiscal stimulus cant work and monetary stimulus will be disastrous. I dont, by the way, think that this effect is symmetric: although people like Robert Lucas were quick to accuse people like Christy Romer of fabricating macro arguments to support a big-government agenda, this didnt actually happen.

In states like Idaho, Montana and Wyoming, an age-old antipathy to wolves flourishes, unchecked.

The politician, invariably male, rises to power with a gaudy indifference to manners and derision for all that came before. He is sarcastic and loves to lecture, sneers at special pleaders and whiners, and his caustic energy persuades fed-up voters that he is the one who can finally take a cattle prod to a fat and unresponsive government.

title: Game Theory: The Year of the Blockbuster

Also memorable is Trevors May-December romance with Patricia Madrazo in Grand Theft Auto V, revealing the tender side of a psychopath, capped by the long, bittersweet drive back to Martin Madrazos house while listening to Chicagos If You Leave Me Now. And in BioShock Infinite what stuck with me was everything from the games audacious first hour or so, the racist Boxer Rebellion and Battle of Wounded Knee exhibitions from the Hall of Heroes, and listening to Elizabeth sing Will the Circle Be Unbroken.

Dick Tracy has just about everything required of an extravaganza: a smashing cast, some great Stephen Sondheim songs, all of the technical wizardry that money can buy (plus the knowledge of how and when to use it), and a screenplay (credited to Jim Cash and Jack Epps Jr.) that observes the fine line separating true comedy from lesser camp, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. title: Calder Lawsuit Dismissed
description: A $20 million fraud lawsuit filed by the heirs of the sculptor Alexander Calder against the estate of his art dealer, Klaus G. Perls, has been dismissed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The suit claimed that Perls and his family held on to hundreds of Calders works, cheated the artists estate out of tens of millions of dollars over the course of three decades and sold fake Calder works. According to the decision by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich, made public last week, the various claims are an incoherent stew of irrelevance and innuendo and the evidence failed to show that any fraud had been committed. All these allegations are so patently inadequate that the court can only conclude that they were brought solely for the purpose of harassment or embarrassment, Judge Kornreich said. The lawsuit was filed in 2010, two years after Mr. Perls died. His wife, Dolly, and employees of his gallery have also died. Calder died in 1976, leaving Judge Kornreich to conclude, Plaintiffs are attempting to litigate issues that necessarily stretch back decades without any personal knowledge or contemporaneous records, where nearly all of the people who had personal knowledge of the facts of the case are dead. Perls represented Calder for more than 20 years, and they were considered friends who frequently dined and traveled together and visited each others families. The Calder Foundation, which is devoted to collecting, cataloging and archiving Calder works, could not be reached for comment on Sunday.

The Pandoras box of camera tricks that is opened here must surely have been intended to capture the speed and disorientation of wartime experience, and the jittery atmosphere in which soldiers snap judgments are made, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. description: China is stepping up efforts to ban smoking in public places by ordering Communist Party officials to lead by example and refrain from smoking in government offices, schools, hospitals, sports and cultural venues and on public transport. Party officials have also been ordered to ask others not to smoke in public.

title: The Year That Will Be
description: Late December is traditionally a time to recap the years news, but do we really have the stomach for it in 2013? Lets look ahead, with a precap of news sure to happen in 2014.

title: Behind the Cover: Henry Leutwyler on Photographing the Things They Lived With
description: Henry Leutwyler shot the cover for the 2013 issue of The Lives They Lived. The issue, subtitled And the Things They Loved, also includes Leutwylers photographs of objects that belonged to several people who died during the past year.

title: This Year in Small Business: Highlights From 2013
description: In July, I wrote a half-time report that compiled links to some of the best stories for small-business owners that I had read so far this year. Heres an update through the end of December.

title: Chinese Women Name and Shame Companies They Say Discriminate
description: Eight young Chinese women, most of them university students facing a tight job market, have named and shamed dozens of Chinese companies they say are illegally specifying that only men can apply for certain positions. They have mailed their complaints to government human resource departments in the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou and Nanjing, and in Yunnan and Henan Provinces.

title: Cooper Tire Abandons Merger
description: Updated, 1:45 p.m. |

title: Gunmen in Greece Attack German Ambassadors Residence
description: Assailants raked the German ambassadors residence in Athens with gunfire early on Monday in an attack that caused no injuries, Greek police officials said.

title: China Says Local-Level Debt Soars, Stirring Fear
description: HONG KONG  The total debt of local governments in China has soared to nearly $3 trillion as the countrys addiction to credit-fueled growth has deepened in recent years, according to the findings of a long-awaited report released on Monday by the central auditing agency.

title: Once an Agitator, Now in Charge of Delhis Government
description: NEW DELHI  On Saturday morning, Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, took the subway from his house in Ghaziabad, a suburb bordering Delhi, to Barakhamba Road in central Delhi. This was an unusual way to travel for someone about to be inaugurated as the citys chief minister. But Mr. Kejriwal, the harbinger of a new paradigm in Indian politics, has done much to suggest a flair for the unusual.

title: BEST OF 2013
description: These 15 stories about individuals and groups showcased style, innovation, irreverence and original thinking.

title: Remember Us? Remember the Writers, Too
description: If youre anything like the Bagger, youve spent the last week in a blissful state of awards-season blackout. Oscar who? Academy what? To return to our rightful place of handicapping the waltz with the little bald man, we thought wed start off slow, with a little recap.

title: Laws Deserve More Than Those Cute Names
description: WASHINGTON  Laws used to have boring names, like the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Now they bear titles that seem focus-group-tested, like the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

title: Image of the Day: December 30
Narrowing the Income Gap, Without Another Bust
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Firing Season Begins With a Fusillade
description: Black Monday lived up to its billing this year as five N.F.L. coaches and one general manager were fired in a dramatic, if unsurprising, mass catharsis that left owners across the league ready to reset the clock and shop for replacements.

title: In Our Pages: December 31
description: 1913: Montreal Left Without Water

title: Seeking a Buyer for a Home Full of Creatures From the Time of Noah
description: The first thing prospective buyers should know about the two-story rowhouse for sale in Borough Park, Brooklyn, is that its glassy-eyed menagerie of taxidermied tenants, from the family of lions to the fluffy-feathered emu, will be removed before the closing.

title: A Distributors Online Pressure and an Actors Personal Pressure
description: Context matters, as Chiwetel Ejiofor can confirm. The star of 12 Years a Slave was minimized on posters for the Italian version of the drama, which instead prominently featured Brad Pitt and Michael Fassbender. Mr. Pitt is a producer and has a small but pivotal part in the film; Mr. Fassbender, playing a brutal slaveholder, has drawn some acclaim. But neither are the lead, nor have they received the kind of attention that Mr. Ejiofor has for his searing performance. After an outcry online that the advertising was racist, the company that produced the posters withdrew them and apologized.

title: Bain to Buy Control of Bobs Discount Furniture
description: The private equity firm Bain Capital announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in Bobs Discount Furniture, the chain of stores known for its low-tech commercials featuring its founder, Bob Kaufman.The companys management team will continue to own a significant stake in the business, according to a news release announcing the deal on Monday.

title: Business Behaving Badly
description: Despite having to paying millions or even billions of dollars in fines, many companies look at the payments as just the cost of doing business.

title: Video: A Year of Corporate Fines
description: For Wall Street, 2013 will go down as the Year of the Big Fine.

description: In the Video

title: I Had My DNA Picture Taken, With Varying Results
description: I like to plan ahead; that much I knew about myself before I plunged into exploring my genetic code. Im a healthy 28-year-old woman, but some nasty diseases run in my family: coronary heart disease, rheumatoid arthritis, Alzheimers and breast cancer.

title: Israel by Foot (and Bike and Sea)
description: From January to March 2014, Israel will host five races throughout the country   three marathons, a half-marathon and an Ironman triathlon.

title: Cracker Barrel Responds to Activist Investor
description: Cracker Barrel wont be sold to the entrepreneurial mind of Sardar Biglari anytime soon.

title: Second Official to Leave After Health Site Trouble
description: WASHINGTON  The No. 2 official at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, who supervised the troubled rollout of President Obamas health care law, is retiring, administration officials said Monday.

title: The Lincolns and the Booths
description: Over a year before firing the shot that killed Abraham Lincoln, the assassin John Wilkes Booth began to stalk his victim by worming his way into Lincolns social circles. But even as the young actor pressed in, Lincolns friends and acquaintances began to cross his path through a series of bizarre, random personal encounters. Fate, it seemed, was stalking the stalker.

title: Video: Matthew McConaughey on The Wolf of Wall Street
description: Matthew McConaughey has had a busy awards season. Although his leading role in the drama Dallas Buyers Club is garnering most of the Oscar attention, the small part he has in Martin Scorseses Wolf of Wall Street also has critics talking (and humming). As a stock trader who teaches a few tricks of the trade to his new employee Jordan Belfort, Mr. McConaughey delivers his dialogue with a sharp tongue and a greedy spirit. In this video, from a recent luncheon for the film, he spoke about that scene and, in particular, the chest-thumping song that he hums in it.

title: Game Theory: The Last of Us, Revisited
description: Chris Suellentrop reviewed The Last of Us, a post-apocalyptic video game drama from the studio Naughty Dog, for The New York Times in June. After that, a member of the team that made the game wrote a rebuttal letter. Below is a condensed and edited version of that essay. A little working knowledge of the game  including familiarity with characters like Ellie, David and Joel  is helpful for following along.

title: Second Deadly Blast Hits Russia
description: Scenes from Volgograd, where an explosion on a trolley bus killed at least 15 people on Monday. The attack came a day after a suicide bombing at the citys main railroad station.

title: Springsteen Album Leaked Through Amazon Download
description: Bruce Springsteens new album, High Hopes, made a brief appearance in MP3 form in the music download section of Amazon.com on Saturday, just over two weeks before its scheduled release date. Although the album could not be purchased and downloaded as a whole, all 12 of its songs could be purchased individually, Billboard reported. Except in the case of the title track, which has been available since Nov. 25, theloophole was closed quickly, but the album appeared on several file-sharing sites within hours.

title: 3-Bean Good Luck Salad With Cumin Vinaigrette
description: This is a colorful variation of the black-eyed peas salad I always serve at my New Years Day open house. You can cook the black beans and red beans together or separately. The black-eyed peas cook more quickly so should be cooked separately.

title: Australia Plans Evacuation of Passengers Stranded in Ice
description: Maritime safety officials began preparations on Tuesday for a helicopter rescue of scientists and others aboard a chartered research ship that has been stuck in Antarctic ice for a week.

title: Farro and Swiss Chard Salad With Grapefruit Vinaigrette
description: A farmer at my market recently was selling huge, sturdy bunches of Swiss chard, the kind I used to cook with in France, with wide ribs and heavy leaves. One bunch weighed almost 2 pounds; the leaves alone, off the stems, weighed in at about 13 ounces. I used the greens for more than one dish, including this substantial salad, to which I also added diced sauted chard ribs.

title: Lentil and Carrot Salad With Middle Eastern Spices
description: I combined two of my favorite Mediterranean salads to stretch the cup of lentils I had in my pantry. Take care not to overcook the lentils; they should be slightly al dente. They go quickly from al dente to mushy, so make sure to check after 25 minutes.

title: Israeli Couscous and Spicy Herb Paste Frittata
description: In Italy leftover pasta is often recycled into a frittata. I decided to do the same with some Israeli couscous that I had tossed with a spicy Yemeni herb and chili paste called zhoug that I found in Yotam Ottolenghis book Jerusalem. I liked the couscous with the chili paste better in this pretty frittata than I did on its own. You wont use up all of the zhoug in the frittata but you will be glad to have the relish on hand to use as a condiment. Note that I do not cook my Israeli couscous in boiling water; I find that it becomes too mushy that way.

title: Andrew Lucks Monster Problem
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Andrew Luck, the record-setting quarterback of the Indianapolis Colts. Mr. Luck was the N.F.L.s number one draft pick in 2012 and led a remarkable turnaround of his team during his first year, taking it from 2-14 in 2011 to 11-5 in 2012. This year the Colts continue to thrive under Lucks leadership, finishing the regular season atop their division with an 11-5 record.

title: Volvo Recalls 31,000 Cars for Oil Pressure Sensor Problem
description: Volvo will recall nearly 31,000 S60 sedans with 5-cylinder engines from the 2011 and 2012 model years because of a problem with the oil pressure warning sensors. The automaker discovered the defect after a mechanic performing routine maintenance on one of the cars forgot to put oil in the engine before the owner drove it off.

title: Regulators Have New Cases of Frauds and Abuses to Tackle
description: Goodbye 2013 frauds; welcome 2014 abuses.

title: Monday Motorsports: Formula One Champion Michael Schumacher Hospitalized After Skiing Accident
description: Michael Schumacher, the seven-time Formula One world champion who retired for the second time in 2012, underwent emergency surgery for brain trauma Sunday after a skiing accident in the French Alps. His manager, Sabine Kehm, said that he was skiing with his son on backcountry terrain near the Mribel ski resort when he fell and hit his head on a rock.

title: Powerlessness and Pretense
description: MOSCOW  Within two hours of a deadly bombing Sunday at the main railroad station in Volgograd, officials announced that they had identified the female suicide bomber. A name, a photo and a biography spread from news agency to news agency; law enforcement supplied journalists with details, including the tidbit that she had been married to two different Chechen rebel fighters, both now dead.

title: On the Porch in Osage County
description: The Weinstein Company gambled that opening its dark family dramedy August: Osage County two days after Christmas, instead of on Christmas (when everyone has enough dark family dramedy to contend with), would pay off at the box office. In five theaters, its take ranked with this seasons other dysfunctional family stories, like Nebraska, but may not have had the surge the studio was hoping for.

title: De Blasio Recognizes Obstacles Standing in Way of Schools Plan
description: As he announced his choice of Carmen Faria as the next chancellor of New York City schools, Bill de Blasio suggested on Monday that he would depart drastically from the policies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. He pledged to reduce the emphasis on standardized testing in classrooms, and he said he would end, at least for now, the practice of closing low-performing schools.

title: No Meeting With Leader of Japan, Chinese Say
description: BEIJING  Chinas Foreign Ministry said Monday that Chinese leaders, angered over a visit last week by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to a contentious war shrine in Tokyo, would not meet with Mr. Abe.

title: Celebrity Cancer Diagnosis Spurs Smokers to Try to Quit
description: Researchers have found that a diagnosis of cancer in a high-profile person sharply increases efforts to quit smoking.

title: Painting Bought at Antique Shop for  400 Is Found to Be a Van Dyck
description: Father Jamie McLeod, a priest who runs a religious retreat in rural Derbyshire, England, became curious about the value of a painting he had bought at an antique shop in Cheshire about a dozen years ago, and brought it to the experts on the British version of the television program Antiques Roadshow.

title: New York Stays Ahead of Florida in Population
description: ALBANY  New Yorks hold on its status as the countrys third most populous state is down to fewer than 100,000 people, according to figures released on Monday by the Census Bureau. And the trend is not in the states favor, as Florida, which is No. 4, gained residents at three times the pace of the Empire State over a years span.

title: The Mileage Resets as the Perks Fade
description: HERES a variation on that old chestnut employed by some local TV stations announcing the first New Years baby: Meet Randall Stempler, the first long-haul flier of the new year  or at least the first one that I have heard from.

title: N.H.L. Tests Fans Zeal With 6 Outdoor Games
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  The N.H.L.s schedule of six outdoor games, its most ever, will begin Wednesday with the Winter Classic before an expected crowd of about 110,000 at Michigan Stadium. That game and three others are sold out or nearly sold out.

title: Philadelphia Monsignor to Be Released on Bail Pending Appeal in Abuse Case
description: PHILADELPHIA  A state judge ruled on Monday that a senior Catholic official who was sent to prison for his role in a sexual abuse scandal should be released on bail after his conviction for child endangerment was overturned.

title: Deadly Clashes Between Iraqi Forces and Tribal Fighters in Anbar
description: BAGHDAD  Heavy fighting erupted on Monday between government security forces and tribal gunmen when the police moved to dismantle a Sunni protesters camp in Ramadi, west of Baghdad in Anbar Province, police and local officials said. At least 17 people died in the clashes, according to a security official.

description: Excerpt One, from the Prologue:

title: Spider-Man Not a Flop, Broadway Restaurateur Declares
description: Its semiofficial: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark may have racked up unprecedented losses of up to $60 million by the time it closes on Jan. 4.

title: Visual Delights on Film and Science-Driven Theater
description: January events at the intersection of science and culture.

title: America in 2013, as Told in Charts
description: Looking back on 2013, many of the economic and political themes seemed familiar: a weak economy. Growing income inequality. Gridlock in Washington. Partisan wrangling over fiscal policy. But others, like the disastrous rollout of the Affordable Care Act HealthCare.gov website and the government shutdown, were new or at least revivals. Below are 10 charts to illustrate a depressing first year of President Obamas second term:

title: 'Beautiful'
description: Scenes from "Beautiful: The Carole King Musical," on Broadway at the Stephen Sondheim Theater.

title: Uganda Issues a Warning Over Fighting in South Sudan
description: JUBA, South Sudan  As the South Sudanese military warned that a rebel column of armed youths had advanced toward the city of Bor on Monday, the president of neighboring Uganda threatened to intervene if the rebels kept fighting, introducing the possibility of a broader regional conflict.

title: Playing With How We Keep Faces Straight
description: A new computer algorithm can subtly modify the image of a persons face to make it easier or harder to remember.

title: De Blasio Announces Chancellor
description: At a news conference in Brooklyn, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio announced his choice for schools chancellor, Carmen Faria, a veteran of the school system.

title: Pollution Rising, Chinese Fear for Soil and Food
description: CHENJIAWAN, China  The farm-to-table process in China starts in villages like this one in the agricultural heartland. Food from the fields of Ge Songqing and her neighbors ends up in their kitchens or in the local market, and from there goes to other provinces. The foods are Chinese staples: rice, cabbage, carrots, turnips and sweet potatoes.

title: Republicans React to Benghazi News
description: The article The Times published on Benghazi this weekend infuriated many Republicans, who ran screaming to television studios.

title: Charities That Inspire Kids: The Gift of Halloween
description: Earlier this month, I asked readers to share stories of charities that had inspired their families and sparked an urge to give in their children. As we head through whats often a week of charitable giving for many and into 2014, well post some of those stories here.

title: F.A.A. Picks Diverse Sites to Carry Out Drone Tests
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration will authorize test sites for drone aircraft in upstate New York, New Jersey and at least eight other states, the agency said on Monday, preparing for a time when unmanned aircraft of various shapes and sizes cruise over the landscape.

title: A Quiet Summer in Cooperstown
description: It was inevitable that the steroids era would intrude on the business of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Mark McGwire had been rejected six times by the Baseball Writers Association of America when Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and Sammy Sosa missed out for the first time last January. In his seventh rejection, McGwire received 16.9 percent of the vote, less than half of Bondss 36.2 percent and far short of the 75 percent required for election.

title: Bankers Beaten Back A Bit
description: Mike Konczal has some surprising news: Financial reform is getting somewhere. We entered 2013 amid universal cynicism; the bankers had bought Washington again, and any reforms would be purely cosmetic. We leave it with significant progress. You can still argue that reform falls far short of what should have happened, and wont do much to prevent future crises. But relative to expectations, this is a happy story.

title: A Happy Moment With Magic Johnson
description: Need a post-holiday (or pre-holiday) pick-me-up? Click over to 24 Hours of Happy, the addictive video for the Pharrell Williams song Happy, featured in Despicable Me 2.

title: Fire at Swatch Workshop Causes Production Delays
description: MADRID  The Swatch Group, the worlds largest watchmaker, said on Monday that production of some watch components would be delayed for as long as two months after a fire destroyed one of its Swiss workshops.

title: Obamacare Not A Total Disaster, Continued
description: Perceptions about health reform are in an interesting place. Just about everyone on the right is still living in October, the annus horribilis of Obamacare (yes, I know it was just a month, and I dont care), and is waiting to move in for the kill after the whole thing collapses. Meanwhile, a funny thing has been happening: enrollments surged this month, to such an extent that the original expectation of 7 million people signed up via the exchanges by the end of March no longer looks crazy.

title: The Starting Lineup: As Othello, a 6-Foot-3 Running Back, No. 27, Eddie George
description: When Eddie George retired from football in 2005, after nine years as an N.F.L. running back, he was 32 years old and had racked up some enviable statistics: 130 consecutive regular-season game starts, 10,441 rushing yards and 68 touchdowns, along with the Heisman Trophy he won at Ohio State University in 1995. Since then, he has started a string of businesses, including fitness programs and a landscape architecture company, opened a sports-themed restaurant and been a motivational speaker.

title: Israels Pairing Prisoner Release and Settlements Angers Many
description: JERUSALEM  As Israel released a group of 26 long-serving Palestinian prisoners early Tuesday, with another announcement of new construction in West Bank settlements expected soon, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faced sharp criticism from all corners, including conservative members of his own coalition.

title: Let Them Eat Acorns
description: SWOOPE, Va.  Hog heaven, it turns out, is a place on earth, a sun-dappled mountainside in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia where one day this fall a herd of Gloucestershire Old Spots, Hampshires, Yorkshires and Durocs contentedly gorged their way toward 300 pounds.

title: Hand-Holding for a Nervous Passenger
description: IVE been traveling my entire life. My dad was an importer who traveled quite a bit to Asia back in the 1960s. So I think my family was actually bred to travel.

title: U.S. Population Up Just 0.7%, Census Finds
description: The United States population grew only 0.72 percent last year, to 316,128,839 in July from 313,873,685 a year earlier, according to figures released Monday by the Census Bureau.

title: Reading Between the Lines of 2013s Big Stories
description: When we see a story in the news repeatedly, we have a tendency to think it must be important. Thinking something is important often means we feel we should do something about it. This year, there were a lot of catchy headlines in the financial news, and most of them represented little more than noise. There were, however, a few important themes in 2013 that may affect your financial plan as we head into 2014.

description: The messages on Twitter clogging users timelines probably seemed vague to some.

title: Delayed Plans Muddy Fate of Italian Bank
description: ROME  The Italian government signaled on Monday that it had no interest in nationalizing Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the countrys oldest bank, after shareholders over the weekend overruled bank management and delayed plans to raise urgently needed cash.

title: Singapore Leads Pack as Cities Prepare for an Influx of Fliers
description: SINGAPORE  Travelers passing through the gigantic Changi International Airport here rarely have to wait long for bags or boarding. Unlike many other airports in this fast-growing region, Singapores airport can handle far more than the 53 million travelers that embarked and departed there this year.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate
description: RECENT SALE

title: Scenes of Life Aboard a Ship Stranded in Antarctic Ice
description: With the bleak, icy weather outside their windows, passengers and crew on a research ship stranded in the Antarctic are occupying themselves in the cozy interior by reading books or laptops, chatting in small groups and passing food to each other at a communal dining table.

title: Spared Winter Freeze, Floridas Mangroves Are Marching North
description: Much of the Florida shoreline was once too cold for the tropical trees called mangroves, but the plants are now spreading northward at a rapid clip, scientists reported Monday. That finding is the latest indication that global warming, though still in its early stages, is already leading to ecological changes so large they can be seen from space.

title: Tales of Caring With Warm Hands
description: The higher one soars in the health care universe, the broader the view becomes. Medical leaders with businessmens titles tend to forswear direct patient care early on  sick people and their beleaguered caretakers shrink into small faceless populations far easier to deal with in the aggregate than in the particular.

title: Giants Promise an Overhaul Under Coughlin
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin, General Manager Jerry Reese and the teams co-owner, John Mara, took turns addressing reporters Monday in the wake of the teams 7-9 season, which ended with the Giants out of the playoffs for the fourth time in five years.

title: Plants Do Compete, and Take Time Off
description: Q. My orchid quit blooming while I cared for a friends profusely blooming plant for a year. When the visiting orchid was gone, my plant started sending out shoots again. Is there any evidence that plants are competitive?

title: Inaugurations, Through the Decades
description: Mayoral inaugurations often reflect characteristics of both the mayor and the era. Here are some reports and recordings from inaugurations dating back to Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1934.

title: Credit Score, by Multiple Choice
description: No credit? No problem  just take a test.

title: Evaluating Borrowers
description: The Entrepreneurial Finance Lab uses a psychometric test to help banks decide whether to lend money in developing economies to small entrepreneurs who otherwise might have no access to credit.

title: In 17 Seconds, Blackhawks Rewrite Ending
description: It was a great Stanley Cup final series, and now the reporters in Boston were prepared to fly back to Chicago for Game 7. The Bruins were ahead, 2-1, in Game 6 as the clock dipped below two minutes and the desperate Blackhawks pulled their goalie. The Boston crowd was roaring. The reporters were typing: The Boston Bruins beat the Chicago Blackhawks and extended the Stanley Cup to a decisive seventh game. ...

title: More Crocodile Species Discovered
description: Biologists studying the African slender-snouted crocodile have determined that there are more species than previously believed. A comparison of animals from West African populations with some from Central Africa suggests that the groups are distinct species that diverged about seven million years ago. The results, published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, may have implications for conservation efforts.

title: What Works for Sharks and Honeybees ...
description: The Hadza people of Tanzania are among the last hunter-gatherer groups on earth, foraging on foot for most of their food. Now scientists have analyzed their movements and determined that they fit a mathematical pattern that also works for sharks, honeybees and other foraging animals.

title: Divining Chinas Direction by What Xi Ate
description: The Chinese public is digging deep for portents of the Communist Partys anticorruption campaign in President Xi Jinpings recent lunch at a popular steamed bun restaurant in western Beijing.

title: Singular Voices From the Arab Uprising
description: Amid the countless images and reports of impassioned populaces marching through the streets that have flashed across countless television screens, here is one thought that never came to this (apparently innocent) mind: Demonstrations are a great place to grope strangers.

title: The Unforgettable Sight, and Sound, of Cabreras Swings
description: A lesson learned on breezy, spring afternoon at Tiger Stadium a quarter century ago: when a transcendent player comes to the plate, stop whatever you are doing  eating a hot dog, catching up on your scorecard, daydreaming  and watch.

title: Spain Tightens Rules for Bottled Olive Oil
description: MADRID  Every morning, cafes here fill up with people enjoying a typical Spanish breakfast, including pouring olive oil out of a plain glass cruet onto a slice of toasted bread.

title: Look for the Label
description: In Spain, producers of olive oil are hoping stricter bottling and labeling rules will bolster brand recognition.

title: There Is Crying in Baseball
description: Upon securing the final out of the eighth inning on Sept. 26, Mariano Rivera retreated to the training room inside the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, descending into a temporary sanctuary hidden from the 48,675 fans who had come to say goodbye to him.

title: A Record-Setting Week on Broadway
description: Santa was in an especially generous mood last week on Broadway, where several shows looked under their trees and saw record-setting receipts.

title: Cocktail Culture | A Bubbly Twist on the Negroni
description: When a bartender at Bar Basso in Milan mistakenly grabbed a bottle of spumante instead of gin while making a Negroni (comprised of the holy trinity of the cocktail world: Campari, Italian vermouth and gin), he inadvertently created a simple, endlessly drinkable twist on a classic: the Negroni Sbagliato (sbagliato is Italian for mistaken). By substituting effervescent wine for the piney, citrusy sweetness of gin, hed somehow stripped the Negroni down to its essence. Sbagliatos retain that pleasing chalkiness and minerality of Campari and the herby qualities of vermouth, but these flavors stretch out across the bubbles and somehow lead one to drink more slowly, savoring the medley. Unlike Negronis, which are all booze but taste like adult candy, Sbagliatos are less likely to put ones party-appropriate sobriety at risk. But if they do wind up going down a little too quickly, rest easy  the Sbagliato is significantly lower in alcohol by volume than its brawnier big brother, a key consideration in the holiday marathon drinking season.

title: $1 Million Prize for Pakistani Pediatrician
description: The first $1 million Caplow Childrens Prize was won by a Pakistani pediatrician who hopes to save hundreds of newborns in one Karachi neighborhood.

title: Kenneth C. Edelin, Doctor at Center of Landmark Abortion Case, Dies at 74
description: Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, a Boston physician whose 1975 manslaughter conviction for performing a legal abortion was overturned on appeal in a landmark test of medical, legal, religious and political questions surrounding abortion in America, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 74.

But the imported and reconstructed monastic setting of the Cloisters, the Washington Heights branch of the Metropolitan Museum, was certainly appropriate to the modern premiere of this medieval mystery play, and to judge from later presentations of it there, the atmospheric trappings must have figured prominently in the productions enchantment.

title: China: Police Kill 8 Assailants in a Clash in Xinjiang
description: Security officers on Monday killed eight attackers and detained one person as the police repelled an assault on a police station in the western region of Xinjiang, government officials said. A report on Tianshan News, the official news website of Xinjiang, said nine people armed with knives had attacked a police station in Shache County, near Kashgar. The attackers also threw explosive devices and set police cars on fire, the report said. It provided no further details. Violence between civilians and security forces has become increasingly common in Xinjiang, where officials say they are trying to deal with rebels or terrorists who live in towns heavily populated by ethnic Uighurs. But Uighurs in the area and some scholars in Beijing and abroad say the Chinese government exaggerates the terrorist threat and is instead mostly deploying security forces to maintain tight control over people who feel oppressed by the ethnic Han authorities.
